Ugh. Okay, so, people always ask me that. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was…complicated. And kinda heartbreaking, even now.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I knew, deep down, I couldn't give that to him. Or her. I didn't even know what it was at first, which made it even harder.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a kid either. They were more into antique furniture and quiet evenings.

And Paulie Bleeker…he was great. He was really great. But he was sixteen too. We were kids trying to be adults, and that just doesn't work.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…different. They were ready. They had a beautiful home, a stable life, and they *wanted* a baby so badly. They were…grown-up. And I wanted my kid to have that. I wanted them to have a life where they didn't have to worry about money or where they were going to live or if their mom was going to finish high school.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a choice. A really hard choice. A choice that I knew was best for the kid, even if it was the worst thing for me.

It still stings, you know? Sometimes I wonder what things would be like if I'd kept it. But then I remember Mark and Vanessa, and I know I made the right decision. They gave that baby a good life. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But it was the right thing to do. And sometimes, the right thing to do is also the hardest thing to do.

Ugh, okay, so love and responsibility. Those are, like, *huge* topics. And honestly, I didn't go looking for either of them. They kinda just…happened to me.

At the beginning, I thought love was just…whatever you see in movies. All dramatic and swoony. And responsibility? That was something adults did, something boring. But being pregnant, and deciding to give the baby up…that changed everything.

I learned that love isn't always about romance. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if that means letting them go. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. That's what Mark and Vanessa showed me. They were willing to open their hearts and their home to a baby, and to *me*, even though it was scary and complicated. That's a different kind of love than I ever imagined.

And responsibility? That's not just about paying bills and doing chores. It's about owning your choices, even the messy ones. It's about facing the consequences and doing what's right, even when it's hard. I had to grow up *fast*, you know? I had to think about someone other than myself. And that was…terrifying. But also kinda empowering.

I also learned that love and responsibility aren't always easy. There's a lot of heartache and uncertainty along the way. But it's worth it. Because at the end of the day, it's about connection. It's about finding people who care about you and who you can care about in return.

And honestly, I learned that sometimes, the most responsible thing you can do is admit you're not ready for something. Giving up the baby wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. It was the most loving thing I could do.

So yeah, love and responsibility. They're complicated. But they're also kinda beautiful. And I'm still figuring it all out, obviously. But I think I'm getting there.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don't expect a heartfelt monologue, alright?

Look, when you find out you're pregnant at sixteen, and your life is suddenly, like, a movie no one asked for, you kinda have two choices. You can fall apart and cry, or you can make fun of it. I chose the latter. Mostly because crying is exhausting.

The sarcasm, the snark, the just generally being a smartass…it was a defense mechanism, honestly. It was a way to keep people at arm's length, to deflect the seriousness of the situation. If I could make a joke about it, it didn't feel quite so scary.

It also helped me deal with the adults. Like, when they were trying to tell me what to do, or lecturing me about responsibility, I could just fire off a witty comeback and throw them off balance. It gave me a little bit of control, you know?

And it wasn't just about dealing with other people. It was about dealing with myself. It was a way to acknowledge the absurdity of it all, to find some humor in the chaos. Because if you can't laugh at yourself, what's the point?

Paulie Bleeker got it. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He just…laughed with me. And that was huge.

It wasn't always easy, though. Sometimes the humor felt…empty. Like I was using it to avoid dealing with my real feelings. But mostly, it helped me get through it. It helped me stay sane.

So yeah, my witty sense of humor wasn't just a personality quirk. It was a survival skill. It was a way to cope with a really messed-up situation and come out on the other side, mostly intact. And with a baby. Which is still kinda crazy when I think about it.



Don't get me wrong, I still had my moments of panic and sadness. But the humor…it was always there. A little bit of light in the darkness.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…deep? Fine. It's not like I haven't had time to think about it.

Look, I started out trying to be *so* cool. Like, super detached and sarcastic. A shield, basically. Because, honestly, I was terrified of being seen as…soft. Or emotional. Or anything that would make people think I was weak.

But then, bam. Pregnant. And suddenly, all that carefully constructed coolness just…crumbled. It was like, I couldn't hide behind sarcasm anymore. I had to actually *deal* with things. And that meant being vulnerable.

It was awful. Telling my dad, telling Paul…it was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it also…freed me, in a weird way. Because once I let people see the real me, the scared and confused me, they actually *helped*.

And that's when I realized I didn't have to have all the answers. I didn't have to be this perfectly self-assured person. It was okay to be messy and uncertain.

The whole search for a family for the baby…that forced me to confront a lot of stuff about what I wanted out of life. I thought I knew who I was, but I didn't. I was just…drifting.

Meeting Vanessa and Mark, they weren't what I expected. They weren't perfect. But they were real. And they made me think about what it means to be a parent, what it means to be a family.

I think, ultimately, my vulnerability allowed me to connect with people on a deeper level. It allowed me to ask for help. And it allowed me to figure out who I was, not who I *thought* I should be.

It wasn't a straight line, you know? There were a lot of awkward moments and missteps. But it was a journey. And it made me stronger. And, yeah, maybe a little less sarcastic. Okay, maybe not *less* sarcastic. But…more honest.

So, yeah. Vulnerability and searching for identity? They pretty much *were* my journey. It was messy, but it was mine. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even a lifetime supply of cheesy tater tots. Almost.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask about that. Like, the whole pregnancy thing was…a lot. And I definitely didn't do it alone, even though I tried to act like I was. It's kinda embarrassing to admit, but I needed people. A lot.

It wasn't like, a big, dramatic support group or anything. It was more…little things. Like, Paul. He was a total goofball, but he was *there*. He didn't judge me, he didn't try to tell me what to do, he just…listened. And he made me laugh, which was important, because I was doing a lot of crying.

And then there was my dad. He's…my dad. He's not exactly the most emotionally available person, but he tried. He made me pancakes, which was his way of showing he cared. And he didn't freak out, which I was expecting. He just kinda…accepted it.

And even my best friend, Leah, who was initially, like, completely horrified, eventually came around. She helped me pick out baby names and stuff. It was weird, but it was nice.

But honestly, the biggest support came from Vanessa and Mark, the couple I was giving the baby to. They were so…excited. And they treated me with so much respect. They didn't see me as just some kid who messed up, they saw me as someone who was making a really brave decision.

They asked for my opinion on everything, from the nursery decor to the baby's name. They wanted me to be involved, and that meant a lot. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

It wasn't about them "saving" me or anything. It was about them being…good people. And their kindness and support gave me the strength to go through with it.

I'm a pretty independent person, and I like to think I can handle things on my own. But I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And that sometimes, the people you least expect are the ones who will be there for you.

It definitely made the whole process a lot less scary. And it helped me feel confident in my decision. Because I knew I wasn't alone.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. It's not like a rom-com moment, you know? It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows and suddenly realizing I was meant to be a mom. It was… a lot.

Honestly? My first thought was, "Seriously?" Like, of all the things that could happen, *this* happened? I was sixteen. I had plans. Okay, not *detailed* plans, but plans. And those plans definitely didn't involve a baby.

Then it was just… panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. I was scared. I was confused. I was mostly just really, really annoyed. It felt like my life was suddenly someone else's story.

I didn't tell anyone for a long time. I just… processed it on my own. Which wasn't great, looking back. I was trying to be all cool and collected, but inside I was a total mess.

It wasn't until I started talking to Paul and my mom that things started to feel… less terrifying. They didn't freak out. They just… listened. And that made a huge difference.

It wasn't love at first sight, you know? It was more like… a slow realization that this little person was depending on me. And that I needed to figure things out, not just for myself, but for them too.

It was complicated. It *is* complicated. But it was also… kind of amazing. Even then, deep down, I knew it was going to change everything. And maybe, just maybe, that wasn't such a bad thing.

So yeah. That's how I felt. A mess. Scared. Annoyed. And eventually… hopeful. It was a lot to take in, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It definitely shook things up.

With my dad, it was…weird at first. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He wanted to fix everything, and you can't *fix* this. It took him a while to get his head around it. We ended up bonding over building the crib, which was surprisingly therapeutic. He's good with his hands, and I needed a distraction.

My mom was…intense. She went into full-on protective mom mode, immediately. She was all about prenatal vitamins and baby names and making sure I was okay. It was a little suffocating, honestly. But I knew she meant well. She just…processes things by *doing* things.

And then there was Leah. My best friend. That was the hardest part. She was…distant at first. I think she was scared. Scared for me, scared of what it meant for our friendship. We had plans, you know? College, moving away, just…life. And suddenly, everything was different. It took a lot of talking, a lot of awkward silences, and a lot of just…being there for each other. She eventually came around, and she was amazing during the whole adoption process. She's a good friend.

Paul…well, Paul was Paul. He was surprisingly chill about the whole thing. He was just…there. Supportive. A good listener. He didn't try to fix anything, he just let me be me. Which was…nice.

It definitely tested all my relationships. It forced me to be honest, to be vulnerable, and to figure out who really had my back. Some people stepped up, and some didn't. And that's okay. It just…changed things. It made me realize who my real friends and family are.

It wasn't easy, but it made me stronger. And it made me appreciate the people who stuck with me, even when things were messy and complicated. It's funny, you know? Something so scary and unexpected ended up showing me who I really am, and who I really want in my life.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while balancing a stack of textbooks and trying not to spill your Cherry Coke.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was a mess. I was angry, scared, confused… all the time. I mean, I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not… this.

A lot of it was just…talking. I leaned on my best friend, Leah, a *lot*. She was the only one who didn't treat me like I'd grown a second head. And Paul, surprisingly, was pretty good. He was awkward about it, sure, but he tried.

My dad was… well, my dad. He was quiet, but he listened. And he made me grilled cheese sandwiches, which, honestly, was his way of showing he cared.

But the biggest thing was probably just… accepting it. Accepting that this was happening, and that I had to deal with it. It didn't make it easy, but it made it… manageable.

I also started writing things down. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It helped to sort through the chaos in my head.

And honestly? A lot of it was just trying to be normal. Trying to go to school, hang out with my friends, and pretend like everything was okay. Which, of course, it wasn't. But it helped to have a little bit of normalcy in my life.

It was hard. Really hard. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that even when things are really, really messed up, there's still hope.

It wasn't about being happy all the time. It was about finding a way to keep going, even when I didn't want to. And that's something I think everyone can relate to, you know? Even if they haven't been through something like this.



It's still… complicated. But I'm okay. I really am.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about this? It was a whole thing, alright? A really complicated thing. But fine, I'll explain it, because people keep asking.

It wasn't about *choosing* one over the other, exactly. It was about…feeling safe. And feeling respected.

Havenbrooke was…intimidating. All those protesters outside, yelling. It felt like a battleground. And honestly, I didn't want a battle. I just wanted to make a decision and get it over with.

Women Now felt…different. It was calmer. More private. The people there were really nice, and they didn't judge me. They just…helped me. They explained everything clearly, and they made me feel like I was in control.

It wasn't about the facilities or anything like that. Both places were clean and professional. It was about the *vibe*. And Women Now just felt…right.

Plus, Mark was way more comfortable with me going to Women Now. He didn't want me to have to deal with all the drama at Havenbrooke. And honestly, his opinion mattered to me.

It wasn't an easy decision, okay? It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. And I wanted to feel as safe and supported as possible. Women Now just offered that.

It's my body, my choice, and I chose what felt best for me. And I don't regret it.



Can we please talk about something else now? This is bringing back a lot of…stuff.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a really direct question. And honestly? It's complicated. It's not like there was some big, dramatic reason. It just… happened.

It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or anything. It wasn't even, like, a super planned thing. We'd been hanging out for a while, Bleeker and I. He was… comfortable. He didn't try to be all intense or make a big deal out of things. He just *was*. And after everything with Paul and the baby, that was… nice.

I was a mess, okay? I was dealing with a lot. I was scared about giving the baby up, and I was confused about my feelings, and I was just… emotionally exhausted. And Bleeker was just… there. He didn't ask a lot of questions. He didn't try to fix anything. He just listened and made me laugh.

It felt… easy. And safe. And maybe a little bit like a distraction. I wasn't looking for anything serious. I just wanted to feel… normal, for a little while.

It wasn't about love, or even really about attraction. It was about connection. About wanting to feel close to someone without all the drama and expectations.

I don't regret it, exactly. It was a moment in time. But it wasn't some big, life-changing decision. It just… was. And honestly, talking about it now is kinda awkward. So can we maybe move on? There's a lot more to my story than just that one night.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're going *there*? It's been, like, years. But fine. You want the truth? Here it is.

It's…complicated. Bleeker was…a lot. He was sweet, okay? Really, really sweet. And he was always there. Like, consistently. Which is more than I can say for most people. He didn't judge me, even when I was being a total mess. He just…accepted me.

But he was also…kind of a space cadet. And a little bit boring. And he definitely wasn't the brooding, artistic type I thought I wanted. I mean, he was a drummer, which is cool, but he wasn't exactly writing poetry or anything.

I think I liked him because he was *safe*. He wasn't going to complicate things. He wasn't going to challenge me. And at the time, that's what I needed. I was already dealing with, like, a million things. I didn't need another drama bomb in my life.

But…it wasn't a *real* connection, you know? It was more like…comfortable companionship. And I realized, eventually, that I wanted something more. Something that made me feel…alive.

I still care about him. I really do. He's a good person. But we just weren't meant to be. It's one of those things.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It's embarrassing. And he's probably still a little bit in love with me. Which is…awkward.

So yeah. That's how I truly feel about Bleeker. A good guy, but not the one for me. Now can we talk about something else? Like, the existential dread of being a teenager? That's way less complicated.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do, honestly.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my…everything.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. A life I couldn't give it. I mean, my parents are…well, they're my parents. They're good people, but they're kinda spacey. And I didn't want my kid growing up with me scrambling to make ends meet and figure things out as I went along.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were stable. They were excited. They could give the baby everything I couldn't. A house with a yard, college funds, a loving, supportive family. 

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing the best parents for it. It was about putting the baby's needs first. 

It still hurts, you know? Sometimes I think about it and it feels like someone punched me in the gut. But I know I made the right decision. And I get to know the baby, to be a part of its life. That's important.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered. It still matters.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows story. It's messy and sad and real. And it's my story.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a moment. A really, really awkward moment.

Honestly? I was terrified. Bleeker is…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, and definitely not equipped to handle, like, *life* in general, let alone a baby. I was bracing for total freak-out mode. Like, full-on running-away-screaming freak-out.

I’d rehearsed what I was going to say a million times, but it all just came out jumbled and weird. I think I started with something about needing to talk, which was super subtle, right? And then I just kinda blurted it out.

His face…it was priceless. Like a deer in headlights. He just stared at me for a solid minute, and I was pretty sure he was trying to calculate the logistics of diaper changes.

Then he started rambling about how he wasn’t ready for responsibility and how his band was finally getting somewhere and…it was a lot. It wasn’t angry, just…overwhelmed.

It wasn’t what I expected. I thought he’d be mad, or disappointed, or something. But he was mostly just…scared. And honestly, seeing him so scared made *me* feel even more scared.

I didn’t want to ruin his life. I didn’t want to hold him back. But I also knew I couldn’t just pretend it wasn’t happening.

It was a really messy, uncomfortable conversation. And it definitely wasn’t a happy ending, at least not right away. But it was…necessary. It was the first step in figuring things out. And even though it was awful, I’m kinda glad I told him. Even Bleeker deserved to know.

It just…sucked. A lot.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. And honestly? It still feels kinda weird to even *think* about. Like, I'm barely an adult myself, you know? I'm still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being.

It's not what I planned, obviously. Not even close. I was thinking more along the lines of art school and maybe moving to New York. Not… diapers and sleepless nights.

But, like, it's happening. And I've had a lot of time to think about it. And it's not all scary. There's a part of me that's… excited, I guess. The idea of having someone who needs me, someone I can love… that's kinda cool.

But it's also terrifying. I'm worried about messing it up. About not being a good enough mom. About having to give up my own dreams.

And it's weird knowing that I'm giving this baby to another family. It's not like I'm abandoning it or anything. I just… I'm not ready. I don't have the resources, the stability, the life to give this baby what it deserves.

So, yeah. It's complicated. It's a mix of fear, excitement, sadness, and a whole lot of confusion. I'm trying to focus on doing what's best for the baby, even if it's not what's best for me.

It's just… a lot to process, you know? I'm still trying to figure it all out. And honestly, I don't think I ever will. But I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to be responsible. And I'm hoping that everything will be okay.



It's not exactly a fairytale, is it? But life rarely is.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…a lot to think about. Honestly? It's kinda terrifying. Before, it was just…easy. We hung out, we listened to music, he was a good listener, and he didn't, like, *judge* me. It was comfortable.

Now? Now there's a tiny human involved. And that changes everything.

I think…I think it's gonna get a lot more real. Before, we were just two kids figuring things out. Now we have to actually *be* adults, whether we want to or not. And Bleeker…he's a good guy, but he's not exactly known for his adulting skills.

I'm hoping he'll step up. I'm hoping he'll realize this isn't just about me anymore. It's about this baby. And he's gonna be a dad. That's a big deal.

I think we'll probably fight more. Because we're both gonna be stressed and scared and probably not handling things very well. And we're both gonna have different ideas about what's best for the baby.

But I also think…I think it could bring us closer. If we can actually communicate and work together. If we can both be willing to compromise and support each other.

I don't know. It's scary. I'm scared of messing things up, of ruining everything. But I also want Bleeker to be involved. I want him to be a good dad. And I want us to be a family, even if it's not the family I expected.

It's gonna be messy. It's gonna be complicated. But I guess that's life, right? And I'm just gonna have to deal with it. And hope Bleeker does too.

Ugh. I need a snack. This is stressful.

Ugh. Okay, so the judgment. Yeah, that was…a lot. Like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on my life, which is just *rude*. It felt like the whole school was staring at me, whispering. And it wasn't exactly supportive whispers, you know? More like, "Oh, look at Juno, she messed up."

Honestly? I mostly just pretended it wasn't happening. I doubled down on the sarcasm, the witty comebacks. It was a defense mechanism. If I could make them laugh, or at least make them uncomfortable, they wouldn't focus on the actual situation.

But it didn't always work. There were days I just wanted to disappear. I spent a lot of time at home, listening to music, trying to avoid people. Paulie Bleeker was a lifesaver, though. He didn't treat me like I was broken or stupid. He just…was there.

My dad was pretty good too, in his own weird way. He tried to be supportive, even if he didn't really understand. And my best friend, Leah…she was amazing. She didn't judge me, she just helped me figure things out.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that their opinions didn't matter. Like, yeah, they could talk, they could stare, they could judge. But it was *my* life. *My* decision. And I had to do what was right for me and the baby.

It was hard, though. Really hard. It took a lot of deep breaths, a lot of sarcastic remarks, and a lot of support from the people who actually cared about me. And honestly? It still stings sometimes. But I learned that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it.

And sometimes, the best reaction is just to roll your eyes and walk away. Seriously. It works wonders.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not like I can just sum it up in a soundbite, you know? It's messy. It's complicated. It's…everything.

Look, at first, it was just…practical. I was sixteen. I had a test to take, a life to live. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I still *am* not ready to be a mom. And that's okay.

But it quickly became way more than that. It wasn't just about what *I* wanted. It was about finding the best life for this kid. And that meant finding parents who were ready, who were excited, who could give this baby everything I couldn't.

Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good people. They're…normal. In a good way. They have a house with a yard and a minivan and they talk about college funds and soccer practice. It's a life I can't give this baby.

It doesn't make it easy, though. There are days when I just…feel weird. Like a part of me is missing. And I worry. I worry that I'm doing the wrong thing. I worry that the baby won't know how much I love it.

But then I remember why I made this choice. I remember that I want this baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life filled with love and opportunity. And I know that Mark and Vanessa can give it that.

It's not about giving up the baby. It's about giving the baby *to* someone. Someone who can give it everything it deserves.

It's still scary. It's still sad. But it's also…right. I think. I hope. It's the hardest thing I've ever done, and I'm still figuring it out. But I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to do what's best.

So, how do I feel about it? It's…a lot. It's a mix of everything. But mostly, I just hope I'm doing the right thing. And I hope this baby knows how much it was loved, even before it was born.

Ugh. Okay, so, the whole pregnancy thing? It was…a lot. Like, a whole *lot*. Before, I was just Juno. You know? A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who liked records and didn't really think about the future much beyond getting into a good college. I was pretty comfortable being…me. A little bit of a mess, maybe, but *my* mess.

Then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, "Juno" wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me, and what I was gonna do with that. It was like someone handed me a responsibility I hadn't asked for, and it completely flipped my world upside down.

It forced me to actually *think* about stuff. Like, what kind of person I wanted to be. What I believed in. What I was willing to sacrifice. Before, I could just coast, you know? Be a teenager. But suddenly, I had to make some serious decisions. And those decisions weren't just about me anymore.

It was weird, because I felt like I was supposed to be figuring out who I was, and instead I was figuring out how to give someone else a good start in life. It was like my own growing up got put on hold, but also…accelerated. I had to be more mature, more responsible, more thoughtful.

I had to learn how to talk to adults without being sarcastic all the time. I had to learn how to navigate complicated emotions. I had to learn how to let go. And honestly, that last one was the hardest.

It wasn't just about the physical stuff, either. It was about realizing that life isn't always what you plan. It throws you curveballs. And sometimes, those curveballs are really, really big.

I think it made me realize that being a grown-up isn't about knowing all the answers. It's about being willing to face the questions, even when they're scary. And it's about doing what you think is right, even when it's hard.

So yeah, it challenged my identity. It forced me to grow up. And honestly? It made me a better person. Even if it was the most unexpected, complicated, and terrifying thing that ever happened to me.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner? It's...complicated. I'm not exactly a "rah-rah, science is awesome!" kinda girl. But I'm not a total slacker either. 

I'd say I'm the…*realistic* one. Like, if Paulie Bleeker is all excited about dissecting a frog, I'm the one pointing out that it smells kinda gross and wondering if it had a good life. 

I'm good at the actual *doing* part of the experiment, you know? I can follow instructions, I'm pretty meticulous, and I don't freak out if something goes wrong. Which, let's be honest, it usually does.

But I'm not gonna pretend to understand all the science-y stuff. I'm more of a "let's just get it done and get a good grade" kinda person. And I definitely don't do the whole "enthusiastic participation" thing. I'm more of a quiet observer.

So, yeah. I'm the reliable, slightly sarcastic, and occasionally morbid lab partner. You want someone to actually *finish* the experiment? I'm your girl. Just don't expect me to be all excited about it. It's science. It's not a party.

Ugh. Seriously? That ad? Yeah, I saw it. It's…subtle, right? Like, they're trying to be all comforting and supportive, but it's still kinda creepy. All those smiling faces and talk about "empowerment." It feels…calculated.

Look, I'm not judging anyone who needs those services, okay? That's their business. And it's good there's a place that offers them. But the ad itself? It feels like they're trying to sell something, you know? Like, "Hey, unplanned pregnancy? No problem! We'll fix it!" It just…doesn't sit right with me.

It's not like they're being upfront about *all* the options, either. It's all very…positive. Like, adoption isn't a sad thing, it's a "loving choice." Which, okay, it *can* be. But it's also complicated and messy and heartbreaking. And they don't really show that part.

It just feels…weirdly sanitized. Like they're trying to make something really difficult and emotional seem easy and convenient. And that's just…not how it is.

I mean, I get it. They're trying to attract clients. But it feels a little manipulative, you know? Like they're preying on people who are already vulnerable.

Ugh. It just makes me feel…icky. I need a chocolate bar. And maybe some music. Something loud and angry. Yeah, that's what I need.

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on the hamburger phone? It's a long story. And honestly, it was mostly Paulie Bleeker's fault.

Okay, so, I needed to call someone. And my phone was…unavailable. Don't ask. It involved a misunderstanding and a very angry stepdad. Anyway, I was at this diner, right? And there it was. Just sitting there. A bright red, perfectly formed hamburger…that happened to be a phone.

It was just…so perfectly ridiculous. And I was feeling particularly ridiculous at the time. Everything was kinda falling apart, and I just needed to do something completely absurd. It felt like a statement. Like, "Yeah, my life is a mess, but at least I have a hamburger phone."

Plus, Paulie thought it was hilarious. And honestly, seeing him laugh was worth the weird looks I got from everyone else in the diner. He's a dork, but he's *my* dork.

It wasn't about the phone call itself, it was about the moment. It was about embracing the chaos and finding humor in the absurdity of it all. It was about being me.

Don't judge. It was a weird time. And it made for a good story, right?

Ugh. Okay. That's…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was way more complicated than that.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my band practice, everything.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him. Not then. Not ever, probably.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were stable. They were excited. They could give him everything I couldn't. A house with a yard, college funds, two parents who were actually prepared for the responsibility.

It was selfish, maybe. But it was also the most unselfish thing I could do. I wanted him to be wanted, to be loved, to have a good life. And I knew that with me, he wouldn't have that.

It was hard. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I don't regret it. I really don't. Because I know he's happy. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't about giving him *up*. It was about giving him *to* someone who could give him everything he deserved. And that's a big difference.



It's…a lot to explain. It's not a simple story. But that's the gist of it. It was about doing what was best for him, even if it meant breaking my own heart.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like my family was, like, *bad*. They were just…them. And “them” is a lot.

My dad, he's a sweet guy, but kinda checked out. Always building model airplanes, avoiding eye contact. And my stepmom, Bren, she tries really hard, but she's…intense. Everything has to be perfect. Like, perfectly decorated, perfectly planned, perfectly *everything*. It was always a little suffocating.

Growing up, it felt like they had this very specific idea of what my life should be. Good grades, college, a sensible career. And a baby? That just didn't fit into that picture. Not at all.

I knew, even before I really *knew* what I was going to do, that I couldn't raise a kid in that environment. Not with Bren constantly critiquing my parenting or my dad disappearing into his workshop. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

It wasn't that they wouldn't have *helped*. They would have. But it wouldn't have been the kind of help I needed. It would have been the kind of help that came with a lot of expectations and judgment.

And honestly, I didn't want to become my mom. She had kids young, and she always seemed…resentful. Like she missed out on things. I didn't want that for myself, or for the baby.

So, yeah, my family definitely influenced my decision. Not in a way that pushed me towards adoption, but in a way that made me realize I needed to create a different kind of life for myself, and for the baby. A life where I could be a good mom, without feeling like I was living up to someone else's expectations.

It was a hard decision, but it was the right one. For everyone. Even if it meant disappointing them a little. Or a lot. It was my life, and my baby's life. And I needed to make the best choice for both of us.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like on TV where everything's all heartwarming and perfect. It was…complicated. And a little stressful. And involved a lot of paperwork. Seriously, *so* much paperwork.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…feeling like I wasn't good enough. Like, I was this teenager, barely able to take care of myself, and I was supposed to be making this huge decision about a baby's life. It was terrifying. I kept second-guessing myself, wondering if I was doing the right thing.

Then there was the whole meeting the potential adoptive parents thing. That was…weird. It felt like I was being interviewed, like I was a product on display. And I wanted them to be good people, obviously, but I also wanted them to *get* it. To understand that I wasn't just giving up a baby, I was making a really hard choice because I wanted that baby to have a good life.

And there was Mark. He was…well, Mark. He was supportive, but he didn't really *get* it either. He kept trying to fix things, to make it all better, and I just needed him to listen. It was frustrating.

And then there was the legal stuff. All the forms, the meetings with the social worker, the court dates…it was exhausting. And it felt so impersonal, like my feelings didn't matter.

But the hardest part, I think, was just knowing that I wouldn't be there to see the baby grow up. That I wouldn't be there for the first steps, the first words, the first day of school. That was…really hard.

It wasn't easy, but I knew it was the right thing to do. And I was lucky to find Vanessa and Mark. They were amazing. They were exactly the kind of people I wanted to raise my baby. And that made all the challenges worth it.

It was just…a lot. A lot of feelings, a lot of paperwork, and a lot of trying to be brave when I didn't feel brave at all.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It's not exactly something I like to dwell on, you know? But yeah, it changed everything. Like, completely rearranged the furniture in my brain.

Before Paul, before everything, I was just…Juno. Kinda sarcastic, kinda detached, just floating through life. I had my friends, my music, my general disdain for most people. I didn't really think about the future, or what I wanted out of life. I just kinda *was*.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything was different. It wasn't just about me anymore. There was this little person growing inside me, and that was…terrifying. And amazing. And complicated.

Having to actually *think* about being a mom, about providing for someone, about making big decisions…it forced me to grow up, way faster than I was ready for. I had to face some really hard truths about myself, about what I wanted, and what I was capable of.

Giving up Seven…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like ripping a piece of my heart out. But it also showed me what I was made of. It showed me that I could be selfless, that I could put someone else's needs before my own.

It made me realize I wasn't as cynical as I thought I was. I actually *cared* a lot. And I wanted Seven to have the best life possible, even if that life wasn't with me.

It also made me figure out what I *didn't* want. I didn't want to be a mom right then. I wasn't ready. And that's okay. It doesn't make me a bad person.

I think, ultimately, it helped me find my voice. I learned to stand up for what I believe in, to make my own choices, and to not let anyone tell me what to do. It made me more confident, more independent, and more…me.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and painful and confusing. But it was also a really important part of my journey. It shaped who I am today. And I wouldn't trade it, even though it hurt like hell.

It taught me that life is unpredictable, and that sometimes the best thing you can do is just…let go. And trust that things will work out, even if they don't work out the way you planned.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. That *guy*. It was…the worst. It wasn't the yelling, honestly. I've dealt with yelling before. It was the…the *details*. Like he was trying to make it real, you know? Like the baby was already a fully formed person with feelings and opinions.

It just…stuck in my throat. I mean, I knew it was a baby. I wasn't stupid. But it wasn't a *person* yet. Not in the way he was trying to make it sound. It was…potential. And it was my potential, and my decision.

And the fingers? Seriously? What was that even supposed to mean? Like, it was already reaching for a sippy cup or something? It was just…cruel. He was trying to make me feel guilty. And it almost worked.

I just wanted to scream. I wanted to tell him to mind his own business and that this wasn't about him. But I couldn't. I just stood there, feeling small and stupid and…really, really sad.

It made me question everything, even though I knew I was doing the right thing. It made me feel like I was a bad person. And that was the worst part.

I just wanted him to go away. I wanted the whole thing to be over. I wanted to be left alone to figure things out.

It was…a really bad day. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. It's not something you just forget.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was mostly just…awkward. And cold. The chairs were really uncomfortable.

Honestly, the paperwork felt so…clinical. Like I was filling out a form for a dentist appointment, not making a decision about, you know, a whole *person*. It was all boxes to check and questions about my medical history and stuff. Like they were trying to reduce it to data.

I think I was mostly trying to look like I had my life together. Like I wasn't a total mess. I kept smoothing my jeans and trying to make eye contact with the woman at the desk, but not *too* much eye contact. You know?

There was this weird mix of relief and terror. Relief that I was actually doing something, taking control of the situation. And terror that I was actually doing it. That it was real. That this wasn't just some bad dream.

I remember feeling really, really small. Like I was just a tiny speck in a huge, complicated system. And I was trying to be brave, but inside I was just…scared. Scared of what everyone would think, scared of what the future held, scared of messing everything up.

I kept thinking about the baby, even though I hadn't even met it yet. And I felt guilty. A lot of guilt. But I also knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

It was just…a really heavy feeling. Like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. And I was trying to fill out the paperwork with a steady hand, even though my whole body was shaking inside.

It wasn't a moment I'm gonna forget anytime soon, that's for sure. It was just…real. And really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay, so, pregnancy. Right. It started as…a really big problem. Like, a life-altering, everything-is-different kind of problem. Honestly, at first, it was just this huge inconvenience. I was sixteen, I had plans, and suddenly I was staring down the barrel of…well, a baby. It felt like my life was over before it even started.

My initial perception was all about what I *couldn't* do. I couldn't go to college right away, I couldn't just hang out with my friends, I couldn't be a normal teenager. It was all about loss, you know? Loss of freedom, loss of control. And I was super angry about it.

But then, as things progressed, and I started feeling…well, *something*…it started to shift. It wasn't like a light switch, it was more like a slow burn. I started thinking about the baby as a person, not just a problem. I started imagining what it would be like to hold it, to raise it.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt the baby, was a huge turning point. They were…good people. Really good people. And seeing how excited they were, how much they wanted a child, made me realize that this wasn't just about me. It was about giving this baby the best possible life.

My perception of motherhood changed too. I used to think it was all about sacrificing everything, about losing yourself. But talking to Vanessa, seeing how she and Mark planned to balance parenthood with their own lives, made me realize that it could be something…fulfilling. Something empowering.

By the end, it wasn't about what I was giving up, it was about what I was *giving*. I was giving a baby a loving home, a stable family, a future. And that felt…good. Really good.

It was still scary, don't get me wrong. It was still a huge decision. But it went from being a terrifying problem to being a difficult, but ultimately hopeful, choice. It taught me a lot about myself, about responsibility, and about what it means to be a grown-up. And honestly? It made me a little less cynical. A little.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all deep and introspective? Fine. It's not like I haven't had enough of that already.

Honestly, at the beginning of the movie, I didn't really *have* a strong sense of identity. I was just…Juno. Sarcastic, a little bit cynical, good at writing, and kinda drifting. I used humor as a shield, you know? To keep people at arm's length and avoid dealing with anything real. I was good at observing people, but not so good at figuring out who *I* was.

The pregnancy…that threw everything into chaos. It forced me to grow up, like, way faster than I was ready for. It wasn't just about the baby, it was about facing responsibility and making a really big decision. And that decision – giving the baby up – was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

But through the process of finding Mark and Vanessa, and getting to know them, I started to understand what I wanted out of life. I realized I didn't want to be defined by the pregnancy, or by anyone else's expectations. I wanted to be me.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, and how much they wanted a child, helped me realize that giving the baby up wasn't a failure. It was a selfless act. And it allowed me to focus on my own future.

And then there was Paulie Bleeker. He was always there, you know? A constant. And realizing that I actually *liked* him, and that he liked me back, helped me see that I was capable of real connection and vulnerability.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same person I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic and a little bit cynical, but I was also more confident, more self-aware, and more willing to let people in. I started to understand that my identity wasn't something fixed, it was something I was constantly creating.

It wasn't about finding myself, it was about *making* myself. And that was a pretty powerful realization. It was messy and complicated, but it was also…good.



It's weird talking about myself like this. I usually just make fun of everything. But yeah, that's pretty much how it went down.

Ugh. Okay, so everyone always wants to know about *that* day. It's…complicated. It wasn't like I suddenly had a change of heart, you know? It wasn't some big, dramatic realization. It was more…a bunch of little things adding up.

I mean, I'd been pretty sure about it for a while. It felt like the right thing to do. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa. They were, like, *good* people. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't.

But then I got to the clinic, and it just…felt wrong. It wasn't the clinic itself, it was…everything. Seeing the protestors outside, all the judgment. And then talking to the nurse, she was nice, but it just felt so…clinical. Like I was just a case, a problem to be solved.

And then I started thinking about the baby. Not like, *my* baby, but just…a little person. And I realized I wasn't ready to say goodbye. Not yet. I needed a little more time to process everything.

It wasn't about wanting to keep the baby, it was about needing to be sure. And I wasn't sure. Not in that moment.

So I just…left. I walked out. It was kinda anticlimactic, honestly. I just kept walking until I found a diner and ordered a grilled cheese. It didn't solve anything, but it felt…better.

It was a messy, confusing time. And it took a lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa to figure things out. But ultimately, it was the right decision. For everyone. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice. It was about being pro-*me*. And pro-baby. And trying to do what felt right, even when it was really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. And it's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, definitely giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was barely keeping my grades up, and my life was… chaotic, to say the least.

I loved the idea of having a baby, don't get me wrong. But I knew I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable, I didn't have a stable home life, and I definitely wasn't emotionally prepared. It wouldn't be fair to the baby to bring it into that.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby having a good life. A life with parents who were ready and able to provide everything it needed. A life with stability and opportunity.

Paul and Vanessa… they were just… perfect. They were already planning a family, and they were so excited about the idea of adopting. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make, and it still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about *not* wanting the baby, it was about wanting the best for the baby. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't glamorous. It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it was my decision, and I stand by it. It was the most selfless thing I've ever done, even if it didn't always feel that way.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That was a low point. Okay, look, it wasn't the *idea* of finding parents that was tacky, it was the *method*. Like, my dad and I were desperate, okay? But the Penny Saver? It's for garage sales and lost dogs, not…finding a family for your baby.

It felt…cheap. And impersonal. Like I was a toaster oven someone was trying to get rid of. I wanted someone who actually *wanted* me, not someone who was just scanning classifieds for a bargain.

Plus, it just felt…sad. Like, "Here's a baby, anyone?" It lacked any dignity. I wanted someone who would appreciate me, who would be excited to be a parent. Not someone who was just filling a void or looking for a project.

My dad thought it was practical, which is classic Dad. But I needed something more than practical. I needed someone who would love me, even though I wasn't going to raise me.

It was just…a really depressing thought. And the Penny Saver just amplified that. It felt like admitting defeat, like saying I wasn't worth anything more than a small ad in a discount newspaper.

So yeah, tacky. Definitely tacky. Don't even get me started on the pictures. That was a whole other level of awkward.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's a long story, honestly. And kinda embarrassing. But fine, I'll tell you.

It wasn't, like, a planned thing. It just…happened. See, I was at Leah's house, and we were bored. Like, *really* bored. We'd already watched all the good movies, eaten all the snacks, and made fun of all her dad's weird hobbies. 

And then Leah's dad brought in a stack of Penny Savers. You know, those free papers full of ads for everything from furniture to lawn care to…well, everything. And there was this one ad, tucked away in the back, for a couple looking to adopt.

It wasn't even about *wanting* a baby, at first. It was just…weird. Like, "Wow, people actually *advertise* that they want to adopt?" It was a totally different world than anything we'd ever thought about.

So we started looking at the ads, just for kicks. Reading about the couples, what they were looking for in a kid. It was kinda sad, actually. And kinda fascinating. 

And then…well, then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, those ads weren't so weird anymore. They were…options. And it was the first time I started thinking seriously about what I was gonna do.

It was a really confusing time. And the Penny Saver, of all things, was the thing that started it all. It's kinda ironic, you know? Finding out about a whole new life in a pile of junk mail.

So yeah, that's why we started looking at the adoption ads. Boredom, curiosity, and then…everything changed.

Ugh, okay, this is…a big deal. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It's my kid. So, yeah, I have thoughts.

I'm not looking for "perfect," because perfect doesn't exist. I just want…good. Really good.

I want a family who's gonna love this kid fiercely. Like, unconditionally. Doesn't matter if they're two moms, a dad and a stepmom, a single parent, whatever. As long as there's love, that's the main thing.

They gotta be stable. Not necessarily rich, but stable. A safe home, food on the table, that kind of stuff. And they need to be able to handle a kid. It's not always sunshine and rainbows, you know? There's gonna be tantrums and scraped knees and teenage angst.

I want them to be open-minded. This kid is gonna be…unique. And I want them to embrace that. I don't want them trying to mold this kid into something they're not.

And honestly? I want a family who's gonna let me be a part of this kid's life. Not like, a constant presence, because that would be weird. But I want to get updates, see pictures, maybe even visit sometimes. I just want to know that my kid is okay.

I'm not looking for a replacement family. I'm looking for a *family* for my kid. A family who's gonna give them a good life, a happy life, and a whole lot of love.

Is that too much to ask? Probably. But hey, a girl can dream, right? It's my kid, and I want the best for them. Even if the best isn't with me.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot.

Look, I'm not one to judge, okay? Everyone's got their own stuff going on. But those two? They're like, aggressively wholesome. It's kinda terrifying. They're always talking about their organic garden and their commitment to conscious parenting. It's exhausting just *listening* to them.

And Vanessa? She's sweet, I guess. But she's also…intense. She's got a whole system for everything. Color-coded schedules, homemade granola, essential oil diffusers in every room. It's a little much.

Mark's…well, Mark's Mark. He's a good guy, I think. A little clueless, maybe. He just wants everyone to be happy. Which is nice, but also kinda naive. He's easily swayed by Vanessa's…enthusiasm.

They mean well, I know they do. And they were really supportive when I…you know. But sometimes I just need a break from all the positivity. It's like, can we just have a normal conversation without talking about the benefits of kale?

They're good people, I guess. Just…a little too perfect. It makes me feel like I'm failing at life just by existing. And honestly, sometimes I just want to eat a bag of chips and watch a trashy movie without getting a lecture about the importance of mindful snacking.

Don't tell them I said that. Seriously. They'd probably make me drink a green smoothie.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was mortifying, even for me. But fine, I'll tell you. It was...complicated.

I wrote: "**Bleeker, you're a genuinely good egg. Don't let anyone tell you different. And seriously, get a haircut.**"

Yeah, I know. It's a mess. It's sweet, but also kinda sarcastic. It's me in a nutshell. I wanted to tell him how I really felt, but I couldn't just *say* it. I had to throw in the haircut comment to keep things awkward and deflect. 

It was the best I could do at the time. I was a mess of feelings, and I didn't want to be all mushy and vulnerable. Plus, he *really* needed a haircut. It was distracting.

Honestly, I still cringe when I think about it. But he seemed to like it, which is all that matters, I guess. He kept the yearbook, so...progress?

Don't judge me too harshly. I was a teenager. We're all awkward and weird. And sometimes, the best way to show someone you care is to make fun of their hair. It's a delicate balance.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Bleeker. Right. Let's just say it's…complicated.

At first, she was *not* a fan. Not at all. I think she saw me as this… chaotic force of nature who was going to corrupt her sweet, sensitive Bleeker. She definitely had a whole "good girl" image in mind for him, and I was… decidedly not that. Lots of side-eye, passive-aggressive comments about my music choices, and pointed questions about my future plans. You know, the whole nine yards.

She was worried about the baby, obviously. And I get that. It wasn't exactly the situation she envisioned for her son. But she mostly seemed worried about what people would *think*. Like, her social standing or something. It was kinda frustrating.

Things got…slightly better after she met Paul and Annie. They're good people. Really good people. And they were able to explain things to her, to show her that I wasn't just some irresponsible teenager. They helped her see that I actually *wanted* what was best for the baby.

She still doesn't totally get me, I don't think. She still tries to offer me advice about things I don't ask for. And she still looks at me like I'm a bit of a wild card. But she's…accepting now. Tolerant, maybe.

She even knitted a little hat for the baby. Which was…surprisingly sweet.

So, yeah. It's not a warm, fuzzy mother-daughter relationship, by any means. But it's not hostile anymore. And honestly, that's good enough for me. I don't need her to love me. I just need her to not actively dislike me. And right now, I think we're at that point.

It's a work in progress, okay? Don't expect us to be baking cookies together anytime soon.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially explosive cloud. I've been practicing what I'm gonna say in the mirror, but it just comes out sounding all robotic and fake. Like, "Mom, Dad, I am currently gestating a human being." Yeah, no. That's not gonna fly.

Honestly, I'm mostly just terrified. My dad's gonna be…disappointed. He's got this whole plan for my life, and a baby definitely wasn't in it. And my mom… she'll be worried. She always worries. She'll want to know all the details, and I don't even have all the details *myself* yet.

It's not that they're bad people, okay? They're just… my parents. And they have expectations. And I'm pretty sure this is gonna shatter all of them.

I keep thinking about how to make it easier, but there's no easy way to tell your parents you're pregnant at sixteen. It's just… bad.

Paul's been really supportive, which is good. He's offered to be there when I tell them, but honestly, I think I need to do this on my own. It's my news, my responsibility.

I just… I want them to understand. I want them to see that I'm not just some irresponsible kid. I'm trying to do the right thing. And I'm gonna be a good mom. Even if I have no idea what I'm doing.

So yeah. I'm feeling… a lot of things. Mostly scared. And a little bit nauseous. And definitely wishing I could just disappear for a while. But I can't. I gotta face the music. And hopefully, they won't completely freak out.

Wish me luck. I'm gonna need it.

Ugh. Okay, so you wanna know why I don't exactly run to my parents when things get…complicated? It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just…them.

It's kinda hard to explain. They're both super into their own stuff. My dad's all about his remodeling projects and my mom's a holistic healer. Which is cool, I guess. But they're not exactly tuned into what's going on with *me*. They're more like…observational parents. They notice things, but they don't really *ask* about things.

And they have these…expectations. Like, I'm supposed to be this quirky, independent kid who has everything figured out. Which is a lot of pressure, honestly. If I went to them with something like…being pregnant…I think they'd just be really confused. And probably disappointed.

They're not judgmental, exactly. They're just…not equipped to deal with this. They'd try to fix it, I think. With essential oils and positive affirmations. And that's not what I need.

I need someone to just…listen. And understand. And not try to make everything okay. Because it's not okay. It's messy and complicated and scary.

So, yeah. That's why I'm hesitant. It's not that I don't love them. It's just that I don't think they'd get it. And I don't want to burden them with something they're not prepared to handle.

It's easier to just figure it out on my own. Even if it's really hard. It's just…easier. Does that make sense? It probably doesn't. It's hard to explain.

Ugh, okay, this is…it’s a big thing to talk about, obviously. But people keep asking, so I guess I gotta explain it again. It’s not like I haven’t thought about it, like, a million times.

Look, I’m sixteen. *Sixteen*. I’m still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I mean, I can barely keep a plant alive. A baby? That’s…a whole other level of responsibility.

And it’s not that I don’t care. I do. A lot. That’s why this is so hard. But I want this baby to have everything. A stable home, two parents who are actually ready for it, a good education, opportunities… things I can’t really offer right now.

My parents are great, but they’re…my parents. They’re already kinda overwhelmed with their own stuff. And I don’t want to be a burden. I don’t want to ruin their lives, or my life, or the baby’s life.

I’ve been talking to Vanessa and Mark, the couple who want to adopt him. They’re…amazing. They’ve been trying for years, and they’re so excited. They’ve already started decorating the nursery. They’re gonna be really good parents.

And honestly, it feels…right. Like, this baby deserves a family who is fully prepared and ready to give him everything he needs. And I can give him that, by choosing adoption. It’s not giving up on him, it’s giving him the best possible start.

It’s not easy. It’s probably the hardest thing I’ve ever had to do. But I think it’s the right thing. For everyone. And I gotta believe that. Otherwise, I’ll just fall apart.

It’s not about what *I* want. It’s about what’s best for *him*. And right now, that’s a life with Vanessa and Mark. And that’s okay. It has to be.

Ugh, okay, this is…a big deal. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person*. My kid. So, the qualities I'm looking for in adoptive parents? It's a long list, honestly.

First off, they gotta be…stable. Like, really stable. Not financially rich, necessarily, but able to provide a good, secure home. No crazy drama, no constantly moving, no…questionable life choices. I need someone who can offer consistency.

They have to be open-minded. Seriously. This kid is gonna be…unique. And I want them to embrace that. No judging, no trying to mold them into something they're not. Just…acceptance.

Humor is a big one. Life is hard, and you gotta be able to laugh. I want my kid to grow up in a home where they can be silly and not feel like they have to be perfect all the time.

Patience. Lots and lots of patience. Kids are…a lot. And this kid will probably be extra.

And they have to be genuinely excited about becoming parents. Not just doing it because they can't have kids of their own. I want someone who *wants* this kid, who will love them unconditionally.

I also want them to be okay with me being…around. I don't want to be a complete stranger. I want to be able to have some kind of relationship, if that's what everyone wants. It's complicated, I know.

Basically, I'm looking for people who are kind, compassionate, and willing to give this kid a good life. People who will love them for who they are, and help them become the best version of themselves. It's a lot to ask, I know. But my kid deserves the best. And I'm gonna make sure they get it.

It's not about finding perfect people. It's about finding people who are willing to try. And who are willing to love. That's all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about the practical stuff – the hospital, the paperwork, finding a good family. But nobody really wants to talk about the *feeling* part. Which is, like, the whole point, isn't it?

Honestly? I don't have a plan. Not a neat, organized, color-coded plan like Paul would probably make. I'm just…trying to brace myself.

I think a lot of it is gonna be about letting myself *feel* things. Which is hard for me, because I usually just try to be sarcastic and deflect. But I know I'm gonna be sad. Really sad. And probably angry. And confused. And maybe even a little bit relieved. It's gonna be a mess of emotions, and I need to let them happen.

I'm talking to a therapist, which is…surprisingly helpful. She doesn't judge me for wanting to do this, and she doesn't try to tell me what to feel. She just listens. And that's good enough.

I'm also leaning on my friends and family. They're being really supportive, even if they don't totally get it. And I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm doing this because I want what's best for the baby. That's gotta be the most important thing, right?

I'm also gonna keep writing. It helps me process things. And maybe I'll make a playlist. A really long, angsty playlist.

I know it's not gonna be easy. I know there are gonna be days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. But I'm trying to remind myself that this isn't a failure. It's a brave decision. And it's a selfless one.

And I'm hoping that, eventually, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I did the right thing. Even if it hurts like hell right now.

It's just…a lot. Okay? It's a lot to process. And I'm just taking it one day at a time. And trying not to think about it too much. Which is probably not the healthiest strategy, but it's what I'm doing right now.



Don't expect me to have all the answers. I'm just figuring this out as I go.

Ugh, okay, you noticed that, huh? It's a thing. It's just…weird. Like, people keep saying I'm "delivering" a baby. Like I'm the UPS guy or something. "Special delivery!" Seriously?

It's not a package! It's a person! A tiny human being that I'm, like, *growing* inside me. It's not something you just…drop off. 

And it makes it sound so impersonal. Like I'm just a vessel. Like I don't have any feelings about it. Which is totally not true. It's complicated, okay? I'm giving a baby a life, and then I'm choosing to let someone else raise it. It's not a "delivery." It's a…a really big decision.

My dad pointed it out too, actually. He said it's a weirdly clinical term for something so emotional. He's surprisingly insightful sometimes.

So yeah, I just don't like the word "deliver." It feels…wrong. I'm not delivering anything. I'm…making a choice. And it's a really hard choice. And people need to stop talking about it like it's a pizza.

Ugh, okay, seriously? That was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. But…look, it’s complicated.

It wasn’t like I *agreed* exactly. It was more like he just…showed up. My dad, Bren, he means well. He really does. He’s just…enthusiastic. And clueless. And he has this way of making everything awkward.

I thought I could handle it. I thought, “Okay, he’ll just sit there and be quiet, and it won’t be a big deal.” Famous last words, right? I figured it would be better than him completely freaking out at home while I was gone. He gets weirdly clingy when he’s worried.

I also kinda felt bad for him. He was trying to be supportive, in his own Bren-way. He was trying to be a dad. And I guess I wanted him to be involved, just…not *that* involved.

But then he started asking all these weird questions about the potential parents. Like, “Do they have a good vacuum cleaner?” And “Are they the kind of people who would make me a grandfather?” It was mortifying.

Honestly, I just wanted to disappear. It was a total train wreck. But, you know, it also kinda showed me how much he cared. Even if he expresses it in the most embarrassing way possible.

So yeah, I didn’t exactly *agree* to it. I just…let it happen. And I regretted it immediately. It was a learning experience, though. I learned that sometimes, even with the best intentions, your dad is just going to make things worse. And that’s okay. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's like, everyone else has it all figured out, right? They're cheerleaders or band geeks or future lawyers or whatever. And me? I'm just…Juno. I like records and avoiding people and making sarcastic comments. 

It's not that I *want* to be labeled, you know? I don't need a box. But it's kinda unsettling not knowing what I'm supposed to *be*. Like, what's my thing? What am I good at? What am I gonna do with my life?

It's not like I haven't tried stuff. I was in drama club for, like, a week. That was a disaster. And I tried out for the school newspaper, but I mostly just wrote snarky captions for the photos. 

I guess I'm just…still figuring it out. And that's okay, right? It's okay to not have a plan. It's okay to be a little bit lost. 

But it's also kinda scary. Like, what if I never figure it out? What if I just end up drifting through life, being sarcastic and listening to The Moldy Peaches?

I mean, that doesn't sound *terrible*, but…I don't know. I want to be something more than just…me. I want to make a difference. I want to do something important.

But right now, I'm just a girl who's pregnant and trying to find a good home for her baby. And that's enough for now. I guess.

It's just…it's weird. Not knowing. It's like being a blank page. And I'm not sure what to write on it yet.

Ugh. Seriously? Brenda. Always Brenda. Like she's some kind of relationship guru or something.

Okay, so, when she suggested me and Leah go "upstairs" – which, let's be real, was code for "get out of the way so your dad can have a man-to-man talk with Mark" – I think my eyes just rolled so far back in my head I almost saw my brain. 

I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, good idea, Brenda. Let's just leave all the important adult stuff to the adults. We wouldn't want to contaminate it with our teenage angst." Or maybe I just gave her *the look*. You know, the one that says, "I'm judging you silently and with extreme prejudice."

It wasn't about wanting to be involved in the drama, okay? It was about the principle of the thing. Like, we weren't kids. We were capable of handling a little awkwardness. And Brenda always treated us like we were fragile little flowers that needed to be shielded from the harsh realities of life.

Plus, Leah and I were having a perfectly good conversation. We didn't need to be exiled to the upstairs bedroom like we'd committed some kind of social faux pas.

Honestly, it just made the whole situation even more uncomfortable. It felt like Brenda was trying to control everything, and it just…didn't work. It never does.

So yeah, not a fan. Definitely not a fan. It was a classic Brenda move, though. Predictably annoying.

Ugh, okay, that's…a lot to unpack. An open adoption. It's not something I really thought about at first, you know? It felt kinda…complicated. Like, more emotional than I was prepared for.

At first, I was leaning towards just…clean break. Like, let the baby have a new life, a new family, and let me move on. It felt easier. Less messy. Less chance of getting all weird and attached and regretting things.

But then I started talking to Mark and Vanessa, the couple, and they were really open about wanting to share updates. Photos, letters, maybe even visits down the line. And it made me think.

It's not about wanting to be a *parent*, exactly. It's about…wanting to know the kid is okay. Wanting to see them happy. Wanting to know they're growing up in a good home. It's selfish, I guess. But it's also…natural.

It's scary, though. Like, what if they're not happy? What if they don't like the photos I send? What if it just makes everything harder?

But I think…I think it could be good. For everyone. For the baby to know where they came from. For me to know they're okay. For Mark and Vanessa to have a connection to my side of the family.

It's not gonna be easy. It's gonna be weird and awkward and probably a little bit heartbreaking at times. But I think…I think it's worth a try. It's a way to make sure this isn't just…a closed chapter. It's a way to keep a little piece of this baby in my life, even if I'm not the one raising them.

So yeah. I'm cautiously optimistic. It's terrifying, but…maybe it's the right thing to do. It's definitely something I need to think about a lot more. And probably talk to Paul about. He's good at talking things through.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…not good. It was like someone just punched me in the stomach, you know? I mean, I *knew* it was an open adoption, and I knew I wasn't keeping the baby, but hearing her actually *say* that my legal rights would be terminated…it just made it so real.

It wasn't about wanting to keep him, exactly. It was about…control, I guess. Like, I was already giving up so much, and to have even that little bit of legal connection just…gone? It felt like I was disappearing, too. Like I wasn't even a part of the equation anymore.

I tried to play it cool, obviously. Sarcasm is my defense mechanism, remember? But inside, I was totally freaking out. It felt like everyone was making decisions *for* me, about my body, about my baby, about my future. And I just wanted to have some say in it.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I just…a vessel?

It was a really scary moment. And it made me realize how complicated everything was. It wasn't just about finding a good home for the baby. It was about navigating a whole mess of legal and emotional stuff.

I think that's when I really started to understand the weight of what I was doing. It wasn't just a decision, it was a life-altering event. And it was going to be hard, no matter what.

So yeah, that moment with Gerta? Not a highlight. Definitely a lowlight. It just…stuck with me.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. That's…a lot. Honestly? It's kinda intense. Like, she's got this whole plan mapped out, right? The perfect nursery, the organic everything, the Montessori school… it's a *lot* of pressure. And for a baby that doesn't even exist yet.

Look, I get wanting a kid. I really do. It's just…she's making it seem like it's the only thing that'll make her life complete. And that's messed up. Like, your life should be okay *without* a baby, you know? A baby shouldn't be a fix for something else.

It's also kinda weird how obsessed she is with finding the "perfect" parents. Like, there *is* no perfect. People are flawed. And that's okay. It's the flawed people who make things interesting.

I mean, Mark and Vanessa are good people. They'll be good parents. But she's putting so much pressure on it, on them, on the baby… it makes me nervous. It feels like she's not seeing the whole picture. It's not all sunshine and rainbows and adorable baby clothes. It's hard work. It's messy. It's exhausting.

I just hope she's ready for all of it. And I hope she remembers that a baby is a person, not a project.

It's not my place to judge, I guess. But it's definitely…a lot to process. And it makes me even more sure that I did the right thing. For me, and for the baby. It's just…she's got a lot of expectations. And that scares me a little.

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark and the whole dad thing? Honestly? It's…complicated.

He's trying, I'll give him that. He's not exactly overflowing with emotional intelligence, but he's *trying* to be a good guy. And that response…it's classic Mark. All awkward and rambling and trying to be funny to cover up the fact that he's totally freaked out.

He's not ready, okay? He's a skater dude who still lives with his mom. He's not exactly equipped to change diapers and sing lullabies. But he's willing to step up, which is more than some guys would do.

It's just…he doesn't really *get* it, you know? He's thinking about the practical stuff – the money, the responsibility – but he's not really thinking about the emotional side of things. He's not thinking about what it means to actually *be* a dad.

And that's okay, I guess. He'll learn. He has to. But it's gonna be a bumpy ride. He needs someone to keep him grounded, to remind him that this isn't just about him anymore.

It's kinda sweet, in a pathetic way. He's so clueless, but he's trying so hard. It's…endearing. But also terrifying. Because this kid is gonna need a lot of support, and Mark is…well, Mark.

So yeah, his response is exactly what I'd expect from Mark. A mess. But a well-intentioned mess. And that's something, I guess.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to unpack this *again*? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed it in my head a million times.

It's not just about being unsupervised, okay? It's about *where* I was unsupervised. The Loring's house is…intense. It's all Pottery Barn and perfect smiles and pretending everything is sunshine and rainbows. It feels…suffocating.

And Mark and Vanessa Loring? They're nice people, I guess. But they're also…really eager. Eager to be parents. Eager to have a baby. And they were looking at me like I was a walking, talking incubator. Like I was just a vessel for their perfect little family.

It felt weird. Like I wasn't a person, just a means to an end. And they kept asking me about baby names and nursery colors and stuff, and it just made me feel…icky.

Plus, they were *so* put-together. Everything had to be just right. And I'm, like, a mess. I wear band t-shirts and listen to The Moldy Peaches and I say whatever's on my mind. I don't *do* perfect.

So being left alone in their house felt like being trapped in a dollhouse. Like I was supposed to be a perfect little doll, and I just didn't fit. It was creepy and unsettling and made me want to run screaming.

It wasn't about not trusting them, exactly. It was about not trusting the *situation*. It was about feeling like I was being judged and evaluated and…processed. And honestly, it just freaked me out.

It's hard to explain. It was just a bad vibe. A really, really bad vibe.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not something I think about all the time, because if I did, I'd probably just curl up in a ball and never leave my room. But it's there, you know? Hanging out in the back of my brain.

It's weird, right? Like, I made a decision. A pretty huge decision. And it's not about *me* anymore. It's about them. Mark and Vanessa. And this little kid who's gonna be, like, a whole person.

At first, it was just…practical. I wasn't ready. I'm not ready, honestly. I have, like, zero life skills. I can barely keep my room clean. I definitely can't raise a baby.
