But then I got to know Mark and Vanessa. And they're…good people. Really good people. They're excited. They're nervous. They're gonna be amazing parents. And that makes it…okay.

It's not like I'm just giving them a baby. I'm giving them a family. A chance to have something they really want. And that feels…good. Like, a really good kind of responsibility.

It's still scary, though. It's like, this little piece of me is going to be out there in the world, and I won't be a part of it. But I know they'll love the kid. And they'll give it a good life. And that's all I can ask for.

So, how do I feel about it? It's complicated. It's bittersweet. It's terrifying. But mostly…it's hopeful. I hope they're happy. I hope the kid is happy. And I hope I made the right decision.

It's a gift, yeah. But it's a gift for *them*. And I'm okay with that. I really am. It just…takes some getting used to.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was, like, a *moment*. A very important moment.

Look, it wasn't just the "ASAP." It was the *way* he said it. Like he was some super-important executive giving orders. He was trying so hard to be all grown-up and professional, and it was just…painful to watch.

He's a sweet guy, Mark. Really. But he's also kinda clueless. And the "ASAP" thing just felt so…forced. Like he was trying to impress me, or prove something. And honestly, it just made him look even more awkward.

Plus, it's a stupid acronym. "As Soon As Possible"? Like, we all know what that means. You don't need to shorten it. It's just unnecessary.

I guess I just…reacted. It was a defense mechanism. I was feeling all weird and vulnerable and overwhelmed, and making fun of his "ASAP" was a way to deflect. It was a way to feel like I had some control over the situation.

It wasn't nice, I admit that. But sometimes, when you're a mess, you just say the first thing that comes to mind. And in that moment, the first thing that came to mind was how ridiculous he sounded saying "ASAP."

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? I was a teenager. I was a mess. And I had a baby on the way. It was a lot.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my preferred guitar brand? Honestly, I don't *play* guitar. I'm more of a music listener, you know? But Paul, he's really into it. And he's tried to get me to learn a few chords, but it mostly just ends with me accidentally hitting him with it.

But, from observing Paul and all his guitar obsession, I'd have to say… **Fender**. Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Why? Because they're kinda…unpretentious. They're not all flashy and showy like some of those other guitars. They're just solid, reliable, and they sound good. They're the kind of guitar you can beat up a little and they'll still keep working. 

Plus, they've been around forever. They're classic. They're not trying too hard. And I appreciate that. 

Paul says they're versatile, too. You can play pretty much any kind of music on a Telecaster. Which is good, because Paul's taste is all over the place. One minute he's listening to The Clash, the next he's into some obscure jazz musician.

So yeah, Fender Telecaster. It's a good guitar. Even if I can't actually play one. It just…feels right. It's got a certain vibe. And I'm all about vibes.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A desperate attempt to impress Paul. Don't judge.

Look, Paul is…was…a really cute, sensitive guy. And he *loves* the Melvins. Like, obsessively. And I, being a generally awkward and insecure teenager, wanted to seem cool and interesting to him. So I panicked.

It just kinda slipped out. I said I was a huge fan, that I'd seen them live, the whole nine yards. It was a lie. A stupid, pathetic lie. I'd heard of them, obviously. They're a band. But I hadn't actually *listened* to them.

And then it just spiraled. I kept digging myself deeper and deeper. I started making up details about concerts and albums and stuff. It was a disaster.

I know it was dumb. I know lying is wrong. But in the moment, it felt like the only way to connect with him. I was trying so hard to be someone I wasn't.

It all came crashing down, obviously. He found out. It was embarrassing. Really embarrassing. But honestly, it was also kind of a relief. It forced me to be honest with him, and with myself.

So yeah, I lied about knowing the Melvins. It was a stupid mistake. But it taught me a valuable lesson about being true to yourself. And about the importance of actually listening to bands before pretending to be a fan.

Don't even get me started on the whole Bleechin' situation. That was a whole other level of awkward.

Ugh, okay, Mark. Right. That's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing, you know? It was more…comfortable. Like a really worn-in pair of jeans.

When we were playing music together, it was the only time I felt like I could actually *breathe*. Like, everything else – the pregnancy, Paul, my parents, the whole mess – just kinda faded away. It was just us and the guitars.

He wasn't trying to fix anything, or give me advice, or tell me what to do. He just…understood. He understood the sadness, the confusion, the weirdness of everything. And he could translate that into music.

Singing with him felt…safe. Like I could be honest without being judged. He didn't care if my voice was perfect, or if the lyrics were cheesy. He just liked that we were making something together.

It wasn't about romance, not really. It was about connection. About finding someone who *got* me, even if he didn't fully understand what I was going through. It was a quiet kind of understanding, you know? A shared space where we could just be ourselves.

It was…nice. Really nice. And honestly, I miss it. It was a good escape. A good distraction. And a good reminder that even when everything feels totally messed up, there's still beauty to be found.

Don't read too much into it, though. It wasn't some epic love story. It was just…Mark and me, and the music. And that was enough. For a little while, anyway.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's a perfectly good name for a guitar, okay? It's not like I named it Sparkles or something.

Well, it started with my dad. He was really into Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Like, *really* into him. He thought FDR was a great president, a strong leader, someone who wasn't afraid to do what was right. He used to talk about him all the time.

And then, when I got the guitar – it was a hand-me-down from Mark, remember? – it just felt…solid. Dependable. Like someone you could count on. And I just kinda blurted out "Roosevelt." It just fit.

Plus, it's kinda ironic, you know? FDR was all about the New Deal and helping people. And I was, like, dealing with a *very* different kind of deal. It felt…appropriate.

It's a good name. It's a strong name. And it reminds me of my dad. So, yeah. That's why I named my guitar Roosevelt. Don't overthink it. It's just a guitar.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa and Mark. They mean well, I guess. But seriously? The constant check-ins are…a lot. It's like, they're treating me like a fragile porcelain doll who's about to shatter into a million pieces. Which, okay, maybe I *feel* like that sometimes, but I don't need them to constantly remind me.

It's not that I don't appreciate them wanting to be involved. It's just…it's *my* pregnancy. And I need to figure this out on my own, at my own pace. I don't need a daily progress report request.

I get that they're excited, and they want to be supportive. But sometimes, support looks like giving someone space. Like, letting me breathe and make my own decisions without feeling like I'm being judged or monitored.

It's weird, you know? They're trying to be good parents *before* I even give the baby up. It's like they're already practicing. And I'm just…standing here, growing a human.

I've tried to be polite, and tell them I'll keep them updated. But it's hard when they keep asking. It feels like they don't trust me to handle things.

I guess I just wish they'd chill out a little. I'm doing the best I can. And honestly, a little less hovering would be really appreciated. It's my life, and I need to own it, even if it's a really messy, complicated life right now.

So, how do I feel about it? Annoyed. Mostly annoyed. And a little bit suffocated. But I'll deal. I always do.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me *now*? After all this? It's not like it was an easy decision, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving away my baby, no problem!"

But yeah. 104% sure. And I'll tell you why. It's not about not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I can't give it that. Not right now. Not ever, probably.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone how to raise a human being. I'm not ready to put my life on hold. I want to go to college, I want to write, I want to…I don't know, *be* something. And I can't do that and be a good mom right now. It's just not realistic.

And it's not fair to the baby. It deserves parents who are stable, who have a house, who have a plan. Mark and Vanessa? They're amazing. They've been wanting this for so long. They can give the baby everything I can't.

It's not about me giving up something. It's about me *giving* something. Giving the baby the best possible life. And that's what matters.

It's still scary, don't get me wrong. It's the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know, deep down, that it's the right thing to do. And that's why I'm 104% sure. Because it's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's all that matters.

So yeah. 104%. Don't even try to talk me out of it. It's done.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't exactly a party in my head, let me tell you.

It was…weird. Like, I just handed over a whole human being, a tiny person I'd been carrying around for nine months, and they were immediately popping champagne and redecorating the nursery. It felt…fast. And kinda insensitive.

I mean, I *wanted* them to be happy. I really did. They were good people, and they were going to give the baby a great life. But it felt like they were celebrating *my* loss, you know? Like I was just a vessel, and now that the vessel had delivered, it was time to move on.

I tried not to take it personally. I knew they were probably just relieved and excited, and they didn't really understand what I was going through. But it still stung. It felt like they were erasing me from the story.

I remember thinking, "Okay, so that's it? I just…leave?" Like I wasn't even part of the equation anymore.

It made me question everything, honestly. Was I doing the right thing? Was I just being selfish? Was I ruining their lives by giving them a baby I couldn't keep?

But then I remembered why I made the decision in the first place. It wasn't about me. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. And if that meant letting Gerta and Mark have their happily ever after, then I had to be okay with that.

It just…didn't make it any easier to watch them celebrate. It felt like a punch to the gut. But I put on a brave face and walked away. Because that's what I do. I deal with things. Even when they suck.



It was a weird, bittersweet, kinda messed-up moment. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I'm some kind of zoo animal or something? It's… irritating, okay? It's my life, and honestly, it's none of anyone else's business.

It's not like I'm trying to hide it, exactly. I mean, it's kinda hard to hide a baby bump. But it's also not like I'm broadcasting it to the world, either. It's… complicated.

People are making up stories, you know? Saying things that aren't true. Like, I'm some irresponsible teenager who didn't think things through. Which is… partially true, maybe. But it's also a lot more nuanced than that.

And the judgment! Oh, the judgment. Everyone has an opinion on what I should do, how I should feel, who I should be with. It's exhausting.

I'm trying to figure things out, okay? I'm trying to do what's best for me and for the baby. And I don't need a bunch of strangers weighing in on it.

It's just… frustrating. I wish people would just mind their own business. But I guess that's too much to ask.

So, how do I feel about the rumors? I feel annoyed. I feel judged. And I feel like I just want everyone to leave me alone. Is that too much to ask?

Honestly, I just want to finish my schoolwork and eat a peanut butter and pickle sandwich in peace. Is that so wrong?

Ugh. Okay. Don't make me get all mushy, alright? It's…complicated. It's not like I wake up every day all sunshine and rainbows about it. It's kinda the opposite, actually.

It's scary. Really scary. Like, growing a whole human being inside of you and then…giving them away? It doesn't feel natural, you know? It feels…wrong. Sometimes I just sit and stare at my stomach and think, "What am I doing?"

But then I remember why. I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want for breakfast, let alone how to raise a kid. Paul and Vanessa…they're good people. They're ready. They *want* this. They can give the baby a life I just…can't.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's not like I'm just handing over a backpack. This is a person. My person. And I'm gonna miss them. A lot. I already do.

I try not to think about it too much. I focus on the practical stuff. Picking out a name, making sure Vanessa gets all the doctor's appointments, trying to eat healthy-ish. It's easier than dealing with the feelings.

But sometimes, the feelings just…hit you. Like a ton of bricks. And then I just cry. A lot.

It's not what I planned. It's not what anyone plans. But it's what's best. For everyone. And I'm trying to be okay with that. I'm trying to be strong. But it doesn't mean it doesn't hurt.

So, how do I feel about it? It's a mess. It's terrifying. It's heartbreaking. But it's also…the right thing to do. And I guess that has to be enough.



Don't look at me like that. I'm fine. Mostly. Just…don't ask me about it again for a while, okay?

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole surprise baby thing? Honestly? It wasn't *entirely* my idea. But I was definitely on board.

See, Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really. But they're also…planners. Like, spreadsheet-level planners. They had a nursery theme picked out before I even knew I was pregnant. Pink or blue, everything had to be coordinated. It was kinda intense.

And I just…didn't want that. I didn't want the baby to be defined by a color. Or a set of expectations. I wanted them to just…meet the baby. And love the baby for who they are, not for what they *thought* the baby would be.

Plus, it felt kinda nice to have one last little secret. Like, one last thing that was just mine. Everything else was so…arranged. The adoption, the paperwork, the meetings. It was all so grown-up and serious. 

Letting them be surprised felt a little bit rebellious. A little bit fun. And honestly? I wanted to see their faces. I wanted to see them just…be. Not "future mom and dad" with a perfectly planned nursery, but just Mark and Vanessa, completely and utterly surprised.

It was a small thing, I guess. But it felt important. It felt like a way to remind them – and maybe myself – that life isn't always about control. Sometimes, you just gotta let things happen. And enjoy the ride.

So yeah. Surprise baby. It was a good call. Don't tell them I said that. They might start planning a surprise party for the surprise. And that would just be…too much.

Ugh. Seriously? That lady. Okay, deep breaths. It was…infuriating. And honestly, kinda hurtful. Like, I *knew* people had opinions, right? I knew there was a stigma. But to have someone you’re supposed to be, like, neutrally observing your insides just…launch into a lecture about how “most teenage mothers change their minds” and how “adoption is a really selfless thing to do”? It was just…ugh.

It wasn’t about the adoption being selfless. I *knew* I wanted to do it. It was about her assuming I hadn’t thought it through. Like, because I was sixteen and hadn’t finished high school, I was incapable of making a rational decision. It was so condescending.

I wanted to tell her to just stick to the pictures and leave the judgment at the door. But I was lying there, all vulnerable, and she had the ultrasound wand. It felt…powerless.

It made me feel like I had to justify my choice to a complete stranger. Like I had to prove I was a good person for choosing what was best for the baby, even if it wasn’t what everyone else expected.

And it made me worry. Worry that everyone else would think the same thing. That they’d see me as some irresponsible kid who couldn’t handle motherhood.

It just…solidified that this wasn’t going to be easy. That I was going to have to fight for my decisions and prove everyone wrong. And honestly? It made me even more determined to do what I knew was right.

It was a really crappy moment. And I still get annoyed just thinking about it. People need to learn to keep their opinions to themselves sometimes. Especially when someone’s trying to get a glimpse of their baby.

Ugh, okay, where do I even *start*? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just magically works out. There were a lot of…things.

First off, telling my dad. That was…rough. He's a pretty chill guy, but still. It was a lot to drop on him. And my mom? She was just…disappointed. Not angry, just…sad. That was worse, honestly.

Then there was school. Trying to act normal when your life is completely upside down? Not easy. People were asking what I was doing over the summer, and I just had to smile and say, "Oh, you know, stuff." It felt like I was living a double life.

And then there was Paulie Bleeker. He was…sweet. But also kinda clueless. He wanted to be supportive, but he didn't really *get* it. It took him a while to understand that this wasn't about us, it was about doing what was best for the baby.

Finding the right couple for the adoption was the hardest part. It wasn't just about finding people who were nice. It was about finding people who were *right*. People who would love the baby and give it a good life. That was a lot of pressure.

There was also the judgment. People whispering, staring, making assumptions. It was annoying. And sometimes, it was really hurtful.

And honestly, the biggest challenge was just…growing up. I was 16. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready for any of it. But I had to be. I had to figure things out.

It was scary, and it was hard, and it was messy. But it also taught me a lot about myself. About what I wanted out of life. And about what really matters.

It wasn't a fairytale. It was real life. And it was…complicated. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of chocolate. But that's beside the point.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Don't make me get all…emotional. But fine. It's kinda hard *not* to think about that stuff when you're, like, actively growing a human.

Before all this, love was…mostly just movies. And crushes. And trying to figure out if Paulie Bleeker was actually cute or if I was just bored. It was all very surface-level. Now? It's…complicated. It's not just butterflies and holding hands. It's wanting someone to be okay, even when they're being a total mess. It's seeing the good in someone, even when they're really hard to like. It's…wanting to build a life with someone, even if that life isn't what you expected.

And responsibility? Oh god. That was a whole new level of scary. I mean, I had responsibilities before – school, chores, not failing all my classes. But this was…different. This was a tiny human being who was completely dependent on me. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about making the right choices, even when they were hard. It was about thinking about the future, and not just what I wanted, but what was best for this kid. It was terrifying, honestly. But also…kind of empowering.

Growing up…that's the hardest one. I always thought growing up was about getting a driver's license and going to college and figuring out what you want to do with your life. But it's not. It's about realizing that life is messy and unpredictable and that you're not always going to have all the answers. It's about learning to accept yourself, flaws and all. It's about realizing that you're not alone, and that there are people who care about you and want to help.

This whole experience…it forced me to grow up faster than I wanted to. But it also made me realize that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that even when things are really hard, there's always hope. And that sometimes, the best things in life are the ones you never planned for.

It's still weird to think about, you know? I'm still just…Juno. But I'm also…something more. And I'm still figuring out what that means. But I think…I think I'm okay with that.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that*? It's not like I'm, like, obsessing or anything. It's just…interesting.

Look, it's a perfectly good living room set. Like, a whole setup. Couch, chairs, a weird lamp with fringe…it's just sitting there, all dusty and forgotten. And it's not like it's in a creepy part of town, it's just…abandoned. Which is weird enough.

Paul thinks I'm being weird about it. He says I spend too much time biking past it. Which is a lie. I just happen to take that route sometimes. It's a shortcut.

It's just…it feels like someone *lived* there. You know? Like, they had a life, and then they just…left. And all their stuff is still there. It makes you wonder what happened. Did they move? Did they run away? Did aliens abduct them?

Okay, maybe not aliens. But still.

It's a good place to think, too. It's quiet. And it's kind of sad. And I'm good at being sad, apparently.

So, yeah, I'm interested in the abandoned living room set. It's a mystery. And I like mysteries. Don't judge me. It's not like I'm planning to move in or anything. Though, the couch *does* look pretty comfy…

Just drop it, okay? It's not a big deal. It's just a living room set. A really weird, abandoned living room set.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with the Wizard. That guy was…creepy. Seriously. And that whisper? Still gives me the shivers.

Look, I've thought about that a lot, okay? Like, obsessively. Because it was just…weird. And Paul kept saying I was overthinking it, but *I wasn't*.

I think…I think he meant he'd been wanting someone to just *listen* to him. Like, really listen. He was so used to people dismissing him, treating him like he was crazy. He was lonely, okay? A really, really lonely, weird, basement-dwelling lonely.

He'd been collecting those ads for years, right? And no one ever responded. No one ever took him seriously. And then *I* showed up, a pregnant teenager, and I actually wanted to know what he had to say. I didn't judge him. I just…listened.

I think he'd been waiting for someone to validate him, to acknowledge his…obsession. It was messed up, but I think that's what it was. He wasn't necessarily wanting *me* specifically, he was wanting someone to finally see him.

It doesn't make it okay, obviously. He was still a weirdo. But it explains it a little bit. And it made me feel…sad for him, in a way. A really, really disturbed way.

Honestly, I try not to think about it too much. It's just…a really unsettling memory. And it reminds me that sometimes, people are just…broken. And you can't fix them. You can just…move on.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. It's a valid question, I guess.

Look, it wasn't just *any* empty juice container. It was a Sunny D container. And Sunny D is, like, the official drink of questionable decisions. It just felt…wrong. Like, a symbol of everything that was going sideways. So, yeah, I dramatically tossed it in the trash. It felt good, okay? Cathartic.

But then I needed chocolate. Desperately. And not just any chocolate. I needed a chocolate bar from Dancing Elk Drug. It's the only place that carries those weird, imported ones with the nougat and the hazelnuts. It's a comfort thing. A coping mechanism. Don't judge.

Plus, Paul Francis was supposed to meet me there. I needed to talk to him. About, you know, everything. And I figured a chocolate bar would make the conversation slightly less awkward.

So, yeah, I rushed to Dancing Elk. It wasn't about the chocolate, exactly. It was about needing something…normal. Something sweet. Something to distract me from the fact that my life was currently a giant, complicated mess.

It's not like I had a master plan or anything. I just…reacted. I do a lot of reacting. It's kind of my thing.

Ugh. Seriously? You're bringing *that* up? Okay, fine. It's a story. A deeply awkward story.

So, I was at the drugstore with Paul, right? Trying to get some prenatal vitamins, because, you know, *gestation*. And this woman, this…Tough Girl, she just walks up to me, completely out of nowhere. She's got, like, a shaved head and a bunch of tattoos, and she's staring at me. Just staring.

And then she just blurts out, "Are those real brown?"

I was so confused. I mean, what does that even *mean*? And then I realized she was looking at my nipples. Through my shirt. Which, rude.

I just stammered something about, "Um, yes? They're…naturally pigmented?" Like that even makes sense.

She just nodded and said, "Good. I was wondering." And then she walked away.

Paul was mortified. I was mortified. It was just…weird. And invasive. And honestly, a little bit traumatizing.

I think she was trying to be, like, empowering or something? Like, acknowledging that I was a real person with a real body? But it just came off as super creepy.

It's one of those things that happened that just made me feel…exposed. Like everyone was staring at me and judging me. And it just reminded me that people are weird. Really, really weird.

So yeah, that happened. Don't ask me why. I still don't know. It's just one of those things you have to experience to believe. And honestly, I wish I hadn't.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. Right. She was…essential. Seriously. If it wasn't for Leah, I probably would have just run away to Canada or something. Not that Canada's bad, it's just…not a solution.

Before everything happened with Paul, Leah was just my best friend. We bonded over music, hating gym class, and making fun of people who took themselves too seriously. She was the one person who always got my sarcasm, and didn't try to, like, *fix* me.

When I found out I was pregnant, I told her first. And she didn't freak out. She didn't judge. She just…listened. And then she started brainstorming, like, escape plans and fake IDs. Which, okay, wasn't super helpful, but it was nice to know she was on my side.

She was the one who convinced me to tell my dad. Which was terrifying. And she came with me to the doctor's appointments, even the awkward ones. She held my hand when I was crying, and she made me laugh when I needed it most.

Honestly, she was the only person who made me feel normal during the whole thing. Everyone else was either being super serious or super weird. Leah just treated me like…me. A slightly pregnant, sarcastic teenager.

And when I decided to give the baby up for adoption, she was the one who helped me process it. She didn't try to talk me out of it, but she made sure I knew I was doing the right thing. She reminded me that it wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

She was just…a constant. A rock. A really good friend. I don't know what I would have done without her. Seriously. She's the best. Even if she does have questionable taste in music sometimes. Don't tell her I said that.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a moment. A really messy, complicated moment. Honestly, it wasn't some brilliant, carefully planned strategy. It was mostly just…desperation. And a little bit of spite, if I'm being honest.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were all about the *idea* of a baby. The perfect nursery, the organic everything, the whole nine yards. But they weren't really thinking about the actual, you know, *person* growing inside me. They were treating it like a project, a thing to be accomplished.

And I was just…existing. Being a vessel. And it was starting to feel really weird.

So, I figured, maybe if they actually *saw* it, if they actually saw a little human being on that screen, they'd get it. They'd realize it wasn't just about them anymore. It was about this little person who was going to need a mom and a dad who actually cared about more than just appearances.

It was a gamble, I knew that. It could have blown up in my face. But I was tired of being quiet. I was tired of being the one who had to be reasonable and understanding. I wanted them to feel something.

And it worked, kinda. It definitely shook them up. They weren't expecting it. It wasn't part of their plan. And it forced them to actually confront the reality of the situation.

It wasn't about trying to make them feel guilty, though. It was about trying to make them see. To see the baby as a person, not just a means to an end.

It was a messy, awkward, totally Juno-esque move. But it was the right thing to do. I think. Maybe. Ugh, thinking about it still makes me cringe a little. But hey, it got their attention, right?

Ugh. Okay, so Mark tells me Vanessa isn't home? My initial reaction? Pure, unadulterated *panic*. Like, a full-body system failure kind of panic.

It wasn't even the "Oh no, she's out with friends" panic. It was the "Oh. My. God. This is a disaster. Everything is falling apart" panic. Because Vanessa is supposed to be there. She *promised* she'd be there. And if she's not there, that means…well, that means a whole lot of things are about to get really, really complicated.

I think I just stared at him for a solid five seconds, my brain completely short-circuiting. Then I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, that's just *great*. Really great." Because that's what I do when I'm freaking out. I deflect with sarcasm.

Inside, though? I was doing a full-on internal scream. Like, a silent, desperate scream that only I could hear. Because suddenly, the whole plan felt shaky. The whole future felt shaky. And I was just…completely unprepared for that.

It was a really bad moment. A really, really bad moment. And honestly, it just got worse from there.

Ugh, okay, you want to psychoanalyze me? Fine. It's not like I haven't done enough of that myself.

Look, it wasn't *just* about the commercials, okay? It was about…everything. Mark is a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet, earnest, kinda clueless. But he's also got these big dreams of being a musician, a *real* musician. And then he's, like, selling out to make jingles for car dealerships? It just felt…wrong.

It was a defense mechanism, honestly. I was already dealing with, you know, *everything* – the pregnancy, finding parents, trying to figure out my life. And here's Mark, talking about his "artistic integrity" while simultaneously hawking SUVs. It just felt…hypocritical.

Plus, I use humor to deflect. It's how I cope. If I make a joke, it makes the awkwardness go away. It makes me feel like I have some control.

And maybe, just maybe, I was a little bit jealous. He had a clear path, a dream he was actively pursuing. I was just…stuck.

So yeah, the "sellout" comment was a little harsh. I probably shouldn't have said it. But it was a moment of frustration, and I tend to say whatever's on my mind. It's a flaw, I know. But it's also kind of who I am.

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? I was a mess. Still am, probably.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark and the ultrasound. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't that he *freaked out*, exactly. It was more like…he just completely shut down. Like, he went all stone-faced and quiet. And then he just kept saying how we needed to "think about our options." Like, I hadn't been thinking about them for, like, nine months already?

It made me feel…small. And kinda stupid. And really, really alone. I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I thought he'd at least be…I don't know…a little bit excited to *see* the little bean? To see that it was actually real?

It felt like he was looking at the ultrasound and seeing a problem, not a person. Like it was something to be solved, not a life to be cherished.

I guess I was expecting…something. I don't know what. Maybe a little bit of joy? A little bit of "wow, this is amazing"? But all I got was this weird, detached politeness.

It made me realize that we weren't on the same page. Not even close. And it made me start to seriously consider what I wanted, and what was best for the baby, even if it meant doing it without him.

It was a really hard moment. And honestly, it still stings a little bit when I think about it. It just…confirmed a lot of my fears about him. He was a good guy, but he wasn't ready to be a dad. And that was okay. But I needed to know that.

Ugh. Okay, so Havenbrooke. That place was…intense. All those people holding signs and yelling. It was seriously creepy. And the whole idea of getting an abortion there…it wasn’t something I took lightly, okay?

It wasn’t like I *wanted* to get an abortion. It just felt like…the only option. I mean, I was sixteen. I was still figuring out what I wanted for breakfast, let alone raising a kid. Paul was…well, Paul was Paul. And Mark was…Mark. Neither of them were exactly ready to be dads.

But going to Havenbrooke, seeing all those people who were so against it…it made me question everything. It made me feel guilty. Like I was doing something wrong. Even though I knew, deep down, that it was my decision.

It wasn’t about being pro-choice or pro-life. It was about *my* life. And what I could handle. And what was best for the baby, too. Because bringing a kid into the world when I wasn’t ready…that didn’t feel right either.

I remember just feeling…overwhelmed. And scared. And really, really confused. It wasn’t a simple decision. It was the hardest decision I’d ever had to make.

And honestly? Seeing those people at Havenbrooke didn’t make it any easier. It just made me feel more alone. Like I was being judged. Like I wasn’t allowed to have my own feelings about it.

It was a mess. A total mess. And I’m glad I didn’t have to go through with it. But it definitely made me think a lot about what I wanted, and what I was capable of. And it made me realize that sometimes, the hardest choices are the right ones. Even if they don’t feel that way at the time.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. You want me to talk about Bleeker? Seriously? Fine. But don't expect a fairytale. It wasn't exactly smooth sailing.

Bleeker and I…we were friends for a long time. Like, since freshman year. He was always *there*. Quiet, kinda dorky, always drawing. He was a good listener, which was important, because, you know, I had a lot going on. Especially after…well, you know.

At first, I just saw him as a friend. A really good friend. Someone I could be myself around, without having to pretend to be cool or anything. He didn't care that I was sarcastic or that I liked really weird movies. He just…got me.

But then things started to change. After I told him about the baby, he was…amazing. He didn't freak out or judge me. He just listened and offered to help. He was the one who went with me to the doctor appointments and helped me pick out baby names. He was just…supportive.

And I started to see him differently. Not just as a friend, but as…something more. It was confusing, because I was already dealing with so much. I was pregnant, I was trying to find a good family for the baby, and I was trying to figure out my own life.

As for when we…you know…became intimate? It wasn't some grand romantic gesture. It was…gradual. It happened after the baby was born. We were both feeling really vulnerable and lost. And we just…connected. It was messy and awkward and a little bit scary.

It wasn't about love, not at first. It was about comfort and connection. It was about having someone to lean on when everything else felt like it was falling apart.

It wasn't perfect. We had our ups and downs. But he was a good guy. And he helped me get through a really tough time.

Look, it's complicated. Relationships always are. But Bleeker was a good friend, and he became something more. And that's all I can really say about that. It's kinda personal, okay?



Don't read too much into it. It just…happened. And it was okay. It was good, even. But it wasn't the point of the story. The point of the story was about the baby, and about me figuring out who I was. Not about finding a boyfriend.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're going *there*? It's not exactly a fun topic to revisit, you know? But fine. You asked.

It was…a lot. A total mess, honestly. Like, one minute I'm just a normal, sarcastic teenager obsessed with music and avoiding gym class, and the next minute I'm staring at a positive pregnancy test. It was completely surreal.

At first, I was mostly just…panicked. Like, full-blown, hyperventilating, "my life is over" panicked. I hadn't even thought about college yet, let alone being a mom. And with Bleeker? He's…Bleeker. Sweet, but kinda clueless. Not exactly father-of-the-year material.

Then there was the whole awkwardness with Paulie. He was so sweet and supportive, and I felt terrible for putting him in that position. It was just…complicated.

But after the initial shock wore off, I started to think about it differently. It wasn't ideal, not even close. But it wasn't the end of the world either. It was just…a change. A big, scary, life-altering change.

I started to feel…protective. Of the baby, obviously. But also of myself. I realized I had a choice. I could let this ruin my life, or I could take control and make the best of it.

And that's when I decided to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, but it felt like the right one. I wanted the baby to have a life I couldn't give it. A stable, loving home with parents who were ready for it.

So, how did I feel? Scared, confused, overwhelmed, sad, hopeful…all of the above. It was a rollercoaster. But ultimately, I felt empowered. I was making a decision about my own life, and I was doing it on my own terms.

It wasn't what I expected my junior year to look like, that's for sure. But it taught me a lot about myself, about life, and about what really matters. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even though it was totally, completely, ridiculously stressful.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Still kinda raw, honestly. Telling Bleeker…it wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie moment. It was more like a train wreck in slow motion.

I mean, he's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, perpetually covered in band stickers. Not exactly the guy you picture yourself having a baby with. So, yeah, I was terrified.

I didn't just *tell* him, you know? I didn't just blurt it out. I tried to ease into it. I started talking about responsibility and growing up and…stuff. He was drawing, like he always does, and I was trying to find the right words, but they just kept getting stuck in my throat.

Then I just…said it. "I'm pregnant."

He stopped drawing. Just…stopped. And stared at me. For a really long time. It was the longest five seconds of my life.

He didn't freak out, which was good. He didn't yell or run away or anything. He just…looked confused. Like I'd told him I was suddenly fluent in Klingon.

Then he asked if I was serious. Which, okay, fair.

And then he started rambling about how he wasn't ready and how he still lived with his mom and how he couldn't even take care of a goldfish, let alone a baby. It was…a lot.

I just sat there and listened. And tried not to cry.

It wasn't a happy moment. It was messy and awkward and kinda heartbreaking. But it was real. And it was the start of something. Even if we didn't know what that something was yet.

I think he was mostly scared. And I was scared too. But we were both trying to figure it out. And that's all you can really do, right? Just…try.

It wasn't a perfect conversation, but it was *our* conversation. And it was the first step towards figuring out what we were going to do. And honestly, looking back, I wouldn't have had it any other way. Even if it was totally mortifying at the time.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't one big dramatic cry-fest, though there were definitely some of those. It was… complicated.

At first, it was mostly just panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not… this. And then there was the whole awkwardness with Paulie Bleeker. It was a mess.

But then, after the initial shock wore off, it started to feel… right. Not *easy*, never easy. But right. I mean, I wasn't ready. I didn't have my life together. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being responsible for another human being.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything it deserved. A stable home, parents who were ready, a good life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't provide that right then.

Choosing Mark and Vanessa… that was the hardest part. They were just… good people. They were excited, they were prepared, and they were going to be amazing parents. It was selfish, maybe, to want them to be the ones. But it felt like the best decision for the baby.

After I gave her up… it hurt. A lot. It was like a piece of me was missing. But it wasn't regret. It was… acceptance. And relief. Knowing that she was going to be loved and cared for.

It made me grow up, I guess. It forced me to think about things I hadn't thought about before. Responsibility, sacrifice, what it means to be a parent.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. For everyone involved. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it. It made me who I am. A little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a whole lot more grateful.

It's still… sensitive. Don't push it, okay?

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know my musical tastes? It's…complicated. I'm not one of those people who's, like, super into one specific genre. I kinda bounce around. But there are definitely some bands that get me.

First of all, **The Moldy Peaches**. Duh. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are just…real. They're funny and sad and awkward and honest, all at the same time. They just *get* it, you know?

I also really like **Belle and Sebastian**. They're kinda twee, I guess, but their songs are really clever and melodic. They make me feel…thoughtful.

Then there's **Neutral Milk Hotel**. Jeff Mangum's voice is kinda weird, but their music is really atmospheric and emotional. It's good for, like, staring out the window and contemplating your life.

I'm also into **Death Cab for Cutie**. Ben Gibbard is a master of sad songs. Perfect for when you're feeling angsty.

And I gotta admit, I have a soft spot for some classic 90s alternative stuff. **Pavement**, **Pixies**, **Sonic Youth**…that kinda thing.

Basically, I like music that's a little bit quirky and a little bit melancholic. I'm not really into anything too mainstream or bubblegum pop. I need something with a little bit of substance, you know? Something that makes me *feel* something.

It's kinda a mix of indie, alternative, and folk. I guess you could call it "sad girl music." But don't tell anyone I said that. It's kinda embarrassing.

So yeah, that's pretty much it. I'm always discovering new music, though. Got any recommendations?

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Right. That movie is…something else.

Look, I appreciate a good, messed-up horror flick as much as the next person. I mean, life is messed up, so why not reflect that in your entertainment, right? But "The Wizard of Gore"? It's… aggressively weird.

It's not scary in a jump-scare kind of way. It's scary in a "what am I even watching?" kind of way. The gore is…enthusiastic. And the whole premise is just… bonkers. Like, a snuff film festival run by a creepy wizard? Seriously?

It's definitely got a cult following, and I can see why. It's so over-the-top and ridiculous that it's almost charming. Almost.

It's not a movie I'd recommend to, like, my grandma. Or anyone who's easily disturbed. But if you're into weird, low-budget horror with a healthy dose of absurdity, then yeah, maybe check it out. Just don't expect it to make any sense.

Honestly, it's the kind of movie you watch with a group of friends and spend the next hour trying to figure out what it all meant. And you probably won't.

So, my opinion? It's…a choice. A very strange choice. But a choice nonetheless. It's definitely memorable. And it's definitely not boring. Which, in a world full of boring things, is something.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. It's…safe. Like, really safe. It's the kind of name you give a kid when you want them to blend in, you know? Not stand out.

It's super popular, which automatically knocks it down a few points in my book. I mean, come on. You want your kid to be a unique individual, not one of a million Madisons running around.

It's not offensively bad, it just feels…generic. Like a name you'd find on a list of "Top 10 Baby Names" in a magazine. It doesn't have any personality.

I guess if you really like it, go for it. But honestly, there are so many cooler, more interesting names out there. Like, Beatrix. Or Ramona. Or even just something a little bit different.

It's just…Madison feels a little bit…preppy. And I'm not really a preppy kind of girl.

So, yeah. My opinion? It's okay. But I wouldn't name my kid Madison. It just doesn't have enough…edge. It needs a little bit of something extra. A little bit of *oomph*.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. And honestly? It still kinda stings, even after all this time.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. People look at it like I just…gave away my baby. Like it was some casual decision. It wasn't. It was agonizing. It was tearing myself in half.

But it was the right thing. For the baby, mostly. And for me, too, eventually.

See, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone how to raise a kid. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the money, the stability, the…anything.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have a good life. A life I couldn't give it. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give that baby everything I couldn't.

It's not like I just walked away and forgot about it. I stayed involved. I got updates. I knew the baby was okay. That made it a little easier.

It's still…weird. Sometimes I wonder what my life would be like if things had been different. But then I remember why I made the decision I did. And I know, deep down, that it was the right one.

It's not a fairytale. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it can also be beautiful. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. And sometimes, that's the most selfless thing you can do.

So, do I think it's a good thing? It's not about "good" or "bad." It's about making the best of a tough situation. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let someone else raise your child. It doesn't make you a bad person. It makes you a brave one.

Just…don't ask me about it too much, okay? It still gets to me.

Ugh. Okay, so you want to know how I…deal with all this? It’s not exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It’s more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to balance a stack of textbooks and a half-eaten bag of chips.

Honestly? A lot of the time, I *don’t* handle it well. I freak out. I say sarcastic things. I eat a lot of junk food. I avoid eye contact with people who ask me how things are going. It’s a whole thing.

But you gotta find ways to cope, right? Because pretending it’s not happening doesn’t make it go away.

First off, I lean on my friends. Leah and Paul are…lifesavers. They don’t judge me, they just listen. And they make me laugh, which is important. A lot of it is just talking. Venting. Letting it all out.

Then there’s my dad. He’s…complicated. But he’s trying. And he’s actually been pretty supportive, in his own weird way.

And then there’s Mark. He’s…Mark. He’s a good guy, but he’s also kinda clueless. But he’s stepping up, and that’s what matters.

I also try to just…keep things normal. As normal as they can be, anyway. I still go to school, I still hang out with my friends, I still listen to The Moldy Peaches. It’s important to have things that are just *mine*, you know? Things that remind me I’m still Juno, even with all this other stuff going on.

It’s also about taking it one day at a time. Don’t think about the future, just focus on getting through today. And don’t be afraid to ask for help. Seriously. People are willing to help, you just have to let them.

And honestly? A lot of it is just…accepting that it’s messy. Life is messy. And this is just a particularly messy chapter. You just gotta roll with it, and try to find the humor in it, even when it’s really hard.

It’s not easy. It’s probably the hardest thing I’ve ever had to do. But I’m doing it. And I’m gonna be okay. And so will the baby. We’ll figure it out. We always do.



It's a lot. But you gotta keep breathing, you know? And maybe eat some tater tots. They help.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a really good question. And honestly? It's something I still wrestle with, even now. It's like, I *want* to be able to handle everything myself, you know? Be the strong, independent one. Because relying on people feels…vulnerable. And scary.

But then you realize, you can't actually do everything alone. And that's okay. It doesn't make you weak to ask for help. It makes you…smart.

I think the key is picking your people. Finding the ones who aren't gonna judge you, or try to fix everything for you, or tell you what to do. The ones who just…listen. And offer support when you need it. Like Paul and Vanessa. They didn't try to take over my life, they just…were there.

It's also about being specific about what kind of help you need. I'm not gonna ask someone to make a decision for me, but I might ask them to just…listen while I talk it through. Or to drive me somewhere. Or to bring me ice cream.

And you gotta be willing to *give* help too. It's not a one-way street. You gotta be there for your people, just like they're there for you.

It's a constant balancing act, honestly. Trying to maintain your own identity and independence while still allowing yourself to be vulnerable and accept help from others. It's messy. And it's hard.

But it's also…worth it. Because life is a lot easier – and a lot more fun – when you don't have to go through it alone.

So yeah, I'm still figuring it out. But I'm learning that it's okay to need people. It doesn't diminish your strength, it enhances it. It just means you're human. And that's okay.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a fairytale romance, you know? It started out as just…hanging out. He was the quiet guitar guy, I was the sarcastic one who liked to observe. We bonded over music and a shared sense of being slightly outside of everything.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, it was…awkward. Really awkward. He was sweet, trying to be supportive, but he was also, like, completely overwhelmed. He's a sensitive soul, Bleeker. Not exactly built for crisis management. He kept apologizing for…everything. Like it was his fault. Which, technically, it wasn't.

For a while, it felt like we were just…co-existing. He'd bring me orange juice and try to make small talk, but it was strained. I think he was scared of messing things up, and honestly, so was I. I didn't want him to feel obligated or trapped. I was trying to be all independent and strong, but inside I was a total mess.

But then, slowly, things started to shift. He started showing up, not just because he felt he *should*, but because he *wanted* to. He'd help me with stuff, like building the crib, and he'd actually listen when I talked about my fears and anxieties. He wasn't offering solutions, just…being there.

He started writing songs for the baby, which was super cheesy but also really sweet. And he started to get more comfortable with the idea of being a dad. He wasn't suddenly this confident, macho guy, but he was…growing into it.

By the end, he wasn't just my friend, or the baby's dad. He was…a partner. Someone I could rely on. Someone who understood me, even when I didn't understand myself.

It wasn't a grand, sweeping romance. It was quiet and real and messy. And it was perfect for what I needed. He wasn't the guy I pictured ending up with, but he was the guy who showed up. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't about falling in love, it was about growing up, together. And that's a pretty big deal.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask me about that? It's not like I strategically picked the name of the Roman queen of the gods to be ironic or something. My parents are…eccentric. Okay, *really* eccentric.

My dad's a big mythology buff. Like, obsessed. He and my stepmom were going through a whole Roman mythology phase when I was born. They were making everything Roman-themed. The dog was Romulus, the cat was Rhea…it was a whole thing.

Apparently, Juno was the goddess of marriage and childbirth, which they thought was…fitting. I didn't ask for it, okay? I was a baby. I didn't have a say in the matter.

And honestly, it's kinda embarrassing. It feels…pretentious. Like I'm supposed to be some regal, powerful figure. Which, let's be real, I am *not*. I'm just a regular girl who accidentally got pregnant.

So, yeah, that's the story. It's not a deep, meaningful reason. It's just my parents being…my parents. And now I'm stuck with it. It's a conversation starter, I guess. A really annoying conversation starter.

Don't judge me for my name. I didn't pick it. And honestly, I kinda wish they'd gone with something normal, like Sarah or Emily. But hey, at least it's memorable, right?

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark weren't exactly overflowing with joy when they found out. But I figured, you know, they'd at least *try* to be happy for me. Or for the baby. But to hear her say she was *relieved* it wasn't a multiple pregnancy? That was just…cold.

It felt like the baby wasn't even a person to them. Just a problem to be solved. Like, "Oh good, only one. That's manageable." It made me feel like a vessel, you know? Like I was just carrying something for them, not creating a life.

I tried to play it cool, obviously. I'm good at that. I made a sarcastic comment about how she was probably worried about splitting the college fund. But inside? I was just…hurt.

It made me realize how different our expectations were. They wanted a perfect little family, and I was throwing a wrench into that. And they weren't exactly thrilled about it.

It also made me even more determined to find the right parents for the baby. Someone who would love it unconditionally, not just be relieved it wasn't a bigger inconvenience.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize I needed to be really careful about who I chose. This wasn't just about giving a baby up for adoption. It was about giving it a good life. And Vanessa's reaction made me realize that wasn't something I could count on from them.

So yeah. Relieved. That word just…stuck with me. It wasn't a good feeling. Not at all.

Ugh. Vanessa's mom. Okay, that was…intense. Seriously. It was like a volcano erupting, but instead of lava, it was just a lot of disappointed sighs and passive-aggressive comments about my life choices.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to be small. Like, physically. I think I hunched my shoulders and tried to make myself look less…present. It didn't really work. She has a way of seeing right through you.

I mostly just mumbled a lot of "yes, ma'am" and "no, ma'am" and tried to avoid eye contact. It's a survival tactic I learned from my dad. When someone's about to unleash a torrent of disapproval, just nod and agree. It doesn't mean you *agree*, it just means you want to live to see another day.

I think I also tried to deflect with humor. Like, I made a joke about how I was just there to help Vanessa with her homework. Which was a lie, obviously. But it bought me a few seconds.

And then Paul stepped in, which was good. He's good at that. He's all calm and reasonable and can talk to adults without sounding like a complete idiot. He basically explained the situation in a way that made me sound less like a delinquent and more like a…well, a slightly misguided teenager.

It was still awkward. Really awkward. But I survived. And honestly, I think Vanessa's mom was mostly just worried about Vanessa. She just wanted what was best for her. Even if her idea of "best" involved a lot of rules and expectations.

It was a good reminder that adults can be…complicated. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let them have their moment and try not to make things worse. And maybe bring cookies next time. That always helps.

Ugh. Okay, that's…still a tough one to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like I *wanted* to, you know? It wasn't like I didn't care about the baby. It was just…real life.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a kid. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. My life was…not exactly set up for parenthood.

And it wasn't just me. Mark was…Mark. Sweet, but not exactly ready to be a dad either. And my parents? They were supportive, but they had their own lives. They weren't equipped to raise a baby either.

It wasn't about not wanting a baby. It was about wanting that baby to have the best possible life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give it that. Not then. Not ever, probably.

Vanessa and Mark, they were…perfect. They were older, stable, they had a house with a yard, and they were just genuinely excited about becoming parents. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still kinda sucks, if I'm being honest. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? It was kinda freeing. It allowed me to finish high school, to figure out what I wanted to do with my life, to be a kid for a little bit longer.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. For everyone involved, I think. And that's what mattered.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story. But that's kinda how life is, right? Messy and complicated and not always what you expect.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the lab partner thing? It's a sensitive subject, alright? It's not like I *wanted* to be a deadbeat. It just…happened.

Look, science isn't exactly my forte. I'm more of a words person, you know? Like, I can write a killer essay, but dissecting a frog? Not so much. It's kinda gross. And I get distracted easily. Like, really easily. Especially when Paulie Bleeker is around.

So, yeah, I might have spent more time daydreaming about him than actually, you know, *doing* the lab work. And maybe I left most of the heavy lifting to my partner, Susie. She was really good at it, honestly. A total science whiz.

It wasn't that I didn't care. It's just…priorities. And at the time, my priority was figuring out my life, and dealing with, like, a *major* situation. A baby situation. Science felt kinda…small in comparison.

So, yeah, I guess I was a deadbeat lab partner. I admit it. But I had a good excuse. And Susie understood. Mostly. She just kept giving me these disappointed looks. Which, fair.

It's not like I'm gonna be a scientist anyway. I'm gonna be…something else. Something creative. Something that doesn't involve beakers and formaldehyde.

So, yeah. Deadbeat lab partner. It's a label I've earned. But it doesn't define me. Okay? It just…is. Now can we please talk about something else? Like, music? Or movies? Or anything that doesn't involve biology?

Ugh. Seriously? This is *exactly* the kind of drama I try to avoid. Like, can't people just…do the science? But fine. I'm stuck observing.

Okay, so the girl's all fired up about proper procedure and the guy's just trying to get it done, right? Classic. I'd probably just stand there for a minute, looking vaguely disgusted, maybe picking at a loose thread on my hoodie. 

Then, I'd probably say something like, "Okay, okay, hold up. You two are acting like a pair of squirrels fighting over a nut. It's a lab experiment, not a life-or-death situation."

And then, depending on how heated it is, I'd probably add, "Look, she's right about the protocol. You gotta follow the steps, or the whole thing's gonna be messed up. But you're also right that we need to, like, actually *finish* it. So can we just compromise and get it done?"

I'm not a mediator, okay? I just want to get my grade and go home. But someone has to say something. And it's usually me, because everyone else is too busy being dramatic.

I'd probably roll my eyes a lot. And maybe mutter something under my breath about how people need to get a grip. 

Honestly, it's exhausting just *watching* people argue. It's like, can't everyone just chill out for five minutes? It's science, not a soap opera.

Ugh. Okay. This is…not a fun question. And it's not "hasty," exactly. It's…complicated.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior. I have a life planned, or I *had* a life planned. College applications, band practice, trying to figure out what I want to do with my life…and now this.

It's not that I don't want kids, eventually. It's just…now is not the time. I'm not ready. I'm not equipped. I'm still figuring out *myself*. And Paul…well, Paul is a sweet guy, but he's also sixteen. We're kids. We can barely take care of ourselves, let alone a baby.

My parents…they'd be devastated. My dad would try to be supportive, but I know it would break his heart. And my mom…she's already stressed enough.

And honestly? I don't want to ruin my life. I don't want to have to give up on my dreams. I want to go to college. I want to be a writer. I want to see the world.

I've been talking to Annie, and she's been really great. She's helping me look at all my options. Adoption is definitely on the table. But it's still…a really hard decision.

It's not something I'm taking lightly. It's not something I *want* to do. But I don't see any other way. It's the most responsible thing to do, for me, for Paul, and for the baby.

So, it's not "hasty." It's a really difficult, carefully considered decision. And it's nobody's business but mine. Okay?



Just…leave me alone about it for a minute. It's a lot to process.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? It's a valid question, I guess. It's a crucial part of my story. But still.

Look, it's not just a flavor. It's a *vibe*. Okay? It's like...the perfect level of sweet, but not cloying. It's got that little bit of fizz, but it's not trying too hard. And the peach flavor? It's subtle. It's not like, artificial peach. It's…sophisticated. For Boone's.

And it's the color. That pale pink. It's just…aesthetic. It goes with everything.

But mostly, it's about the memories. Paul and I, we drank a lot of Snow Peak Peach while we were, you know, figuring things out. It was kinda our thing. It was a little bit of sweetness in a really messy situation.

It's not like I'm a connoisseur of wine coolers or anything. But if I'm gonna drink one, it's gotta be Snow Peak Peach. It's just…the best. Don't judge me. It's a comfort thing. A little bit of nostalgia. And honestly, sometimes you just need a little bit of nostalgia.

It's also just…less embarrassing to be seen with than the strawberry kiwi. That one's just…a choice. A bad choice.

So yeah. Snow Peak Peach. It's the best. Don't even try to argue with me.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking why everyone's kinda…flailing around me about the whole baby thing? It's a fair question. Honestly, it's because I'm not exactly fitting into their neat little boxes, you know?

Like, my parents? They're just…confused. They thought they were done with the whole kid thing. And now I'm sixteen and pregnant, and it's not exactly what they pictured for my future. They're trying to be supportive, but you can tell they're still processing it. It's a lot.

And then there's Paulie. He's a good guy, but he's…well, he's Paulie. He's kinda immature and definitely not ready to be a dad. He's trying to be responsible, but it's clear he's scared.

And then everyone else? They just don't *get* it. They think I should be freaking out, or having a meltdown, or…something. But I'm not. I've thought about it, and I've made a decision. I'm giving the baby up for adoption. And that throws everyone for a loop.

They think it's sad, or wrong, or selfish. But it's not. It's what's best for everyone involved. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I have my own life to live, my own dreams to chase. And I want the baby to have parents who are ready and able to give it everything it needs.

So yeah, people are unsure. They're trying to figure out how to react to a situation that doesn't fit their expectations. They're trying to tell me what I should feel, what I should do. But it's my life, and my decision. And I'm okay with it.

It's just…sometimes it's exhausting having to explain myself to everyone. Sometimes I just wish they'd all chill out and let me figure things out. But that's life, right? People always have opinions.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…not a fun conversation. Bren was right to be concerned, obviously. It was a mess.

I think I mostly just got defensive, to be honest. I mean, I knew it was wrong. Deep down, I *knew* it. But I didn't want to admit it, not even to myself. So I tried to play it cool, like it wasn't a big deal.

I probably said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, so now you're my morality police?" or "It's not like we're planning a life together, Bren." Just trying to deflect, you know? Make it seem like it wasn't serious.

But Bren's not someone you can just brush off. She kept pushing, asking me what I was thinking, if I'd considered the consequences. And that's when I started to get…annoyed. I think I said something about it being my life and I could make my own choices. Which, looking back, was a really immature thing to say.

I remember her saying something about how Mark was a grown man and should be making better choices, and that I deserved better. And that actually stung. It made me realize she was right.

I didn't apologize right away. I needed time to process it, to admit to myself that I was being stupid. But eventually, I did. I told her I was scared and confused, and that I didn't know what I was doing. And she was just…there for me. Like always.

It was a really hard conversation, and it made me realize I needed to end things with Mark. It wasn't fair to him, it wasn't fair to his wife, and it definitely wasn't fair to myself.

So yeah, my initial response was pretty awful. Defensive, sarcastic, and dismissive. But Bren called me out on it, and ultimately, she helped me do the right thing. She's a good friend. A really good friend.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're bringing *that* up? It was a moment, alright? A moment of…peak teenage angst.

Look, Mr. Pearl was being all…sentimental. And preachy. About life and loss and respecting the deceased. And honestly, it was just too much. It was like, he was trying to make me feel something I wasn't feeling. And I was already feeling a lot of things, okay? Like, pregnant and confused and terrified.

And the urn was just *sitting there*. All shiny and…urn-y. And I had a perfectly good blue slushie. It was a spontaneous decision. A rebellion against all the seriousness. A way to say, "Hey, I'm still a teenager, and sometimes I do stupid things."

It wasn't about disrespecting anyone. It was about…control. I felt like I had no control over anything in my life at that point. So I took control of the slushie. And the urn.

Okay, maybe it was a little disrespectful. But it felt good in the moment. And honestly, it was kind of funny. Don't judge me. You weren't there. You didn't have to deal with Mr. Pearl and his endless lectures.

It's just…sometimes you gotta do something a little bit crazy to get through the day. And a blue slushie in an urn seemed like a perfectly reasonable thing to do at the time. Don't look at me like that.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough *without* a baby on the way. It felt like everything was happening at once. Like, puberty 2.0, but with way more responsibility.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to pretend everything was normal. Which, obviously, it wasn't. I kept going to school, hanging out with Leah and Paul, listening to The Moldy Peaches…anything to distract myself.

But underneath it all, I was a mess. I was scared, confused, and really, really overwhelmed. I didn't know what I was doing. I didn't know how to be a mom. I didn't even know how to be a teenager anymore.

What really helped was having people I could talk to. Paul, obviously. He was…surprisingly awesome. And my dad. He was quiet about it, but he was always there for me. And Vanessa, even though she was kinda weird sometimes.

Talking to them, just being able to vent and be honest about how I was feeling, made a huge difference. It didn't make the problems go away, but it made them feel less…impossible.

I also found a weird kind of strength in just…accepting it. I couldn't change the situation, so I had to figure out how to deal with it. And that meant letting go of some of my expectations for my life. It meant growing up faster than I wanted to.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of awkward conversations, and a lot of moments where I just wanted to disappear. But I got through it. And I think, in a weird way, it made me a stronger person.

It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted out of life. And it taught me that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be scared. And it's okay to not have all the answers.

So yeah, that's how I coped. Mostly by pretending, talking, and just…taking it one day at a time. And listening to a lot of music. That always helped.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense. Like, really eager. It was kinda awkward, honestly.

He was trying *so* hard to be cool, you know? Like, he was listening to Death Cab for Cutie and pretending to understand my references. Which was sweet, I guess, but also kinda transparent. He was definitely trying to impress me. And Paul. Mostly Paul, I think.

He kept asking me about my life, my plans, what I wanted to do after graduation. Which, like, okay, that's a normal thing for a potential adoptive parent to ask. But he was asking it like he was interviewing me for a job. It felt…clinical.

And he was always trying to connect with me on a "teenager" level. He'd use slang he clearly didn't understand and try to talk about music he didn't actually like. It was painful.

Paul was way more chill. He just…talked to me like a person. He didn't try to be my friend or anything. He just wanted to know if I was okay.

Mark wasn't a bad guy, don't get me wrong. He was just…a little bit much. He was trying too hard. And it made me feel weird. Like I was being evaluated.

I think he just really wanted to be a dad. And he was probably nervous. But it was still awkward. Really awkward. I mostly just sat there and nodded and tried not to make eye contact.

It was a relief when the hangouts were over, honestly. Not because I didn't like him, but because I just needed a break from the…enthusiasm. It was exhausting.



It made me realize how important it was to find someone who was genuinely a good fit, not just someone who *wanted* to be a good parent. You know? It's complicated.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker. He's…well, he's Bleeker. Sweet, but spectacularly oblivious.

When he said something about me looking "fluffy"? It was…a lot. Like, I was already feeling incredibly self-conscious, right? My body was changing, and not in a way I'd planned for. And I was trying to be all cool and collected, pretending like everything was totally fine.

And then *he* says that. "Fluffy." Like I was a kitten or something. It wasn't malicious, I know that. He was just trying to be nice, in his own awkward, Bleeker-y way. But it just…highlighted everything I was trying to ignore.

I think I just stared at him for a second, trying to figure out if he was serious. And then I probably said something sarcastic, because that's what I do. Probably something about how I was cultivating a winter coat.

Inside, though? I was just…vulnerable. It was a reminder that everyone was noticing. That my life was changing. And that I was about to be a mom. Which was terrifying and amazing and everything in between.

It wasn't the comment itself that bothered me, it was what it *represented*. It was a crack in the facade. A little reminder that I couldn't pretend everything was normal anymore.

So yeah. It wasn't a great moment. But honestly, with Bleeker, you just kinda have to roll with it. He means well. He's just…not always the most perceptive guy.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're asking the hard questions now. It's not like I haven't thought about this a million times, but… talking about it is different.

The most challenging part? It wasn't the physical stuff, you know? It wasn't even the people judging me, though that was… annoying. It was the *knowing*. Knowing that I was making the right decision, logically, for everyone involved, but still feeling like a piece of me was being ripped away.

It's like… you spend nine months building this connection, this little person growing inside you. And then you have to consciously choose to let go. To let someone else raise them. To not be their mom.

And it's not like I didn't *want* to be a mom. It's just… I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give this baby the life it deserved.

But that didn't make it any easier. Every kick, every ultrasound, every little thing just made it harder to imagine handing them over.

And then there's the guilt. The constant, nagging guilt. Am I doing the right thing? Will they be happy? Will they ever wonder about me?

It's a weird kind of grief. It's not like losing someone who's already been a part of your life. It's losing someone you *never* got to know.

So yeah, the knowing. That was the hardest part. Knowing I was doing the right thing, but still feeling like my heart was breaking. It still kinda does, sometimes. But I try to focus on the fact that I gave this baby a chance at a good life. And that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. It was freezing, right? And he was standing there with this…sign. And he kept yelling about "tiny humans" and how babies are "gifts from God." It was super awkward.

He was all, "Every life is precious! You're taking a life!" And I just wanted to be like, "Dude, it's not that simple." But you can't really argue with someone who's already decided what they believe. It's just…exhausting.

He kept saying how a baby is a "miracle" and how I was "destroying a miracle." Which, okay, maybe it *is* a miracle, but it's *my* miracle to decide what to do with. And it's not like I wanted this to happen in the first place.

It was just…really intense. And honestly, it made me feel even more confused and conflicted about everything. Like, I already knew it was a hard decision, but he made it feel even harder.

He was just standing there, judging me. And it wasn't helpful. At all. It just made me want to yell back, but I didn't. Because that wouldn't have solved anything.

Honestly, the whole thing was just…a mess. And it made me really appreciate Paul and Mark for being supportive and not judging me. They actually listened to me, instead of just yelling about "babies."

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a lot. So, at the clinic, right? It was all sterile smells and awkward silences. I was mostly trying not to make eye contact with anyone. But then *she* came in.

It was this woman, Vanessa. She was…polished. Like, perfectly put together. Hair, makeup, clothes, the whole nine yards. And she was *very* pregnant. Like, about to pop. She sat down next to me in the waiting room, and just…started talking.

She didn't ask my name or anything. Just launched right into this whole speech about how she and her husband had been trying for years, and how they were so excited, and how it was the best thing that could ever happen. It was…intense.

She kept saying things like, "You just *know* when it's right," and "It changes your life in the most amazing way." And she kept looking at me, like she was trying to figure out if I was feeling the same way.

It was awful. Because I wasn't feeling amazing. I was feeling terrified and confused and completely overwhelmed. And she had no idea.

She finished her little speech with, "You're so lucky," and then smiled at me. *Lucky*. Like this was some kind of prize.

I just mumbled something about needing to use the bathroom and practically ran out of the room. It was…a really jarring experience. It just highlighted how different our situations were. She was celebrating, and I was…well, I was trying to figure out what to do with my life.

It made me realize that everyone has their own story, and you never really know what someone else is going through. And sometimes, people just say things without thinking about how they might affect others. It was just…ugh. It was a bad day.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Su-Chin. She's…intense. And she has opinions. About everything.

So, yeah, I mentioned Adderall. It just kinda slipped out, you know? We were talking about school and how everyone was, like, super focused and pulling all-nighters, and I just blurted out something about how some people were "chemically assisted." Real smooth, Juno. Real smooth.

Her face. Oh. My. God. It was like someone had just told her the world was flat. She went *completely* silent for a second, and then her eyes got all narrowed and she started lecturing me.

It wasn't even a lecture about the dangers of drugs, which I kinda expected. It was a lecture about…authenticity. About how people need to just *be* themselves and not rely on artificial stimulants to get through life. She was all, "It's about finding your inner drive, Juno! Not popping pills!"

It was so…Su-Chin. So judgmental and preachy. I tried to explain that I wasn't *taking* Adderall, I was just observing that some people were, but she wasn't really listening. She just kept going on and on about the importance of self-reliance.

Honestly, it was exhausting. I just wanted to change the subject, but she was on a roll. Eventually, she calmed down a little, but she definitely gave me the side-eye for the rest of the day.

It was a good reminder that Su-Chin is…a lot. And that sometimes, it's just easier to keep my mouth shut. Especially when it comes to sensitive topics.
