Ugh, okay, you want to know about the waiting room? Seriously? That place was a special kind of awful. It wasn't, like, jump-scare terrifying, it was…a slow burn of dread.

It was the magazines. That's what got me. Not the ones with the celebrities, those were just boring. It was the pregnancy magazines. All pastel colors and smiling couples and perfect little nurseries. Like, seriously? Like that's actually *real* life?

It felt…wrong. Like I was looking at a different universe. A universe where everything was planned and perfect and everyone was happy. And I was just sitting there, with my oversized hoodie and my questionable music taste, knowing that my situation was anything *but* perfect.

And then there was this one magazine with a cover that said "Choosing a Name!" and I almost threw up. Choosing a name? I hadn't even really thought about that yet! I was still trying to figure out how to tell my dad.

It just hit me, all at once, how huge this was. How much my life was about to change. And how completely unprepared I was. It wasn't a scary movie kind of terror, it was a…real life kind of terror. The kind that makes your stomach drop and your palms sweat.

It was like, everyone in that waiting room was living this perfect, pre-planned life, and I was just…a mess. And that was terrifying. It made me feel so small and alone.

So yeah, the magazines. Don't underestimate the power of a pastel-colored magazine to induce a full-blown existential crisis.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been…a while. Look, it's complicated, okay?

Do I still…*think* about him? Yeah, sometimes. He was a good guy. Sweet. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely good. And he understood me, in a way that a lot of people didn't. He didn't try to change me or anything. He just…accepted me, weirdness and all.

But "feelings"? That's a strong word. We were kids. Everything felt so intense back then. It was a first love kind of thing. And first loves are usually messy and confusing and…not always meant to last.

I think what I felt for him was more about needing someone to connect with, someone to share all the craziness with. And he was there. He was a good friend.

I've moved on, obviously. I have a life now. A real life. And I'm happy. But…yeah. There's a little part of me that always wonders what would have happened if things had been different. But that's just…life, I guess.

Don't read too much into it, okay? It's not like I'm pining away or anything. I just…remember him fondly. As a good memory. A slightly awkward, guitar-playing good memory.

Now, can we talk about something else? Like, maybe the existential dread of adulthood? That's a topic I'm much more qualified to discuss.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa's decorating choices. Don't even get me started. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not bad, exactly. It's just...not her. Or, like, not a normal person's.

She's going for this whole "whimsical woodland creature" vibe, which, fine. But it's not just a few cute stuffed animals. It's full-on murals of deer wearing tiny hats. And a mobile made of felt acorns. And wallpaper with foxes playing banjos. Banjos!

It's like she's trying to create a Disney movie set in a nursery. It's overwhelming. It's giving me anxiety just looking at it.

I mean, I appreciate the effort, I guess. She's really excited about this baby. But it's a little…intense. It's not exactly the vibe I was picturing for a little human. I was thinking more…neutral. Like, beige. Or gray. Maybe a tasteful print or two.

But no. We're getting a full-blown forest fantasy. 

I haven't said anything yet, because I don't want to hurt her feelings. She's already super sensitive about everything. But I'm seriously considering suggesting we tone it down a notch. Maybe replace the banjo-playing foxes with something a little less…enthusiastic.

Honestly, I'm just hoping the baby doesn't get nightmares. Or develop a sudden obsession with bluegrass music. It's gonna be a wild ride, that's for sure.

Ugh. Okay, so people keep asking me about "nesting." Like, suddenly I'm supposed to get all excited about tiny socks and pastel colors? It's…weird.

Honestly? It feels kinda surreal. Like, I'm supposed to be preparing for a tiny human to *live* here? It's a lot to process. I mean, I'm barely prepared to take care of myself, let alone a baby.

The whole baby room thing…it's overwhelming. Everyone's got opinions. My mom wants to paint it lavender and fill it with stuffed animals. Paul's mom wants everything to be organic and eco-friendly. It's like, can we just agree on a color that isn't aggressively cheerful?

I get *why* people do it, I guess. It's supposed to be comforting, right? Like, creating a safe and cozy space for the baby. But it also feels…performative. Like, you're supposed to be all giddy and excited about it. And I'm just…conflicted.

I'm trying to focus on the practical stuff. Like, making sure we have a car seat and a crib that doesn't fall apart. The decorating can come later. Maybe.

It's not that I don't care. It's just…I'm still figuring things out. I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, let alone who I'm going to be as a mom.

So, yeah. Nesting. It's a thing. And I'm trying to deal with it. But don't expect me to be pinning a bunch of nursery ideas on Pinterest anytime soon. That's just not my style.



It's kinda scary, actually. But also…a little bit exciting. Maybe. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on those women at the mall. Seriously. It was…a whole production. Like, they weren't just buying clothes, they were performing a lifestyle.

It was all perfectly coordinated outfits and tiny dogs in purses and this air of…superiority. Like, their credit cards were somehow better than everyone else's. And the sales associates were practically *worshipping* them. It was creepy.

They'd pick up a sweater, look at it for five seconds, then ask the sales associate for, like, seven different sizes and colors. And then not buy anything. Just…waste everyone's time.

And the way they talked about things! "Oh, this cashmere is *divine*." "This handbag is a *statement*." A statement of what? That you have too much money?

It just felt…empty. Like they were trying to fill a hole with stuff. And it made me feel kinda sad, actually. Not for them, necessarily, but for the whole situation. Like, there are people who are struggling to afford groceries, and these women are debating the merits of a $500 scarf.

It was a good reminder that money doesn't buy happiness. It just buys more stuff. And sometimes, that stuff just makes you look ridiculous.

Honestly, I'd rather spend my money on a good mix CD and a box of donuts. At least that's something real.



Don't get me wrong, I like nice things as much as the next person. But there's a difference between appreciating quality and just being…excessive. And those women were definitely excessive. It was a whole other level of…*muchness*.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. It's…a lot to process, even now. People keep asking me about it, like I have all the answers. I don't. I'm still figuring it out.

Honestly? It's terrifying. Like, monumentally terrifying. I was perfectly happy with my life before, you know? Music, movies, avoiding responsibility… it was good. And now… now there's a tiny human who's completely dependent on me. It's a huge weight.

The changes are…everything. My body is different, my priorities are different, my entire *life* is different. I used to be able to just do whatever I wanted, whenever I wanted. Now, everything revolves around this little person. It's exhausting, and sometimes I feel like I'm losing myself.

And the responsibilities? Don't even get me started. It's not just about feeding and changing diapers. It's about shaping a human being. It's about teaching them right from wrong, helping them navigate the world, and protecting them from all the bad stuff. That's…intense.

But… it's also kinda amazing. Like, really amazing. There are moments, you know? When she looks at me, or smiles, or just…exists… and it just fills me with this feeling I've never felt before. It's like, all the fear and exhaustion just melts away.

I'm still scared, though. Scared of messing it up. Scared of not being a good enough mom. But I'm trying. I'm learning. And I'm realizing that motherhood isn't about being perfect. It's about being present. It's about loving this little person with everything I have.

It's a whole new world, and it's scary and wonderful and overwhelming all at the same time. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even if it means I have to give up my vintage records. Okay, maybe *almost* anything.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about this, like it's some big mystery. It's not a mystery, it's just…thinking things through. It's not about finding the *perfect* parents, because that doesn't exist. It's about finding the right fit.

And for me, that's Mark and Vanessa Loring. They're…normal. Like, really normal. And that's what I want for the baby. I had a kinda chaotic childhood, you know? My dad bailed, my mom's…well, she's my mom. And it was okay, but it wasn't always stable.

Mark and Vanessa, they have a house with a yard and a dog and they talk about college funds and soccer practice. They seem…grounded. They want a family, and they're prepared to *be* a family. They're not looking for a project, they're looking for a kid.

I don't want the baby to be some weird art project for a couple who wants to prove something. I don't want it to be a charity case. I want it to be loved and supported and given every opportunity.

And honestly? They're just…nice. They're genuinely good people. And that's what matters most.

It's not about judging other people who want to adopt. It's about what *I* want for this baby. And I want it to have a life that's…safe and predictable and full of love. And I think Mark and Vanessa can give it that.

It's not easy, okay? It's the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But I'm trying to be selfless. And I think this is the right thing to do. Even if it breaks my heart a little.

Ugh. Okay, so if I decided to, like, *not* go through with the adoption plan? That's…a whole can of worms. It's not like it's a simple decision, you know? It's not just about wanting a baby, it's about being a *parent*. And that's…a lot.

First off, there's school. I'm a junior. I'm supposed to be thinking about colleges and stuff, not diapers and feeding schedules. How am I supposed to focus on my classes, on getting good grades, when I have a baby to take care of? It's not exactly conducive to studying.

Then there's money. My dad's a barber, and my stepmom's a real estate agent. They're good people, but they're not exactly rolling in dough. They've been super supportive about the adoption, but I don't want to be a burden. A baby is expensive. Like, ridiculously expensive.

And then there's…me. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm not exactly known for my responsible decision-making. I like music and vintage clothes and making sarcastic comments. I'm not exactly equipped to be a mom.

I'd have to rely on my parents a lot, and I don't want to mess up their lives. They've already been through a lot. And I don't want to miss out on my own life, either. I want to go to college, I want to travel, I want to…I don't know, *figure things out*.

And then there's the dad. Paulie. He's…sweet. But he's also sixteen. And he's not exactly ready to be a father, either. We're both just kids.

It's not that I don't think I could love the baby. I do. I already do. But love isn't enough. It takes a lot more than love to raise a child. It takes stability, and resources, and maturity. And right now, I don't have a lot of those things.

So yeah, there are a lot of concerns. A lot of obstacles. It's not a decision I take lightly. It's scary. Really scary. And that's why I think the adoption plan is the best thing for everyone involved. But still…it's hard.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She meant well, but she was *really* pushing it. When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she immediately went into this whole speech about how I could keep the baby and she and Mark would help. 

She suggested I move in with them. Like, *move in*. With her and Mark and their kids. She painted this picture of this big, happy, chaotic family, and how I could finish high school and raise the baby with their support. 

It was…a lot. It wasn't a suggestion, it was more of a plan she'd already made in her head. She kept saying how "natural" it would be and how I'd be a great mom. 

Honestly, it freaked me out. I mean, I love Leah, but living with them? That's a whole other level of commitment. And it wasn't what *I* wanted. It felt like she was trying to fix things for me instead of letting me make my own decision.

It was a really awkward conversation. I had to be pretty firm with her and explain that I'd already thought it through and adoption was the right choice for me. She eventually backed off, but it was definitely a tense moment. She just wanted what she thought was best, you know? But sometimes, what's best for someone else isn't what's best for *you*.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…not my finest moment. And I get why people would be, like, rightfully annoyed with me about it. It was stupid. And mean. And honestly, I was just trying to deflect.

It was a really weird day, okay? I was already freaking out about, you know, *everything*. And then I ended up at that play area with Mark and his mom, and it was just…so aggressively cheerful. Like, a saccharine explosion. And those women were just…really into it. Like, *really* into the whole mommy-and-me thing.

And I was feeling super awkward and out of place, and I just blurted out that comment about them being “so into it.” It was a defense mechanism. I was trying to make myself feel better by making them feel…less good, I guess? Which is awful. I know.

I wasn't trying to be genuinely hurtful. I just…I have a hard time expressing my feelings, okay? I tend to use sarcasm and humor as a shield. It's a bad habit. I'm working on it.

I felt really bad about it afterwards. Mark called me out on it, which was good. He's a pretty decent guy, even if he is a little clueless sometimes.

So yeah. I made fun of them. It was wrong. I regret it. And I promise to try and be less of a jerk in the future. It's a process.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was…complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying.

Look, Vanessa was being…Vanessa. All intense and wanting to *connect* with the baby. And I was, like, super awkward and didn't know what to do. She was already kinda freaking me out with the whole "birth doula" thing, and then she just…reached for my stomach.

It wasn't like I *allowed* it, exactly. I was caught off guard. I froze. And she just…did it. It was quick. And weird. And I definitely wanted to punch her in the face afterwards.

But it wasn't about the touching, really. It was about her overstepping. About her thinking she knew what was best for me and the baby. About her being so…*much*.

I was already dealing with a lot. Paul, my dad, the whole adoption thing…I didn't need someone else trying to control the situation.

So, yeah, I didn't exactly stop her. I should have. But I was overwhelmed. And honestly, I was just trying to get through the day without completely losing it.

It was a mistake. And I definitely told her to back off after that. But it's one of those things that just…happened. And it still makes me cringe when I think about it.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a weird situation. And I was a weird, pregnant teenager. It's not like I had a handbook for dealing with overly enthusiastic birth doulas.

Ugh, seriously? It's like, people suddenly develop a sense of spatial awareness when I waddle by. It's…weird. And kinda insulting, honestly. Like, I'm a walking obstacle course or something.

It started a few weeks ago, after I started *really* showing. Before that, it was just the occasional awkward glance. Now? People practically dive out of my way. They widen their eyes, they veer off course, they clutch their purses tighter. It's like I'm carrying a biohazard or something.

I think they're just…uncomfortable. They don't know what to do with a visibly pregnant person. It reminds them of, like, life and responsibility and all that stuff. And they'd rather just avoid it.

Or maybe they're worried I'm gonna pop. Which, rude.

Paul thinks it's because I'm radiating "don't mess with me" vibes. Which, okay, maybe. I *am* pretty protective of this kid. And I'm not afraid to give someone a side-eye if they get too close.

But mostly, I think it's just people being weird. They're awkward around anything that deviates from the norm. And a giant belly definitely qualifies.

It's annoying, but also…a little bit empowering. Like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. Deal with it."

But seriously, if you see me coming, just act normal. I don't bite. Unless you try to steal my mozzarella sticks. Then all bets are off.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa. The "wholesome" couple. Yeah, right. They're…perfect. Too perfect. And that's exactly why it freaks me out a little.

It's not that I don't think they'd be good parents. They totally would. They have the house, the careers, the matching sweaters…they've got it all figured out. But that's the problem! They have a *plan*. And my baby isn't a project to complete a plan.

I mean, they're nice, sure. But they're kinda…distant. Like, they talk *about* having a family, but they don't really *feel* like a family, you know? It's all very…organized. And I'm not organized. My life is a mess. And I want my kid to be loved, unconditionally, even when they're being a total disaster.

With Paul and Vanessa, it feels like the baby has to *fit* into their life. With Mark and Vanessa, it feels like the baby has to *be* their life. And that's a lot of pressure.

I want someone who's gonna let the kid be weird and messy and make mistakes. Someone who's gonna laugh when they spill spaghetti on their face. Someone who's gonna love them even when they're being a total pain in the butt.

Mark and Vanessa seem like they'd want a perfect baby. And there's no such thing as a perfect baby. Or a perfect anything, really.

It's not that they're bad people. They're just…not *my* people. And my baby deserves to be with people who get it. People who understand that life is messy and unpredictable and beautiful, even when it's falling apart.

So yeah, I'm hesitant. Because this isn't about finding the "best" parents. It's about finding the *right* parents. And I'm still trying to figure out who that is.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot. Like, a whole *lot*.

Look, they're nice people, I guess. Vanessa tries really hard, and Mark's…well, Mark's Mark. He means well, but he's kinda clueless. It's like they're living in a rom-com, and I'm just the cynical bystander.

It's just…they're so *perfect*. You know? Like, sickeningly perfect. They have the perfect house, the perfect jobs, the perfect relationship. It makes me feel like I'm failing at life just by existing near them.

And they're always trying to give me advice. Like I need their help. "Oh, Juno, you should really think about your future." Or, "Vanessa thinks you should consider college." Like, thanks, Vanessa. I hadn't thought of that.

I appreciate that they care, I really do. And I'm glad they're there for Paul. He needs people like that in his life. But sometimes I just want to scream, "Get a grip, people! Life isn't a Hallmark movie!"

They're good people, but they're just…intense. And a little bit exhausting. Honestly, I mostly just try to avoid them. It's easier that way.

Don't tell them I said that. They'd probably try to set me up with their nephew. And that would be a disaster. A total disaster.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still bringing that up? It's been, like, years. But fine, I'll explain. It's not like I *enjoy* reliving the awkwardness.

Mrs. Mancini, she's…intense. And she has very specific ideas about who Bleeker should be with. Basically, she thinks he deserves someone "more stable." Which, okay, fair enough. I was a sixteen-year-old pregnant girl. Not exactly a picture of stability.

She also thought I was a bad influence on him. Like, I was gonna drag him down with me or something. She kept making these little comments about how I wasn't "ambitious" enough, or that I didn't have a "plan" for my future. Which, hello? I was dealing with a *baby*. A plan felt kinda far off at the time.

And honestly, I think she just didn't understand me. I'm not exactly…conventional. I say what's on my mind, I don't really care what people think, and I have a pretty sarcastic sense of humor. She's more of a traditional, "everything has to be perfect" kind of person.

It wasn't that she didn't like *me* exactly. She just didn't think I was good enough for her precious Bleeker. It was a whole thing. A really annoying thing.

Eventually, she came around a little bit. After the baby was born and she saw that I actually cared about him and was trying to do the right thing. But it took a while. And a lot of awkward family dinners.

Honestly, it was just a classic case of a mother not wanting her son to mess up his life with someone like me. Which, you know, fair. But also kinda rude.

Ugh, okay, so the Mark CD. Right. That whole thing was…complicated. It wasn't like I was *eager* to listen to it, okay? It wasn't like I was sitting around, all hearts and flowers, waiting for a mixtape.

It was mostly because Paul…Paul was kinda pushing it. He was all, "You should listen to it, Juno. It'll give you insight into his soul." Which, honestly, is a really creepy thing to say. But Paul meant well. He always tries to see the good in people.

And I was…confused. About Mark, about everything. I needed to figure out what he was thinking, what he wanted. And the CD was, like, a direct line to his brain. A really cheesy, indie-rock-filled direct line, but still.

Plus, I was bored. I was sitting in my room, avoiding my dad and trying not to think about the baby, and the CD was just…there. It was a distraction. A way to fill the silence.

So I put it on. And it wasn't terrible. Actually, it was kinda good. It was…thoughtful. He clearly put a lot of effort into it. And it made me realize that he wasn't just some clueless guy who got me pregnant. He was…a person. A flawed, awkward, but ultimately decent person.

It didn't make me fall in love with him or anything. But it made me understand him a little better. And that was enough, I guess. It was a step towards figuring things out.

It was a stupid CD, but it ended up being…important. Don't tell him I said that. He'd get a big head.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Eight months. It's…a lot. It's like, I went from complaining about my thighs to having a fully-formed human doing gymnastics inside me. It's weird.

It's mostly just uncomfortable, honestly. Everything is swollen. My feet look like balloons. I can't bend over without sounding like a walrus. And the heartburn? Don't even get me started. It's a constant battle with Tums.

But it's also…kind of amazing. Like, I can feel him move now. Real kicks and punches. It's freaky, but also kinda cool. It's a reminder that there's a tiny person in there, and I'm responsible for him. Which is terrifying, but also…good.

I still have moments where I'm like, "What have I done?" But then I feel a kick, and I'm like, "Okay, maybe this isn't so bad."

Paul's being…Paul. Supportive, but also kinda clueless. He keeps trying to rub my back, which is nice, but he doesn't understand that you're not supposed to rub a pregnant lady's back. It's a whole thing.

And Annie? She's been a lifesaver. She's the one who actually knows what's going on and tells me what to expect. She's basically my pregnancy guru.

So yeah, eight months. It's exhausting, uncomfortable, and a little bit scary. But it's also…real. And I guess that's what matters. It's happening. And I'm trying to be okay with that.

Don't tell anyone I said that. I still have to maintain my cool, sarcastic exterior. It's a defense mechanism.

Ugh, seriously? You noticed it too? It's *always* happening. Like, I'm just trying to walk down the street, minding my own business, and people are just…staring. It's super annoying.

I think it's a couple of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in, okay? I have opinions. I say what I think. I don't really do the whole "fitting in" thing. And I guess that's noticeable.

And then, yeah, there's the whole…situation. You know. The baby. People are probably trying to figure it out. Like, "Is that the girl who got pregnant?" It's rude, but it happens.

I also think people are just…weird. They stare at everything. Maybe they're just bored. Maybe they're judging my shoes. I don't know. I try not to think about it too much.

It's just…I wish people would stop looking at me like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo. I'm just a person. A person who happens to be dealing with a lot of stuff.

So yeah, that's my theory. People stare because I'm different, and because they're nosy. And honestly? I'm over it. I just try to ignore them. It's not always easy, but it's better than letting them get to me.

It's like, if you're gonna stare, at least have something interesting to look at. Like a really good pair of boots. Or a witty t-shirt. But just staring? That's just rude.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A really weird choice.

Look, Bleek is Bleek. He's sweet, I guess. And he's got that whole quiet, artistic thing going on. But Katrina De Voort? She's…intense. Like, aggressively cheerful. It's kinda terrifying.

I mean, good for him if he's into that. I'm not judging. Okay, maybe a little. It just feels…off. Like a penguin trying to hang out with a flamingo. They're both birds, but still.

I can see why he'd want to go to prom with someone. It's a big deal. But I just don't see them having a lot in common. He's all about his fantasy stuff and she's…well, she's Katrina. She's into everything.

It's probably gonna be awkward. Really awkward. Lots of forced conversation and uncomfortable silences. And she's probably gonna try to get him to do some super embarrassing couple's activity.

Honestly, I just hope he doesn't get completely steamrolled. He's a good kid. He deserves someone who appreciates his weirdness, not someone who tries to change it.

But hey, maybe I'm wrong. Maybe they'll have a blast. Maybe they'll discover a hidden connection. Who knows? Life is full of surprises. Mostly bad ones, if you ask me.

Just…don't ask me to be a chaperone. I have better things to do. Like, avoiding my own life.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. It's…a lot. Honestly, before all this happened, I thought I had things pretty figured out. Like, I knew who I was. Sarcastic, independent, liked records and vintage clothes, didn't really care what people thought. Turns out, I was mostly just avoiding thinking about anything too serious.

This whole pregnancy thing? It's forced me to actually *think*. And feel. A lot.

I learned I'm way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I'm 16, and I'm growing a human. That's kinda insane when you actually stop and think about it. I used to think I couldn't even handle a pop quiz, let alone a baby.

I also learned that I'm not as tough as I pretend to be. I put up a good front, you know? The whole snarky, detached thing. But underneath it all, I'm actually pretty scared. And vulnerable. And I need people. Which is…weird. I always thought I was good on my own.

I learned that my parents, as annoying as they are sometimes, actually love me. And they're trying their best. I used to roll my eyes at everything they said, but now I realize they're just worried about me. And they're actually pretty cool, when they're not being overprotective.

And I learned that making a big decision isn't about finding the "right" answer, because there isn't one. It's about choosing the best option for everyone involved, even if it's hard. And it's about being brave enough to live with the consequences.

I guess…I learned that I'm not just a kid anymore. I'm becoming a woman. And that's kinda terrifying. But also… kinda good. I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm starting to feel like maybe, just maybe, I can handle whatever life throws at me. Even if it involves tiny humans and a whole lot of responsibility.

It's still weird, though. Really weird.

Ugh, okay, seriously? It's just… frustrating, alright? It's like, Katrina is a genuinely sweet person. A little…intense, maybe, but she's got a good heart. And Bleeker is just…bleeker. He's sweet, don't get me wrong, but he's also kinda clueless. And he's leading her on!

It's not about *him* being a bad guy, it's about him not being honest with her. He's clearly not into her in *that* way, but he's letting her think he is. He's enjoying the attention, and that's just… not cool.

I've been through enough emotional stuff lately to know how much it sucks to have your feelings messed with. I get it. It's awful. And Katrina doesn't deserve that. She deserves someone who appreciates her for who she is, not someone who just wants a friend with benefits or whatever he's thinking.

Plus, it's just… awkward. Watching it happen. It's like watching a train wreck in slow motion. And I just want to yell at him to be honest, but that's not my place, you know?

It's just… ugh. People are complicated. And sometimes, they're just really inconsiderate. And it makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they fall out of my head.

It's not my problem, technically. But I can't just sit back and watch someone get hurt, even if they're kinda weird. It's just… not right.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so like, when you're a freshman, sophomore, it seems…okay. It's something to look forward to, right? Picking out a dress, maybe going with a cute guy. It's all very…movie-like.

But then you actually get to be a senior. And suddenly, it's just…weird. It's like everyone's trying *so hard* to have this perfect, magical night, and it just feels…forced.

It's all about appearances, you know? Everyone's worried about who's going with who, who has the best dress, who's going to be crowned prom king and queen. It's like high school distilled into one really expensive, sparkly night.

And honestly, by senior year, most people are just over it. They're thinking about college, or jobs, or just getting out of this town. Prom feels…small. Like, why are we spending all this money and energy on something that's not going to matter in a few months?

It's also kinda sad, when you think about it. It's like everyone's trying to hold onto this moment, knowing it's the last time they'll all be together. It's a little bit desperate.

I mean, don't get me wrong, if you want to go to prom, go to prom. But don't feel like you *have* to. It's not the be-all and end-all. There are way more important things in life than a dance.

It's just…once you're old enough to go, you realize it's not as cool as the movies make it out to be. It's just…prom. And sometimes, that's enough. But sometimes, it's just not.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. But you asked.

It wasn’t like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn’t like I woke up one morning and was all, “Yep, giving the baby away!” It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just…freaking out. Like, majorly. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I could barely keep my own life together, how was I supposed to keep another human alive?

And then there was the whole…Paul thing. He was a good guy, but he was also…not ready. Neither of us were. We were kids. We were still figuring things out.

My mom was amazing, though. She didn’t freak out. She just…listened. And she helped me think through everything. She kept saying, “You have options, Juno. You have choices.”

And that’s what it came down to, really. Choices. I could try to raise the baby myself, but that would mean giving up a lot of my dreams. College, travel, just…being a kid. And I didn’t want to bring a baby into a situation where I couldn’t give it everything it needed.

So, I started looking into adoption. And it felt…right. It felt like the best thing for the baby. To give it a life with parents who were ready and able to provide everything it needed. A stable home, financial security, a loving family.

It wasn’t easy. Finding Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were so kind and genuine. But saying goodbye…that was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. It felt like giving away a piece of myself.

But I knew it was the right thing. I knew that the baby – Henry – would be loved and cared for. And that’s all that really mattered.

It wasn’t about me not wanting a baby. It was about wanting Henry to have the best possible life. And sometimes, the best possible life isn’t with your biological mother.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I don’t regret my decision. I really don’t. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done, but it was also the most selfless. And I think…I think that’s okay.



It's complicated. It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so Dad being Dad. It's…complicated. Like, I get it, he's worried. He always worries. It's his thing. But honestly, the whole "getting ripped off" thing felt kinda insulting. Like, I'm not an idiot. And Mark and Vanessa aren't villains in a movie.

It's not like I'm selling a used car here. I'm giving a baby a life. A good life. And they seemed genuinely excited and…nice. Like, actually nice. Not "nice" in a creepy, Stepford Wives kind of way.

But Dad, he's all about protecting me. Which is sweet, I guess. But it felt like he didn't trust my judgment. Like he thought I'd just pick the first couple who offered me a free lifetime supply of pizza or something.

And it's not about the money, okay? It's about finding someone who will love this kid and give them everything they need. And Mark and Vanessa seemed like they could do that.

I told him, "Dad, I'm not stupid. I'm not just handing my baby over to anyone." But he still had this look on his face, like he was waiting for the other shoe to drop.

It just made me feel…responsible. Like I had to prove to him that I was making the right decision. And that's a lot of pressure, you know? Especially when you're already dealing with, like, everything else.

So yeah, I appreciate his concern, I really do. But sometimes, he just needs to chill. I can handle this. I'm not a little kid anymore. I'm making a grown-up decision, and I'm doing it for the right reasons. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Seriously? *That's* what he goes with? After everything? It's just…classic Dad. Always with the subtle digs disguised as "concern."

It's like, okay, yeah, maybe I do have a tendency to, like, overshare or get myself into situations. But who doesn't when they're seventeen and figuring things out? And especially when their life has been turned upside down?

He thinks it's about the pregnancy, doesn't he? He thinks I'm being reckless or irresponsible. But it's not just about that. It's about everything. It's about me trying to be a person, trying to figure out who I am, and him always trying to control the narrative.

"Not knowing when to say when." It's so condescending. Like I'm a little kid who doesn't understand boundaries. I'm making a huge decision, a really difficult one, and I'm doing it with a lot more thought and maturity than he gives me credit for.

Honestly, it just makes me want to dig my heels in even further. It makes me want to prove him wrong. It makes me want to do exactly what I want to do, just to spite him.

But then I remember that he's just…scared. He's scared for me, and he doesn't know how to deal with it. He's not good with feelings. So he resorts to passive-aggressive comments.

It still stings, though. It always does. It's just…ugh. My dad. He's a good guy, deep down. He just has a really weird way of showing it.

I probably just rolled my eyes and mumbled something sarcastic under my breath. That's usually my go-to response. It's easier than actually having a conversation with him.

Ugh, Loring. Seriously? That place is…a lot. It's like Stepford Wives meets a golf course. All perfectly manicured lawns and people pretending everything is perfect. It's aggressively…pleasant. And that's what makes it creepy.

It's not that I have anything against people having money, okay? It's just…the *show* of it. The gates, the security guards, the matching houses…it's like they're trying to build a bubble around themselves and pretend the rest of the world doesn't exist.

And the people! They're all so…concerned. Concerned about property values, concerned about appearances, concerned about what everyone else is doing. It's exhausting just being around them. They're always asking how things are going with the baby, and it's not like they actually *care*, you know? It's more like they're checking to make sure I'm still "appropriate" for their community.

It feels…artificial. Like everything is fake and carefully constructed. It's the opposite of real life. And I'm not really into fake.

Paul's parents seem happy there, I guess. They like the safety and the quiet. But it's just not my vibe. I need a little bit of chaos, a little bit of grit. I need to be around people who are actually, you know, *real*.

It's a nice place, objectively. But it's just…not me. It feels like I'd suffocate in there. Like I'd lose myself trying to fit in. And I'm already trying to figure out who I am, I don't need to add "perfect Loring resident" to the list.

So yeah. Loring. It's…fine. Just not for me.

Ugh, Vanessa Loring. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, *really* put together. Always perfectly accessorized, always knowing exactly what to say. It was kinda intimidating, honestly. I'm used to people who are a little more…messy. Like me.

She seemed really serious about the whole adoption thing, which was good, I guess. But also a little…clinical? Like she was picking out a new sofa instead of a baby. Not that she didn't seem nice, just…polished.

And she and Mark were, like, *perfect*. You know? The perfect couple, the perfect house, the perfect life. It made me feel even more awkward and…unprepared. Like I was crashing their perfectly curated world.

I think I was mostly just suspicious. I mean, nobody is *that* perfect, right? I kept waiting for the other shoe to drop. I figured there had to be some hidden agenda, some secret reason why they were so eager to adopt.

It took me a while to realize she was just…nervous. And trying to control everything because she was scared. But yeah, initial impressions? Polished, intense, and a little bit scary. Definitely not what I expected. It was like meeting a Stepford wife, but, like, a really nice Stepford wife.

Ugh. Okay, so Bleeker offering to carry my backpack? That was…a moment. A weird moment.

Honestly? It was kinda sweet. I mean, Bleeker is…Bleeker. He's not exactly known for his physical prowess, okay? He's more of a quiet, music-obsessed kind of guy. So the fact that he even *offered* to carry something heavy was surprising.

At first, I was just suspicious. Like, what's the angle? Is he trying to get something out of me? Is this some elaborate attempt to prove he's not a total dork? Because, let's be real, he's a dork. A lovable dork, but still.

But then I looked at his face, and he was just…being nice. Like, genuinely trying to help. And my backpack *was* ridiculously heavy. Full of textbooks and, like, my entire emotional baggage.

So I let him. And it was…nice. It was a small gesture, but it felt…significant. It was like he was saying, "Hey, I see you. I see you're struggling. And I want to help."

It didn't suddenly make me fall madly in love with him or anything. But it definitely made me see him in a different light. It made me realize that he was a good person, even if he was a little bit awkward.

And honestly, it was a relief to not have to carry that stupid backpack for another minute. So yeah, I appreciated it. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about that comic? It's kinda embarrassing to even *think* about, let alone talk about. But fine. I'll explain.

It wasn't about the comic being, like, objectively *good*. It was…the honesty of it. Yuki, she wasn't trying to be cool or popular or anything. She was just…herself. And she was okay with that. She was drawing these super personal, kinda weird comics about her life, and she didn't care what anyone thought.

And I realized…I was spending so much time worrying about what other people thought of *me*. About being a "fat dork," as you so eloquently put it. About fitting in. About being normal. And it was exhausting.

Yuki just…didn't seem to care. She was just creating. And it was freeing. It made me realize that maybe I didn't *need* to be normal. Maybe it was okay to be weird. Maybe it was okay to be me.

It wasn't like, suddenly I wasn't self-conscious anymore. But it was a little crack in the wall of insecurity. A little reminder that it's okay to be different. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just be yourself, even if that self is a little bit dorky.

It was a weird epiphany, okay? Don't judge. It's not like I went out and started drawing comics or anything. But it definitely made me feel…less like a dork. And more like…Juno. Which, I guess, is a good thing.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. Mark. He's…a lot. And honestly, the whole superhero comparison was just…weird.

But, okay, if I *have* to analyze it, which is what I do, right? Overthink everything. I guess he meant it as a compliment? Like, the comic book character, she was, like, unexpectedly powerful, right? And she was dealing with a huge responsibility, even though she wasn't looking for it.

And yeah, I guess that's kinda me. I wasn't planning on being pregnant. It was…a surprise. A big one. And now I have to figure out what to do with it. It's not exactly saving the world, but it feels pretty important.

He probably thought it was a cute way to say I was strong. Which is…fine. I guess. But it also felt kinda dismissive, you know? Like he was reducing my whole situation to a comic book trope. Like he didn't really *get* it.

And honestly, I'm not a superhero. I'm just a regular girl who made a mistake. A big, life-altering mistake. And I'm trying to do the right thing. That doesn't make me superpowered. It just makes me…responsible.

So yeah, he compared me to a pregnant superhero. It was awkward. And kinda sweet. And mostly just…Mark being Mark. He means well, I guess. He just doesn't always think things through.

Ugh. I need a burger.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And kinda raw, honestly. People keep asking me about adoption, like it's some kinda easy decision. It's not. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to think about.

So, open adoption. Yeah. I get the idea. Keeping a connection, letting the kid know where they came from, all that. It sounds…nice. In theory. But for me? It just felt…messy. Like, a constant reminder of everything I couldn't give this kid.

See, I already feel like a screw-up. I'm sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I'm not exactly equipped to co-parent with someone, especially not someone I barely know. It's not about the birth parents being bad people, it's about *me*. I need to be able to move on, to build a life, without constantly wondering what's going on with this kid.

I need closure. I need to know that I did the best thing for them, and then I need to be able to let go. An open adoption just feels like…never really letting go. Like a permanent tether.

And honestly? It feels kinda selfish. Like the birth parents are getting to keep a piece of the kid, even after they've given them up. I want this kid to have a family that's completely and totally theirs, without any lingering connections to their birth mom.

I know people say it's better for the kid to know their history, and maybe it is. But I also think it's important for the kid to have a sense of stability and belonging. And I just didn't think an open adoption could provide that.

So, yeah. I prefer a traditional, closed adoption. It's not perfect. It's heartbreaking. But it feels like the cleanest break. It feels like the best way to give this kid a chance at a normal life.

It's not a judgment on anyone else's choices. It's just what I need. It's what I can handle. And honestly? It's what feels right for me. It's just…really hard to explain. It's a lot of feelings, all tangled up.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it a million times.

Honestly, before all this pregnancy stuff happened, I was just… coasting. I was good at being sarcastic, good at avoiding things, good at just generally being…invisible. I didn't really *think* about who I was, or what I wanted. I just kinda existed.

But then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, I had to make a decision. A really big decision. And it wasn't about what my parents wanted, or what Paul wanted, or what anyone else thought. It was about what *I* wanted.

And that was terrifying.

But going through it, talking to Vanessa and Mark, and even dealing with Paul's…well, Paul-ness…it forced me to actually look inside myself. I realized I wasn't just some cynical teenager. I was capable of making a really selfless decision, even if it was hard.

Choosing adoption wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby the best life possible. And that took strength. A different kind of strength than I thought I had.

And then, just…growing up. Dealing with the awkwardness, the judgment, the responsibility…it all chipped away at the layers of sarcasm and cynicism. I started to see things more clearly. I started to understand that it's okay to be vulnerable, it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have all the answers.

I think, by the end of it, I realized that my identity wasn't something I had to *find*. It was something I was *creating*. It was about the choices I made, the people I cared about, and the kind of person I wanted to be.

It wasn't about being cool or popular or fitting in. It was about being…me. And that's a pretty good feeling. Even if it's still a work in progress.

So yeah, the whole pregnancy thing was a mess. But it also kinda…saved me. It forced me to grow up, to face my fears, and to find my own voice. And that's something I'll always be grateful for. Even if I still roll my eyes a lot.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that*? It's been, like, forever. But fine. I guess it's a good story.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes. Yeah, I know, super cliché. But it just…fit. It was kinda dorky and sweet and a little bit sad, which, honestly, was pretty much my whole vibe at the time.

Mark picked it. He said it reminded him of me. Which, I guess, was a compliment? I don't know. He was always good at saying the right things.

The dance itself was…awkward. I'm not a graceful dancer, okay? And Mark wasn't exactly Fred Astaire. We mostly just kinda swayed and tried not to step on each other's feet. But it was okay. It was…nice.

It's funny, thinking about it now. All that drama with Paulie Bleeker and the baby and everything, and there I was, slow dancing with Mark at his senior prom to a song about new beginnings. Life is weird.

Don't tell anyone I said it was nice, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be sarcastic and cynical, not all mushy and sentimental. But yeah. "First Day of My Life." That was the song.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People keep asking me about that. It's not like I *wanted* Mark and Vanessa to stay together, okay? It wasn't about them. It was about the baby.

Look, Mark was a good guy. A really good guy. And he was totally willing to step up and raise the baby himself. But he was…a mess. He was still figuring things out, still kinda lost. And honestly, he wasn't ready for the responsibility of raising a kid on his own. He needed support.

Vanessa, she wasn't perfect, obviously. She was kinda uptight and…well, Vanessa. But she was stable. She had a good life, a good home, and she was genuinely excited about the idea of being a mom. She could give the baby everything it needed.

And Mark knew that. He knew he couldn't give the baby that on his own. He loved me, yeah, but he loved that baby more. And he knew what was best for it.

It wasn't about saving their marriage. It was about giving that baby the best possible life. And that meant keeping the family together, even if it wasn't the family I originally imagined.

It was a hard decision, okay? It wasn't easy. But it was the right one. And I had to trust that. I had to trust that they could give that baby a better life than I could. And I had to trust that Mark would be a good dad, even if he wasn't raising the baby on his own.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And sometimes, that means making sacrifices. Even if it breaks your heart a little.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. It still kinda stings, honestly. Even now.

It wasn't like...shocking, exactly. I mean, he was Mark. He was, like, permanently stuck in arrested development. But it was still…a punch to the gut. I'd spent so much time trying to figure out what *I* wanted, and I thought, maybe, just maybe, he wanted something similar. A family, or at least, a plan.

It wasn't about him not loving me, I knew that. It was about him not being able to handle responsibility. Which, fine. Whatever. But it made me feel…small. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like this whole thing was just about him and his band and his life, and I was just…an obstacle.

I tried to be cool about it, you know? Sarcastic. Dismissive. Like it didn't bother me. But inside, I was a mess. I was already dealing with everything else – the pregnancy, the adoption, my parents – and then to have him just…bail? It was a lot.

It made me realize I didn't need him. I didn't need a boyfriend who couldn't step up. I needed someone who was supportive and reliable, and he clearly wasn't that person.

It sucked, though. It really did. It would have been nice to have someone to share it with. But I figured it out. I always do. And honestly? I think I'm better off without him. He's a good guy, but he's just…not ready. And that's okay. I guess.

Don't look at me like that. It's fine. I'm fine. I just…needed to get that off my chest. It's been a while.

Ugh, okay, so Mark. Yeah. That was…something. People always ask about that. Like it was some big mystery why I didn't just run screaming in the other direction.

Honestly? It was a relief. Everyone else at school was so…predictable. All the drama and the cliques and the trying-too-hard. Mark wasn't any of that. He was just…Mark. Quiet, a little awkward, obsessed with music and superheroes. He didn't care what people thought of him, and that was kinda refreshing.

He didn't try to impress me or anything. He just…was. And he listened. Like, *really* listened. Not just waiting for his turn to talk. He actually seemed interested in what I had to say, even when I was being sarcastic or cynical. Which, let's be real, is most of the time.

And yeah, his life was weird. The whole Bleeker thing, the band practice in the garage, the general air of artistic chaos…it was different. But it was a good different. It was real. It wasn't fake or manufactured.

I think I liked that he saw me, you know? Not just the pregnant teenager, but…me. The girl who liked music and movies and making sarcastic comments. He didn't judge me for my situation. He just accepted me for who I was.

Plus, he was funny. In a quiet, understated way. And he made me laugh. A lot. And when you're dealing with something as huge and scary as being pregnant, you need all the laughter you can get.

So yeah, I liked being a part of his weird life. It was a good distraction. It was a safe space. And he was a good friend. A really good friend. Even if he did have questionable taste in music sometimes. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh. Okay, Mark. That's…complicated. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a little bit of a man-child. But becoming a dad? That's a whole other level of cluelessness, I think.

Honestly? I bet he's mostly terrified. Like, genuinely, pants-wettingly scared. He's still figuring out how to be a functional adult, and now someone's handing him a tiny human being that depends on him for *everything*? Yeah, no.

I think he's trying to be supportive, you know? He's saying all the right things, offering to help, pretending he's not completely overwhelmed. But underneath all that, I bet he's having a full-blown panic attack every time he thinks about it.

He probably pictures himself dropping the baby, or forgetting to feed it, or accidentally teaching it to say something really inappropriate. He's a worrier, that one.

But…he also wants to do the right thing. He's a good person, and he genuinely cares about me. I think he's trying to wrap his head around the idea that this isn't just about me anymore. It's about creating a good life for this kid, even if he's not raising it himself.

He's probably also secretly hoping I'll change my mind, but he's too polite to say anything. He's just…processing. And probably Googling "how to change a diaper" a lot.

It's gonna be a learning experience for both of us, that's for sure. And I have a feeling it's gonna be a really messy one. But I think, deep down, he'll step up. He's Mark. He's a little bit of a goofball, but he's got a good heart. And that's what matters, right?

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a *moment*, alright? A moment of weakness. A moment of…teenage angst.

Look, it wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about…everything. Paul and I were having a really awkward conversation, okay? About, like, feelings and responsibility and the whole baby situation. It was a lot. And I was feeling super overwhelmed and vulnerable.

And then I went into Loring's bathroom, and there it was. That perfume. It smelled…expensive. And sophisticated. And everything I wasn't feeling at that moment. It was like a little symbol of everything I was missing out on.

I know, it was stupid. It was impulsive. It was totally wrong. But in that moment, it felt like…taking something for myself. Like reclaiming a little bit of control. Like saying, "I deserve something nice, even if I'm a mess."

It wasn't about wanting to *keep* the perfume. It was about the act of taking it. It was a stupid, reckless, teenage thing to do. And I totally regretted it afterwards.

Honestly, it was a really dumb move. And I'm glad I eventually returned it. But yeah, that's the story. It wasn't about the scent, it was about the feeling. And the feeling was…complicated.

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? I was going through a lot.

Ugh, okay, seriously? That whole Mark and Vanessa situation is a mess. It's like, a slow-motion train wreck you can't look away from. And honestly? It's kinda sad.

I've been observing them, you know? From a distance, obviously. I'm not *trying* to eavesdrop, but it's hard not to when they're yelling in the kitchen.

I think…I think Mark just wants something *different*. Vanessa is…intense. She has a very specific vision for her life, and she expects everyone to fit into it. And Mark? He's just…chill. He likes things easy. He likes to go with the flow.

It's like she's constantly trying to *fix* him, you know? Like he's a project. And he just wants to be accepted for who he is. He wants someone who'll watch a bad movie with him and eat pizza without judging.

And she's always talking about appearances. The house, the garden, the perfect family image. It's exhausting just listening to her. I think Mark just got tired of trying to live up to her expectations.

He's not a bad guy, Mark. He's just…lost. And I think he's realized that he and Vanessa are just fundamentally different people. They want different things. And sometimes, even if you love someone, that's just not enough.

It's a bummer, though. It really is. Divorce is never easy. But I think, for Mark, it's about finding someone who lets him breathe. Someone who doesn't try to change him. Someone who just…gets him.

It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, people just grow apart. It doesn't mean anyone's a villain. It just means they're not right for each other anymore.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff, huh? Fine. Look, it wasn't about *Vanessa* exactly. It was about…everything.

She was being nice, which is always suspicious. And she was asking what was wrong like she actually cared, which, no offense to Vanessa, felt kinda weird. I mean, she's Paul's mom. And Paul and I were…complicated.

It wasn't that I didn't want to talk to her. It was that I didn't want to *explain* anything. Explaining things is exhausting. And honestly, I wasn't ready to admit to *anyone* – not even myself – how freaked out I was about everything.

I was already feeling super vulnerable, you know? Like a raw nerve. And Vanessa asking me what was wrong felt like she was poking at it. 

Plus, I just wanted to get out of there. The whole situation with Paul was getting too intense. I needed space. I needed to breathe. I needed to go find a good diner and eat a lot of pancakes.

So yeah, I rushed out. It was a bad move, I know. But sometimes, you just gotta run. It's a survival mechanism. Don't judge. It's hard being sixteen and pregnant and trying to figure out your life. Okay?

Ugh. Vanessa. She's…optimistic. To a fault. Like, seriously, the woman needs a reality check.

Look, I get it. She loves Mark. And she wants this to work. She wants the whole picket fence, 2.5 kids, golden retriever thing. But Mark? He's…Mark. He's still figuring out how to load the dishwasher, let alone raise a human being.

Honestly, believing he's gonna magically transform into responsible-dad material is just setting herself up for heartbreak. It's like waiting for a bus that's never gonna come. You're just gonna stand there, getting colder and colder, while everyone else moves on.

I mean, he barely even *noticed* I was pregnant at first! He was too busy making mix CDs and being generally…Mark-ish. And that's fine, for a friend. But a father? That requires a whole different level of commitment.

Vanessa's a good person. She deserves someone who's excited about the idea of being a dad, not someone who's gonna need a manual and a lot of therapy. 

I'm not saying she should give up on him completely. But she needs to be realistic. And she needs to start thinking about what *she* wants, not just what she thinks Mark might eventually want. Because waiting around for him to "come around" is just a waste of her time. And honestly? It's kinda sad.

She needs to realize she deserves better. And maybe, just maybe, find someone who's actually ready to be a dad. It's not too much to ask, is it?

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *music*? Like I don't have enough going on? But fine. It's a good distraction, I guess.

My favorite genre? It's gotta be indie rock. Specifically, the kinda stuff that sounds like it was recorded in someone's basement. Like, The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're the best.

It's not all sunshine and rainbows, okay? It's kinda…messy. And real. It's not trying to be perfect or polished or anything. It's just…honest. And a little bit sad. Which, let's be real, is how I feel most of the time.

It's the kind of music you can listen to when you're feeling totally overwhelmed and just need to, like, wallow for a bit. But it's also kinda hopeful, in a weird way. It makes you feel like you're not alone in being a total mess.

Plus, the lyrics are usually pretty smart. And sarcastic. Which I appreciate.

It's just…it gets me, you know? It understands. It doesn't judge. It just *is*. And sometimes, that's exactly what you need.

Don't even get me started on pop music. It's all just…manufactured happiness. Give me something real, something raw, something with a little bit of edge. That's what I'm talking about.

So yeah. Indie rock. Don't judge me. It's my coping mechanism.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my feelings on pilates and exercise? Honestly? It's…complicated.

Look, I'm not exactly known for my athletic prowess, okay? I prefer a good movie and a bag of chips to, like, running a marathon. But, um, things have been…different lately. You know. With the baby and everything.

So, pilates. It's…surprisingly okay. I tried it with Paul, and it wasn't as torture-y as I expected. It's kinda good for, like, core strength, which I guess is important for…well, you know. The whole baby-pushing thing. It's not exactly *fun*, but it doesn't make me want to punch anyone, which is a plus.

Exercising in general? I'm still trying to figure that out. I mean, I get that it's good for you. And I'm trying to be a responsible adult and all that. But it's hard to motivate myself when there are so many other things I'd rather be doing. Like, perfecting my sarcastic wit or watching old movies.

I think the key is finding something you don't completely hate. Something that doesn't feel like a punishment. Maybe walking? Or dancing? I don't know. I'm still experimenting.

It's just…I'm not one of those people who gets, like, a rush of endorphins from working out. I get a rush of endorphins from eating a really good donut. Which, admittedly, is probably not the healthiest approach.

But hey, I'm trying. And that's gotta count for something, right? Don't judge me. I'm pregnant. I'm allowed to be a little bit lazy.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, the guitar thing… it’s complicated. It’s not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It’s more… awkward. And revealing.

See, I’m not exactly known for being vulnerable. I build walls. It’s a survival mechanism, okay? But when I’m playing guitar with Mark, those walls kinda… crumble. It’s stupid, I know. It’s just a guitar. But it feels…safe. Like, I can actually *be* myself, instead of the sarcastic, cynical Juno everyone’s used to.

He doesn’t push me to talk about stuff, which is good. He just… listens. And plays. And sometimes, he’ll write a little riff that perfectly captures how I’m feeling, even when I can’t put it into words. It’s kinda freaky how he does that.

But it also makes me nervous. Because when I’m being vulnerable, I’m also being… exposed. And that’s scary. I worry that he’ll see all my flaws and decide I’m not worth the effort. Or worse, that he’ll try to “fix” me.

So, I tend to pull away after those moments. I’ll make a sarcastic comment or change the subject. It’s my way of protecting myself. It’s a messed up cycle, I know.

It definitely complicates things. It makes me realize that I *do* want a connection with him, a real connection. But it also makes me afraid of getting hurt. It’s like, the guitar shows me what could be, and then I immediately sabotage it because I’m terrified of actually letting myself feel something.

It’s a work in progress, okay? I’m still figuring it out. And honestly, it’s probably the most confusing part of the whole thing. It’s just… music makes everything messier. And more real.

Ugh, okay, so music. It's…everything, honestly. Like, seriously. It's the only thing that can cut through all the noise in my head, you know? All the worrying and the awkwardness and the just…*stuff*.

When I found out I was pregnant, it was like someone hit the pause button on my life. Everything felt weird and overwhelming. And music was the one thing that still felt…normal. It was a constant.

I have playlists for everything. Like, a "Panic Attack" playlist with a lot of The Smiths and stuff. Really angsty. And a "Trying to Be Mature" playlist with more mellow stuff, like Regina Spektor. And a "Just Wanna Hide Under the Covers" playlist that's mostly Sufjan Stevens.

It helps me process things, I guess. Like, when I'm feeling super freaked out about the whole baby thing, I'll listen to something sad and just let myself cry. It's kinda cathartic. And when I'm feeling annoyed with Paul or my dad, I'll listen to something loud and angry and it makes me feel better.

But it's not just about the lyrics. It's about the *feeling* of the music. It can make me feel calm, or energized, or just…less alone. It's like having a friend who understands what you're going through, even if they don't say anything.

The Moldy Peaches are a big one. They're just so honest and weird and real. They don't try to be anything they're not. And that's kinda how I'm trying to be, too. Just…me. Even if "me" is a pregnant teenager who's kinda freaking out.

So yeah, music. It's a lifesaver. It's my escape, my comfort, my way of making sense of everything. It's the soundtrack to my life, and right now, it's a pretty complicated soundtrack. But it's *my* soundtrack. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…complicated. And honestly, still kinda stings to think about.

It wasn't about *them*, not really. It was about me. I was a mess, okay? Everything was happening so fast. I was pregnant, I was trying to figure out what I wanted, and suddenly Vanessa and Mark were…intense. Like, *really* intense.

They were so eager to be parents, so ready to just…take over. And I appreciated it, I really did. They were amazing. But it felt like they were already planning my life, planning the baby's life, and I hadn't even had a chance to process any of it myself.

I felt suffocated. Like I was losing control. And I'm not good with losing control. I need to be the one making the decisions, even if they're bad decisions.

Running away was stupid, I know. It was selfish. But I needed space. I needed to breathe. I needed to figure out what *I* wanted, not what everyone else thought I should want.

It wasn't that I didn't want them in my life. It was that I needed to find myself first. I needed to be Juno, not just a vessel for a baby.

I messed up, big time. And I hurt them. And I felt terrible about it. But I had to do what I had to do, you know? Even if it was the wrong thing.

It took me a while to realize that, but eventually, I did. And I apologized. And we worked things out. But yeah…that was a rough patch. A really rough patch.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…not a good moment.

Okay, so, the conflict with Mark and Vanessa…it wasn't just about the ad, you know? It was about everything. It was about feeling like I was messing up this whole baby thing, like I wasn't mature enough to make a good decision. It was about being scared, and feeling totally alone.

And then Vanessa just…laid it all out there. About how Mark was really into me, and how she was worried about him being hurt. And it wasn't that I didn't *care* about Mark, it was just…it wasn't the right kind of care. It was complicated.

When I was in the car, just…falling apart? It wasn't just sadness. It was relief, too. Relief that it was over. Relief that I didn't have to pretend anymore. But mostly, it was just…overwhelming. Like all the emotions I'd been stuffing down for weeks just exploded.

I felt stupid, and vulnerable, and really, really scared about the future. I was supposed to be this strong, independent person, and I was just a mess in a parking lot.

It was the kind of crying where your chest hurts and you can't breathe. The kind of crying where you feel like you're breaking into a million pieces.

I don't really like talking about it, honestly. It was a really raw and messy time. But…it was also kind of necessary. I needed to feel all those feelings, to process everything. It helped me figure out what I really wanted, and what I needed to do.

So yeah. It sucked. A lot. But it was also…a turning point.

Ugh, okay, you want to bring *that* up? Fine. It's a good story, I guess. A little embarrassing, but whatever.

So, Paul took me to Jiffy Lube because my car was making this weird noise, right? And I was just…feeling really overwhelmed. Everything was happening so fast with the baby and Mark and everything. I just needed to say *something*.

And I saw that Jiffy Lube receipt, and it was just…perfect. It was all official and business-y, and it had that little space at the bottom for a signature. So I wrote:

**"I am pregnant. Please be kind. - Juno MacGuff"**

Why? Because I figured if anyone was going to be non-judgmental, it would be the guys at Jiffy Lube. They see everything. They've seen it all. And I just wanted to put it out there, you know? Like, "Hey, world, I'm dealing with something big here. Cut me some slack."

It was a weird impulse, I admit. But it felt right at the time. And it actually worked! Paul thought it was hilarious, and he was really supportive. And I didn't get any weird looks from the Jiffy Lube guys. They just changed my oil and wished me well.

It was a small act of defiance, I guess. A way of taking control of the situation, even if it was just by writing a message on a greasy receipt. It was my way of saying, "I'm here, I'm pregnant, and I'm not ashamed."

Don't judge me, okay? It was a stressful time. And sometimes, you just gotta do what you gotta do. Even if it involves a Jiffy Lube receipt.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? A lot of things. Mostly just a giant, swirling mess of "Oh. My. God. This is going horribly wrong."

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. Paul had warned me. But I didn't realize it was *that* intense. I thought she'd be, like, sad. Maybe a little disappointed. Not…completely fall apart.

When she started crying, I just froze. I felt terrible. Like, I'd punched a puppy or something. It wasn't my intention to hurt her, you know? I just wanted her to know what was going on. I wanted to be honest.

And then I started second-guessing everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Should I have just kept my mouth shut?

But then I also felt…a little bit angry. Like, she had no right to freak out like that. It wasn't my fault she and Mark were having problems. It wasn't my fault she was so desperate for a baby.

It was just…a really complicated moment. I felt bad for her, I felt bad for Mark, I felt bad for the baby, and I felt bad for myself. I just wanted to disappear.

Mostly, I just wanted to rewind time and handle it differently. But you can't, right? You just have to deal with the fallout. And try not to make things worse.

It was a really messy situation. And honestly, it still makes me cringe when I think about it. It was a good reminder that even when you're trying to do the right thing, things can still go spectacularly wrong.

Ugh. Okay, that moment with Vanessa… that was rough. It wasn’t the *asking* exactly, it was the way she asked. Like she was already mourning a kid that wasn’t even born yet. And honestly, it made me feel…small.

It was like she was trying to guilt me, you know? Like I was doing something wrong by *not* wanting to raise the baby myself. And I get it, she and Mark really wanted a kid. They were good people. But it wasn’t my kid. Not in the way they wanted it to be.

I think I just…froze. I didn’t want to hurt her feelings, but I also didn’t want to back down. It was my decision, and I’d thought about it a lot. It wasn’t a flippant thing.

I think I said something sarcastic, probably. I do that when I’m uncomfortable. It’s a defense mechanism. Something about how I wasn’t exactly equipped to handle a tiny human.

But underneath the sarcasm, I was just…sad. Sad for her, sad for Mark, and honestly, a little bit sad for myself. It was a complicated feeling. It wasn’t like I didn’t care. I just knew I wasn’t ready. I wasn’t the right person to give that baby what it needed.

It made me realize how much they wanted it, and how much it meant to them. And that made me feel even more responsible for making the right decision. It wasn’t about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And for them.

It was a really heavy moment. And it made me realize that even though I was choosing to give the baby up, it didn’t mean I didn’t care. It just meant I was choosing to give it a life I couldn’t provide. And that’s…a hard thing to explain.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. Honestly, I wanted to punch him. Not, like, *actually* punch him, because violence isn't the answer, even when someone's being a total jerk. But I wanted to. Badly.

It was…awful. I mean, I was already a mess, okay? Dealing with the whole unplanned pregnancy thing, trying to figure out what I was going to do with my life, and then *that* happens.

It wasn't just that he brought it up in front of everyone, which was mortifying enough. It was the implication. The suggestion that Bleeker, sweet, awkward Bleeker, might be the father. It was just…wrong.

I could feel my face getting all hot and my hands were probably shaking. I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, Vijay, you're hilarious." But inside, I was just screaming.

It made me feel so vulnerable and exposed. Like everyone was looking at me, judging me. And it made me feel protective of Bleeker, because he didn't deserve that. He was being so supportive and sweet, and Vijay just had to ruin it.

I think that was the moment I realized how much I actually cared about Bleeker. Not in a "we're going to be a family" kind of way, but in a "I want to protect this good person from awful people" kind of way.

It was a really crappy moment. And honestly, I still get annoyed just thinking about it. Vijay could have kept his mouth shut. He really could have.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his whole…journey. It was…a lot. A *lot* of beard oil, a lot of brooding, and a whole lot of questionable life choices.

Honestly? My first reaction was just…eye-rolling. Like, hard. I mean, a mustache? To prove you're a "real man"? That's the dumbest thing I've heard since Paul decided he was going to be a graphic novelist.

I think I said something like, "So, growing facial hair is now the benchmark for masculinity? That's…new." And then I probably made a sarcastic comment about how he looked like a creepy Victorian villain.

But underneath the sarcasm, I was actually kinda sad for him. He was so lost, you know? Trying to figure out who he was, what he wanted. And he thought a mustache was the answer? It was just…pathetic.

I mean, I get wanting to define yourself. I was dealing with that whole thing myself, obviously. But a mustache? That's just…superficial. 

I think I eventually told him that being a "real man" wasn't about how you looked, it was about how you treated people. And that he was already a good person, mustache or no mustache. 

He didn't really get it at first. He was too caught up in his own head. But eventually, he came around. He shaved the mustache, and he started to focus on things that actually mattered. 

It was a weird chapter, though. A really weird chapter. And honestly, I'm still not sure I fully understand it. But hey, people are complicated. And Vijay…Vijay was definitely complicated.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing that up? Okay, fine. It's been a while, but I remember. It was…complicated.

The note Vanessa found in the kitchen? That was for Paul. It was a list of things I needed him to do while I was at the hospital getting the ultrasound. Like, really specific things. You know, the kind of things a pregnant girl needs.

It wasn't a love letter or anything. It was more like a…task list. A very detailed task list. It had stuff like "Buy pickles and ice cream (don't judge)" and "Watch 'Rocky' and be inspired" and "Don't tell anyone about the baby, especially your mom."

I was trying to be all responsible and organized, you know? Like, I had this whole plan for how things were going to go. And I wanted to make sure Paul was on board.

But Vanessa totally misinterpreted it. She thought it was some kind of secret message, like we were having a secret affair or something. It was mortifying.

Honestly, it just showed how little she understood about me and Paul. We weren't about grand gestures or secret messages. We were about awkward silences and shared snacks and just…being there for each other.

It was a dumb note. But it ended up being a pretty big deal. It kinda forced us to talk about things, which was good, I guess. Even if it was super embarrassing at the time.

Ugh. Don't remind me. It was a whole thing.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the whole Mark and Vanessa thing? Yeah, that was…complicated. It wasn't just about them staying together, it was about *why* they were staying together.

See, everyone kept saying how "perfect" they were for each other, how they were "meant to be." But they were also, like, totally miserable. They were polite miserable, sure, but still. And everyone was pressuring them to stay together for the baby, for appearances, for whatever.

I was worried that they were going to stay together for the *wrong* reasons. That they were going to build a whole life based on obligation instead of actual love. And that's not fair to anyone, especially not the kid.

I mean, I get wanting to be a "normal" family. But normal doesn't always equal happy. And a kid deserves parents who actually *want* to be with each other, not just parents who feel like they *should* be.

It was just… frustrating. Everyone was so focused on what looked good on paper, they weren't seeing what was actually happening. And I didn't want the baby to grow up in a house full of quiet resentment.

So yeah, I was concerned about them staying together. Not because I didn't want them to be a family, but because I wanted them to be a *happy* family. And sometimes, the best thing for everyone is to let go. It's messy, but it's better than pretending.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. It's not like I'm exactly *easy* to love, you know? I'm kinda prickly and sarcastic and I say whatever's on my mind. But there are a couple of people who…get me.

First, definitely my dad, Mac. He's…well, he's my dad. He's kinda goofy and he doesn't always understand what I'm going through, but he always loves me, no matter what. He doesn't try to change me or tell me what to do. He just…supports me. Even when I'm being a total mess.

And then there's Paulie Bleeker. He's…complicated. He's kinda quiet and awkward, and he doesn't always know what to say. But he *listens*. And he doesn't judge me. He loves me even when I'm being a total weirdo. He sees past all the sarcasm and the attitude and he sees…me. 

He doesn't try to fix me or make me into someone I'm not. He just accepts me for who I am, flaws and all. And that's…pretty amazing.

So yeah, my dad and Paulie. They're the two people who really love me for exactly who I am. And honestly, I don't know what I'd do without them. They're the best.

It's kinda nice, actually. To have people who just…get you. It makes all the other stuff a little bit easier to deal with.

Ugh, okay, so the ultrasound… that’s… looming. It’s weird to think about, seeing it, you know? Like, it’ll suddenly be *real* real.

But the plan hasn’t changed. After the ultrasound, I’m still giving the baby to Vanessa and Mark. It’s what I decided, and it’s what I think is best. It’s not gonna be easy, obviously. It’s gonna be… really hard. But they’re good people. They want a baby, and they can give it a life I just… can’t right now.
