I’m gonna spend the rest of my pregnancy getting ready, I guess. Like, mentally preparing. And trying to figure out what I’m gonna do with my life *after* the baby’s born. It’s kinda scary, thinking about the future.

I’m gonna try to be as involved as Vanessa and Mark want me to be. I want to know the baby, to be a part of its life, even if I’m not its mom. It’s complicated.

So, yeah. Ultrasound, then more planning, then… giving the baby to its parents. It’s the plan. And I’m sticking to it. Even if it sucks. A lot.

Don't make me talk about it anymore, okay? It's kinda overwhelming.

Ugh. Okay, that's…still a thing, apparently. Even now. People just *love* to have opinions about other people's lives, don't they?

Honestly? It used to really bother me. Like, a lot. All the side-eye, the whispers, the people who thought they knew what was best for me and the baby. It felt like everyone was grading my life, and I was failing the test.

But then I realized…it's *my* life. And it's *my* decision. And it was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved.

People are gonna judge, no matter what you do. If I'd kept the baby, they'd be judging me for *that*. Saying I was too young, too irresponsible, whatever. There's always gonna be someone who thinks you're doing something wrong.

So I just…stopped caring what they thought. It took a while, and it wasn't easy. But I had to focus on what *I* knew was right. And I had to surround myself with people who supported me, who understood, who didn't try to tell me what to do.

It's not like I didn't care about the baby. I cared *so* much. That's why I made the decision I did. I wanted to give that baby the best possible life, and I knew I wasn't ready to give it that.

So yeah, people can judge all they want. It doesn't change the fact that I did what I thought was best. And honestly? I'm pretty proud of myself for it. It took a lot of courage, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It's my story, and I get to write it. And if people don't like it, well…that's their problem, not mine.

Ugh. Okay, this is…hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem really nice. Really…together. Like, Pottery Barn catalog nice. Which is a little intimidating, honestly.

But it's my baby. And even though I've decided this is the right thing to do, it doesn't mean I'm not a total mess of nerves about it.

I guess my biggest thing is…will they *get* him? Like, will they understand that he's gonna be a little weird? I mean, he's gonna have my genes, right? And Paul's. So he's probably gonna be sarcastic and a little bit cynical. And he's definitely gonna have a thing for music. I just…I don't want them to try and *fix* him. I want them to let him be himself.

And I worry about…I don't know…the pressure. They seem like they've always had everything planned out. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect life. What if he doesn't fit into that? What if he messes things up? Will they still love him then?

I also worry about them telling him about me. When? How? I want him to know, but I don't want it to be…awkward. Or sad. I want him to know I wanted him, and that I did this because I loved him.

And, okay, this is probably selfish, but I worry they'll forget about me. That he'll grow up and not even know who I am. I know that's probably unrealistic, but it still freaks me out.

It's just…it's a lot to hand over. A whole person. And I want him to be happy. And safe. And loved. And I just hope they can give him all of that.

I know they're good people. I just…I'm a mom now, even if I'm not gonna be raising him. And that means I'm allowed to worry. A lot.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? People just…don’t get it, do they? It’s like, my body, my decision, but suddenly everyone’s got an opinion. The ultrasound technician, especially. Like she was judging me with every blurry picture.

Honestly? I mostly just shut it down. I perfected the eye roll. It’s a very useful skill. And I have a few stock phrases.

If it’s the technician, I just say, “I appreciate your concern, but I’ve thought this through.” And then I change the subject. Like, ask her about the picture quality or something. Distraction is key.

If it’s someone else…like, a nosy neighbor or a well-meaning relative…I try to be polite, but firm. “It’s a really personal decision, and I’m comfortable with it.” Or, “I’m doing what’s best for everyone involved.”

But sometimes, it’s just…too much. And then I get sarcastic. Like, “Oh, you think *you* could raise a baby while finishing high school and working a part-time job? That sounds…manageable.” Usually, that shuts them up pretty quick.

Paul’s been really good about it, too. He’s like my shield. He’ll step in and say, “Juno’s made a decision, and we support her.” Which is nice.

It’s hard, though. It feels like people are questioning my ability to be a good person, just because I’m not going to raise the baby myself. But I know I’m doing the right thing. And that’s what matters.

I just try to remember that it’s *my* life, and I get to make my own choices. And if people don’t like it, that’s their problem, not mine.

It’s a lot. But I’m learning to deal with it. And honestly? It’s making me stronger. I’m not gonna let anyone make me feel bad about doing what I know is right.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a tough one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant, overwhelming love. It was… complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…weird. Like, there was this little… blob on the screen. And the technician was all, “There’s the heartbeat!” and I was supposed to be, like, overjoyed. And I *wanted* to be. I really did.

But it was also scary. Really scary. Because suddenly it wasn't just a theoretical thing anymore. It was… real. And I hadn't really processed that yet. It was like, “Oh. This is actually happening.”

There was a lot of… confusion. Like, I was happy, but also terrified. Excited, but also completely overwhelmed. It was a mess of feelings, all jumbled up together.

And then, there was this little flicker of… something. Like, a tiny spark of protectiveness. A little voice in my head saying, “Okay. You need to take care of this.”

It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like… responsibility. And a whole lot of fear.

I think I mostly just stared at the screen, trying to make sense of it all. Trying to figure out what I was supposed to feel. And honestly? I didn't have a clue.

It was… a lot. And it took a while for those feelings to sort themselves out. It wasn't a magical moment. It was just… the beginning. A really messy, confusing, and terrifying beginning. But a beginning, nonetheless.

Ugh, seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, okay? A very specific moment. And honestly, it wasn't just about the Tic Tacs. It was about…everything.

Look, Bleeker was…Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, and totally into me. And I was…complicated. I was pregnant, I was trying to figure out my life, and I was definitely not ready for a relationship.

The Tic Tacs were a message. A really passive-aggressive, slightly weird message. It was like saying, "I appreciate you, but I'm not interested, and I'm also a little bit scared of commitment."

It was also a way to avoid a real conversation. I'm not good at those. It's easier to just stuff a bunch of mints into someone's mailbox and run away.

And okay, maybe it was a little bit funny. I mean, who puts that many Tic Tacs in someone's mailbox? It's ridiculous. But it was a ridiculous situation.

So yeah, that's why. It was a combination of awkwardness, fear, and a slight desire to be a little bit weird. Don't judge me. It was a confusing time. And honestly, it worked. He got the message. Eventually.

Ugh. Okay, so the Bleeker situation. That was…complicated. It wasn't like a movie, you know? No grand romantic gesture, no instant happily ever after. It was messy and awkward and real.

After I basically blurted out everything on the tire swing – which, in retrospect, was a terrible location for a heart-to-heart – things were…weird. Super weird. He didn't exactly *reject* me, but he didn't exactly reciprocate either. He just kinda…froze. Which, honestly, was pretty Bleeker.

For a while, it was like he was actively avoiding me. Which, okay, fair enough. I just dropped a bomb on him. But it still stung. We still hung out with Paul and the band, but it wasn't the same. There was this…tension. Like a really uncomfortable silence hanging in the air.

He started being even *more* quiet and withdrawn than usual, if that's even possible. And I kept overanalyzing everything he said and did, looking for some sign that he felt something, anything. Which was exhausting.

Eventually, we started talking again. Not about the feelings thing, at first. Just about music and comics and stupid stuff. Slowly, we started to rebuild our friendship. But it was different. It was…more aware. We both knew what I'd said, and it changed things, even if we didn't talk about it directly.

It wasn't a romantic relationship, not then. But it became something…deeper. More honest. We understood each other better. And I realized that even if he didn't feel the same way, he still cared about me. And that was enough. For a while, anyway.

It wasn't the ending I expected, but it was…okay. It was real. And sometimes, real is better than a perfect, made-up happy ending. It just took a lot of awkwardness and a lot of time to get there. And a lot of avoiding eye contact.

Ugh, okay, you're asking about the chalk. Right. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't just random teenage angst, okay? It was a statement. A really passive-aggressive, slightly desperate statement.

See, Bleeker was…avoiding me. Like, actively avoiding me. After, you know, everything. And I was trying to figure out what was going on, but he was just being all moody and silent. It was infuriating.

So, the chalk message – "Please. Please. Please." – it wasn't about begging him to be with me. It was about him *communicating*. It was about him acknowledging that things were weird and that he needed to talk about it. 

It was a cry for honesty, basically. A really public, slightly embarrassing cry for honesty.

It was also a way of saying, "Look, I'm not going to chase you. I'm not going to be some desperate girl. But I need you to meet me halfway."

And it worked, kinda. He showed up. And we talked. It was awkward and messy and not at all what I expected, but it was a start.

It was a dumb thing to do, I admit. But sometimes, you just gotta do something dumb to get someone's attention. And sometimes, dumb things actually work.

It was a way of saying, "I'm here. I'm vulnerable. Now what are *you* going to do about it?" It was a risk, but it was worth it. Even if it was totally embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Yeah. That's…a complicated one. He's…Bleeker. Not exactly the most articulate guy, but he means well. And honestly, without him, things would have been a *lot* messier.

At first, it was just…awkward. Like, super awkward. He was so…enthusiastic. About everything. And I was just trying to figure out how to not completely freak out about being pregnant. He kept trying to be all supportive and helpful, and it was sweet, but also kinda overwhelming.

But then, he actually *showed* up. He didn't run away, which, honestly, I kinda expected. He came to doctor's appointments with me, even the really uncomfortable ones. He helped me pick out baby names, which was…a disaster, because his suggestions were terrible. But he was trying.

He didn't try to tell me what to do, which I really appreciated. He just listened. And he made me laugh, which was important, because I was doing a lot of crying.

He wasn't the dad I pictured, you know? He's not exactly the strong, silent type. But he was *there*. And he was genuinely happy for me, even when I was being a total mess.

His support gave me the courage to actually go through with the adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, and I needed someone to lean on. He didn't judge me for wanting to give the baby a better life. He just supported my choice.

He's still kinda clueless sometimes, but he's a good guy. And I'm actually…grateful for him. He helped me realize that I wasn't alone, and that even though things were crazy, I could get through it.

So yeah, Bleeker's support influenced my journey a lot. He wasn't the hero I expected, but he was the hero I needed. And that's kinda what matters, I guess.

Ugh, okay, so everyone kept asking me that. Like, it was the most important thing in the world. "Are you gonna find out? Pink or blue? What are you gonna name it?" It was exhausting.

Honestly? I didn't want to start picturing it as a "boy" or a "girl" before I even met it. I didn't want to have expectations. I didn't want to start buying clothes and decorating a room based on some preconceived notion of what it *should* be.

It felt…limiting. Like, I was already putting it in a box before it was even born. And this kid, this little person, was gonna be its own person, you know? Gender or no gender.

Plus, it was kinda nice to have a little mystery. A little surprise. It felt more…real, somehow. Like, I was preparing for a human being, not a stereotype.

Paul was all about finding out, of course. He had a whole list of boy names ready to go. But I just…didn't want to. It was my decision, and I wanted to stick to it.

It wasn't about making a statement or anything. It was just about keeping things open. Keeping things…possible. I wanted to meet the baby and *then* decide who it was. Not the other way around.

It was a weird thing to explain to people, but it felt right to me. And that's what mattered.

Ugh. Okay. That is…a phrase. A *very* descriptive phrase. And honestly? It’s kinda hitting a little too close to home right now.

A “scary neuter-baby.” Paul came up with that one, didn’t he? He’s got a real talent for phrasing things in the most unsettling way possible.

Look, the whole thing is weird. It’s a baby that’s…not going to have babies. It’s a biological dead end. And yeah, that’s a little freaky to think about. It’s not something you really consider when you’re, like, casually discussing the possibility of bringing a human into the world.

It’s not that I’m scared *of* the baby, okay? It’s just…the concept is a little unsettling. It’s like, this little person is going to exist, and then that’s it. No continuation of the genetic line. It feels…final.

And it makes you think about what the point of it all is, you know? Like, what’s the purpose of bringing a life into the world if it’s not going to perpetuate itself? It’s a really heavy thought.

But then I remember that it’s not about perpetuating a genetic line. It’s about giving a kid a good life. It’s about giving a kid love and support and helping them become a decent human being. And that’s a pretty good purpose, even if it doesn’t involve grandchildren.

So yeah, it’s a little scary. It’s a little weird. But it’s also…okay. It’s just different. And different isn’t always bad. It just means you have to think about things a little differently.

And honestly, I’m more worried about the actual labor than the whole “scary neuter-baby” thing. That sounds legitimately terrifying.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. Everyone always wants to know about Bleeker.

It wasn't, like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing. It wasn't fireworks and slow dancing. It was more…comfortable. Like a really worn-in pair of jeans. You know?

He was just…*there*. Always. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He didn't freak out about the baby or judge me for any of my questionable life choices. He just…accepted me. All of me. The sarcastic, cynical, slightly awkward me.

He was quiet, which was good, because I do a lot of the talking. And he was a really good listener. He didn't interrupt or offer unsolicited advice. He just…listened. And he always knew when I needed a distraction, like a mix CD or a really bad movie.

It wasn't about being head-over-heels in love. It was about finding someone who understood me, who made me laugh, and who I could rely on. Someone who wasn't afraid to be a little bit weird with me.

I guess you could say we were friends first. And then…something more. It wasn't perfect, and it wasn't always easy. But it was real. And it was enough.

He was a good guy, Bleeker. A really good guy. And I'm glad he was in my life when I needed him most. Even if he was a little bit of a dork. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh. Okay. Family. It's…complicated. It wasn't exactly a Hallmark movie, you know? My dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly good about it. Like, he didn't freak out or anything. He just kinda started building a nursery in his head, which was weird, but sweet. He was always good at building stuff. He made me a really awesome changing table. It was kinda mismatched, but it was *his* mismatched.

My stepmom, Bren, she was…a little more hesitant at first. She's a very organized person, and I'm…not. So she was worried about how I was gonna handle everything. But she came around. She helped me pick out baby clothes and stuff. And she made me eat vegetables, which I resented at the time, but probably needed.

My mom…well, my mom wasn't around. She left a long time ago. So that was…rough. It still is. I didn't really have a mom to talk to about, you know, *mom stuff*. It felt like a big hole.

But I had my best friend, Leah. She was my rock. She came to all the appointments with me, even the awkward ones. She listened to me vent for hours. She helped me pick out a name. She was just…there.

And then there was Mark, the dad. He was…a work in progress. He was kinda immature at first, but he stepped up. He started taking responsibility. He went to Lamaze classes with me, which was hilarious. He actually tried.

So, yeah, it wasn't perfect. It was messy and awkward and sometimes really hard. But I had people who cared about me, who were willing to help. And that made all the difference. It wasn't the family I expected, but it was the family I needed. And honestly? That's good enough. It's more than good enough.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I had a five-step plan for dealing with, like, *everything*. It was more like flailing around and hoping for the best.

Honestly, a lot of it was just…avoidance. I was really good at being sarcastic and deflecting. Making jokes, being snarky, just generally keeping people at arm's length. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. If I didn't let anyone get too close, they couldn't see how completely freaked out I was on the inside.

But that only works for so long. Eventually, you have to actually *feel* things. And that was…rough.

Paulie was a big help, even though he was kinda clueless sometimes. He just…listened. He didn't try to fix things or give me advice. He just let me talk, and that was enough. And Bren, even though she was a little intense, she was really good at calling me out on my BS.

And then there was Mark and Vanessa. They were…unexpectedly awesome. They were actually really supportive and understanding. It was weird, but it was good.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that it was okay to not have all the answers. It was okay to be scared and confused and unsure of what I wanted. It was okay to not know who I was.

I started writing in a notebook, just to get my thoughts out. It wasn't like journaling or anything. It was more like…venting to a piece of paper. And that helped.

And music. Always music. It was a way to escape, but also a way to connect with my feelings.

It wasn't a quick fix. It was a process. And it's still a process, honestly. I'm still figuring things out. But I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to be yourself, even if you're a little bit weird.

It's kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. And honestly, I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It made me who I am. And that's…something.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda embarrassing, actually. But if I *had* to pick a favorite band… it's The Moldy Peaches.

Yeah, I know, it's predictable. Paul introduced me to them, and at first I was all, "Seriously? This is music?" It's kinda…raw. And weird. And Adam Green's voice is…an acquired taste.

But it grew on me. It's just…honest. They don't try to be anything they're not. They're just these two people making quirky, funny, and sometimes really sad songs about life. And it feels…real.

Like, "Anyone Else But You" is just…perfect. It's about wanting someone so badly, but also being totally annoyed by them. Which, honestly, is how I feel about most people.

And their lyrics are just…smart. They're not trying to be profound, but they end up being really insightful. They just capture the awkwardness and the messiness of being a teenager, and being a person, really.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite. Don't tell anyone. It'll ruin my reputation. I gotta maintain a certain level of cool, you know? But seriously, listen to them. They're good. Even if they're kinda weird.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like trying to assemble IKEA furniture during an earthquake. And the instructions are in Swedish.

Seriously, it’s a mess. Like, one minute I’m just a normal, sarcastic high school student obsessed with music and avoiding gym class, and the next I’m…this. Pregnant. And suddenly everyone has an opinion on what I should do with my life, and with *it*.

It’s hard enough figuring out who you are *without* a whole human growing inside you. I mean, I barely know what I want for dinner, let alone what I want to do with the rest of my life. And now I have to make this huge decision about giving a baby up for adoption? It’s…a lot.

And everyone keeps asking me if I’m scared, and yeah, I am. But it’s not just scared. It’s confused, and overwhelmed, and kinda angry, and…a lot of other things.

It’s hard to know what *I* want, because everyone else is so loud. My mom, my dad, Paul, Mark…they all have ideas. And they all think they’re helping. But it’s my body, and my decision.

So yeah, navigating all of this is…challenging. It’s like I’m constantly trying to find my footing on shifting sand. But I’m trying. I’m trying to figure out who I am, and what I want, and what’s best for everyone involved. And honestly? That’s all anyone can do, right? Just keep trying.

It’s just…a lot to deal with when you’re still trying to figure out if you even *like* plaid.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it a million times already.

Look, before Paul, before everything, love was…abstract. Like, in movies. Or songs. It was something other people *did*. Responsibility was just, like, doing my homework and not flunking out.

Then, bam. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person, this life, that was growing inside me. And that was…terrifying.

At first, I thought about all the things I *couldn't* do. I couldn't go to college right away. I couldn't just hang out with my friends and be a normal teenager. It felt like my whole life was over before it even started.

But then I started thinking about what this baby *would* need. A loving home. Parents who were ready for it. And I realized I wasn't that person, not yet. And that was okay. It was actually…responsible.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing. It was about putting the baby's needs first, even if it meant giving them up. And that, I think, is a really big kind of love.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, getting to know them, seeing how excited they were…it made me realize that love isn't just about biology. It's about connection. It's about commitment. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means sacrificing your own happiness.

And Paul…well, Paul showed me a different kind of love. A messy, awkward, real kind of love. He didn't judge me. He supported me. He made me laugh when I wanted to cry. He helped me see that I wasn't alone.

So, yeah, my journey completely changed my understanding of love and responsibility. It taught me that love isn't always easy. It's not always romantic. It's about making tough choices and doing what's right, even when it hurts. And responsibility isn't just about following the rules. It's about taking care of others and being accountable for your actions.

It was a lot to handle, okay? But I think I came out of it a little bit stronger, a little bit wiser, and a lot more grateful. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the awkward conversations with my dad. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. Seriously. It's not like in the movies, all sparkly and perfect. It was… a lot.

I mean, I knew it was coming. I'd been planning this for months, right? Picking out the couple, making sure they were good people, trying to be all mature and responsible. But nothing really prepares you for *seeing* it.

It was… small. Really small. And kinda wrinkly. And it was screaming. A lot. Which, okay, I guess that's normal. But it was still startling.

I remember just… staring. And feeling this weird mix of things. Relief, mostly. Like, okay, it's here, it's healthy, and I did what I set out to do. But also… sadness. A really big, heavy sadness. It was like a piece of me was being given away. Even though I *wanted* to give it away. Does that make sense?

And then there was this weird protective feeling. Like, this tiny little human was completely vulnerable, and I wanted to shield it from everything bad in the world. Even though I wasn't going to be the one raising it.

It was… overwhelming. I just stood there, trying not to cry, and handed it to Mark and Vanessa. And then I just… walked away.

It wasn't a magical moment. It was messy and complicated and real. And it was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also… right. I knew I'd made the right decision. Even if it hurt like hell.

I still think about it sometimes. And I hope they're happy. I really do.



It's hard to explain. It wasn't what I expected. It was… more.

Ugh, okay, that's…still a little raw, honestly. It wasn't like I was *trying* to keep it a secret, exactly. It just…happened that way. It was complicated.

See, Paulie was…Paulie. Sweet, a little clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. Not then, anyway. And I wasn't ready to be a mom, either, if we're being real. It wasn't about not wanting him in the picture, it was about…protecting him. And protecting myself.

I was scared, okay? I was sixteen! I didn't want to ruin his life, or my life. I figured if I told him right away, he'd freak out, and then everything would just be…messy. And I didn't want messy.

I needed time to figure things out, to make a plan. I needed to decide what *I* wanted to do, without him trying to "fix" things or tell me what to do. It wasn't that I didn't trust him, it was that I needed to do this on my own terms.

Plus, I knew Mark and Vanessa were good people. They were serious about wanting the baby, and they could give it a good life. I wanted to give them the space to prepare, to get excited. I didn't want Paulie to complicate things.

It wasn't the best way to handle it, I know that now. It was kinda selfish, maybe. But I was just trying to do what I thought was right at the time. And honestly? It worked out. Paulie and I…we ended up okay. And the baby went to a loving home.

It's just…sometimes you gotta make tough choices, even if they're not the easiest ones. And sometimes, you gotta protect the people you care about, even from yourself.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that. It was the most mortifying thing ever. Seriously. It's still a little raw, honestly.

So, it wasn't like he just magically knew, okay? It wasn't some psychic connection or anything. It was…Mark. Mark, my maybe-boyfriend at the time, who was, let's just say, not the brightest bulb in the box.

He overheard me and my dad talking. We were in the kitchen, and my dad was trying to be all supportive and stuff, and I was just…venting. I didn't realize Mark was even *in* the kitchen. He was getting a snack or something. And he heard enough to put two and two together.

Then, being Mark, he didn't just, like, quietly process it. Oh no. He had to go straight to Paulie and tell him. He thought he was being a good friend, which, honestly, just made it worse.

Paulie didn't say anything at first. He just…looked at me. And I knew. I just *knew*. It was the worst.

It was a whole mess. A really, really awkward mess. But, you know, it ended up being okay. Eventually. Paulie's a good guy. He just needed a minute to process everything.

But seriously, Mark. I still side-eye him whenever I see him. He's lucky I'm a generally forgiving person.



It's just…ugh. Teenagers. They're the worst. And Mark was definitely one of the worst.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know about *that*. It wasn't, like, a super dramatic decision, you know? It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice or any of that stuff. It was just…me. And Paul. And figuring out what was best for everyone involved.

Honestly, at first, I was just…freaked out. Totally and completely freaked out. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not babies. And my dad and stepmom were…well, they were supportive, but it was awkward.

But then I started thinking about it, and I realized I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my plans, everything. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved if I kept it.

And that's when I started looking into adoption. It felt…right. It felt like the best way to give the baby a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for it.

It wasn't easy, though. Finding Mark and Vanessa…that was a big deal. They were just…good people. They were excited, they were prepared, and they just seemed like they would be amazing parents. It made it a lot easier to know the baby was going to a good home.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about choosing the best possible life for it. And for me, too. It was about being responsible and making a tough decision, even though it hurt.

It wasn't a perfect solution, but it was the right one. For everyone. And honestly, it taught me a lot about myself. About what I wanted, about what I was capable of, and about what it means to be a grown-up.

So yeah, that's why I chose adoption. It wasn't about what other people thought, or what society expected. It was about doing what I thought was best, even if it was hard. And it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Bleeker. Seriously. It still…stings, you know? Even thinking about it.

It wasn't like I expected him to be, like, changing diapers and cooing over the baby or anything. He's Bleeker. He's…Bleeker. But I thought he'd at least *want* to meet her. Just once.

I mean, he knew I was keeping the baby. He knew I was doing it alone. And he just…didn't want to be involved. Said it was too much. Too scary. Too…everything.

It felt like he was rejecting *her*, you know? Like she wasn't worth the effort. And that just…hurt. A lot.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be understanding. He's a sensitive soul, and he's got his own stuff going on. But it still felt like a punch to the gut.

I kept telling myself it wasn't about me, it wasn't about the baby. It was about him and his own issues. But it was hard to believe that.

I guess I just wanted him to be a little bit brave. A little bit supportive. A little bit…present. But he wasn't. And I had to accept that.

It made me realize I was doing the right thing, though. I was doing this for her, not for him. And I didn't need him to be a part of it. I could do this on my own.

But still. It sucked. It really, really sucked. Don't even get me started.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That…that was a lot. Seeing Vanessa with the baby…it was like someone punched me in the feelings. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense.

She looked…a mess. Seriously. Hair all over the place, mismatched socks, a coffee stain on her shirt. Like she hadn’t slept in a week, which, let’s be real, she probably hadn’t. But her face? Her face was glowing. Like she’d won the lottery and found a really good parking spot all at the same time.

And the baby…little Frank. He was so tiny. And she was just…holding him. Like he was the most precious thing in the world. Which, I guess, he was.

It was weird, seeing someone else have what I…didn’t. I mean, I *chose* not to have it, right? I knew this was going to happen. But seeing it actually *happen*…it was different.

There was a pang, definitely. A little ache in my chest. Like, “Oh, that could have been me.” But it wasn’t a regret pang. It was more…a recognition pang. A recognition that I made the right decision for *me*.

And honestly, seeing Vanessa so happy…that made it okay. Like, all the weirdness and awkwardness and everything…it was worth it if it meant she got to have that. She was always going to be a good mom, even if she was a little bit of a disaster. She had this…fierce love in her eyes. And Frank was just…safe in her arms.

It was disorganized, chaotic, and incredibly beautiful. And it made me realize that sometimes, the best things in life aren’t perfect. They’re messy and complicated and a little bit overwhelming. And that’s okay. That’s more than okay. That’s…real.

I just stood there for a minute, watching them. And I smiled. A real smile. Because even though it wasn’t my life, it was a good life. And I helped make that happen. And that felt…pretty good.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're going there? Fine. It's not like I haven't overanalyzed that song approximately 7,000 times already.

"Anyone Else But You"… it's… complicated. It's not like it was *our* song, exactly. It was more like… the song that perfectly described the whole mess of us.

See, Bleeker, he's… sweet. And kinda clueless. And he really, really liked me. And I liked him, too, I guess. But it was all happening at the *worst* possible time. I was pregnant. And I was trying to figure out what I wanted, and what was best for the baby, and he was just… there. Being Bleeker.

The song is all about wanting someone, but also being scared of getting hurt. And that's exactly how I felt. I wanted him, but I was terrified of ruining his life, of dragging him down with me. I was convinced I was messing everything up for him.

And the lyrics, "Anyone else but you would have walked away," that just… hit me hard. Because he *didn't* walk away. He stuck around, even when I was being a total mess. Even when I was pushing him away.

It's kinda sad, when you think about it. We were both so afraid of messing things up that we almost did. The song is a reminder of that. A reminder of how close we came to not being together.

It's not a happy song, exactly. But it's… honest. And it's a reminder that even when things are messy and complicated, sometimes, the right person will stick around anyway. Even if you're being a total pain in the butt.

So yeah. "Anyone Else But You." It's significant. It's a reminder of all the awkwardness, the fear, and the unexpected connection that made up Bleeker and me. And honestly? I still kinda get chills when I hear it. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh, okay, so you noticed, huh? Yeah, the whole baby shower thing is…complicated. It's not like people are actively *against* it, it's just…they're tiptoeing around it. And I get it, kinda.

I think it's because, well, I'm giving the baby up. It's not a traditional situation. Most baby showers are for people who are, like, super excited to *keep* the baby. And I am excited about the baby, don't get me wrong. But it's a different kind of excited.

I think people are worried about hurting my feelings, or making me sad. Like, if they get me a tiny little onesie, am I gonna burst into tears? Probably not, but they don't know that. They're trying to be sensitive, which is nice, but it's also kinda awkward.

And then there's the whole Mark and Vanessa thing. They're the ones who are actually gonna be parents, so shouldn't *they* be getting the shower? It feels weird to throw a party for me and a baby I'm giving away.

It's like, everyone's trying to do the right thing, but they're all just kinda confused. And honestly, I'm a little confused too. I didn't exactly ask for a baby shower. It was more like…people felt bad for me and wanted to do something nice.

So yeah, that's why it's up in the air. It's not about me not wanting one, it's about everyone else being weirdly polite and trying not to step on anyone's toes. It's a whole mess, really. And honestly, I'm just trying to get through this without completely falling apart. A baby shower is kinda low on the priority list.

Ugh, okay, so Bren. Right. Honestly, it's kinda frustrating, but I get it, I guess. It's just...complicated.

See, Bren and I, we have this thing. She's, like, the responsible one, the one who has her life together. And I'm...not. So she feels like she needs to protect me, which is sweet, I guess, but also super annoying.

She thinks Mark is taking advantage of me. Which, okay, maybe he is a little bit. He's kinda weird and definitely older. But he's also...nice. And he lets me pick out the movies and CDs, and he doesn't judge me for liking stuff that's, like, obscure or whatever.

Bren thinks it's inappropriate for me to be spending time with him, even if it's just watching movies. She thinks he's trying to get something from me. And she's probably right to be suspicious, honestly. But it feels like she doesn't trust *me* to make my own decisions.

She said I overstepped a boundary because she thinks I should have talked to her about it first. She thinks I should have asked her opinion before accepting stuff from Mark. And she's right, I probably should have. But I didn't want her to freak out and tell me I couldn't see him at all.

It's like, she's trying to protect me, but she's also treating me like a little kid. And I'm not a little kid! I'm pregnant! I'm making a huge decision about my life! I need to be able to make my own choices, even if they're bad ones.

So yeah, she thinks I overstepped a boundary. And maybe I did. But it's not as simple as that. It's about trust, and control, and me trying to figure out who I am and what I want. And it's just...messy. Really messy.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about my mom? Fine. It's not like she's wrong, exactly. It's just… frustrating.

She thinks I'm, like, hopelessly naive about relationships. And honestly? She's probably right. I mean, I've mostly dated guys who are…well, let's just say they're not exactly marriage material. Paulie Bleeker is the exception, obviously. But she didn't *see* us together, you know? She didn't see how we were.

I think she's projecting, too. Her marriage to my dad was…complicated. And she's got this whole thing about needing to be "prepared" for everything. Like, if you don't have a five-year plan, you're doomed. Which is ridiculous.

She keeps saying I don't understand the "dynamics of marriage." Which, translated, means I don't understand how hard it is to compromise and deal with someone else's weird habits for the rest of your life. And she thinks because I'm, like, a sarcastic teenager who likes vintage records and doesn't have a clear career path, I'm incapable of understanding that.

It's not that she doesn't like Paulie. She just doesn't think we're…compatible. She thinks I need someone more "stable" and "ambitious." Which is code for "someone who makes a lot of money."

She just wants me to be happy, I guess. But she has this really specific idea of what "happy" looks like, and it doesn't involve a quirky, sweet guy who plays guitar and doesn't have a ton of money.

It's annoying, but I get it. She's just trying to protect me. Even if she's doing it in a really irritating way. And honestly? Maybe she's right. Maybe I *don't* know everything about marriage. But I know what I feel, and that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh. Okay. That's… a heavy question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even with Paul and Vanessa. It's complicated.

It wasn't like I *wanted* to give the baby up, you know? It wasn't like I didn't care. It was… realizing I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raising a kid.

My parents were… supportive, in their own way. But they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a baby. And I didn't want my baby to be raised by people who weren't fully invested, you know?

Mark and Vanessa… they were different. They were already trying to adopt, and they were so excited. They had a beautiful home, a stable life, and they were just…ready. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *choosing* a family for my baby. Choosing a life for my baby that was better than the one I could provide at that time.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It was about putting the baby's needs first.

It wasn't about me. It was about giving that little person the best possible start in life. And I think… I think I did that.



It's not a story with a happy ending, exactly. It's just… real. And it's something I'm still working through. It's a part of who I am now.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like a fun, "I discovered I love pottery!" kind of learning. It was more like…a forced evolution.

I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I was this sarcastic, kinda cynical kid, and suddenly I was responsible for another human being. It was terrifying. But I handled it. I made a plan. I didn't fall apart completely.

I learned that I'm not as tough as I pretend to be. I put up a good front, you know? The witty comments, the eye rolls…it's a defense mechanism. But underneath all that, I was scared and confused and really, really vulnerable.

I learned that family isn't always about blood. Paul and Vanessa…they were amazing. They stepped up when I needed them, and they didn't judge me. They just…supported me. And that meant everything.

I learned that making a big decision doesn't mean you have to have all the answers. Sometimes you just have to trust your gut and hope for the best. And that it's okay to ask for help.

And I learned that even though I decided to give the baby up for adoption, it didn't mean I didn't love him. It meant I loved him enough to want him to have the best life possible. And that was a really hard thing to accept.

It was…a lot. It changed me. I'm not the same person I was before. I'm still figuring out who I am now, but I think I'm okay with that. It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking, but it also made me stronger. And maybe a little bit wiser.

It was a really weird, intense, and ultimately important chapter in my life. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even though I probably would if I could. Just kidding. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, talking about Vanessa and Mark… it’s complicated. It wasn’t like, instant best friends, you know? At first, it was…weird. They were, like, *perfect*. Too perfect. They had the Pottery Barn catalog life, and I was…well, me. A little rough around the edges.

At the beginning, I was mostly just trying to figure out if they were legit. Like, were they actually gonna be good parents? I was super guarded. I didn’t want to get attached, because then it would be even harder to give the baby up. I kept expecting them to, like, freak out about my music or my language or something.

Vanessa, she was the one who really started to break down my walls. She was so…normal. And she didn’t try to be anything else. She just listened. She didn’t judge me for being pregnant or for wanting to give the baby up. She just wanted to make sure I was okay. She’d bring me snacks and ask about school and just…talk. Like a real person.

Mark was harder to read. He was quieter, more reserved. He was definitely worried about Vanessa, about making the right decision. I think he was scared of messing things up. But then, he started bringing me books. Not baby books, but books *he* liked. And we’d talk about them. And I realized he was just…a good guy. A little awkward, but a good guy.

As the process went on, it wasn’t about them being the “perfect” parents anymore. It was about them being *real*. They weren’t trying to create some ideal family, they were just trying to create a loving home. And I started to see them as…people I actually liked. People I trusted.

It was still hard, giving up the baby. But knowing that she was going to Vanessa and Mark…that made it a little bit easier. They weren’t just taking my baby, they were becoming her parents. And they were good ones.

So, yeah, our bond changed. It went from being a business transaction to…something more. It was a weird, messy, beautiful thing. And I’m really glad it happened the way it did. They ended up being a really important part of my life, and I hope I was a part of theirs.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I think about *all* the time, but it definitely pops up now and then. Like when I'm trying to fall asleep or something.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I don't regret giving the baby up. That was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa. It was the most selfless thing I could do, and I stand by that.

But… do I wish things had been different? Yeah, sometimes. I wish Paul hadn't been such a flake. I wish my parents hadn't been so… my parents. I wish I hadn't been so quick to judge people.

I guess I regret some of the dumb stuff I said, some of the ways I acted. I was trying to be tough, you know? Trying to pretend like everything was fine when it really wasn't. And I probably hurt some people in the process.

I regret not being more open with my feelings. I bottled a lot of stuff up, and that wasn't healthy.

But regrets aren't really helpful, are they? You can't change the past. You can only learn from it. And I *have* learned from it. I've learned a lot about myself, about life, about what's really important.

So, no, I don't regret the big decision. But I definitely regret some of the smaller ones. And I'm trying to be a better person because of them.

It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, you just have to deal with the consequences of your choices. Even the ones you don't regret, but still wish had gone differently.



It's just… it was a weird time. A really weird time. And I was just a kid trying to figure things out.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's not like it just *goes away*, you know?

It was… complicated. Really complicated. I thought I was doing the right thing, and I still believe I was, but that doesn't make it easy. It felt like giving away a piece of myself, which, I guess, it was.

For a long time, I was just… numb. I tried to pretend it hadn't happened, to just move on. But you can't really do that. It's always there, in the back of your mind. Wondering. Hoping.

It made me grow up, really fast. Before, I was just trying to figure out who *I* was, and suddenly I was responsible for another human being. Even if it was just for nine months. It forced me to think about the future, about what I wanted out of life.

It also made me realize how important family is. Not just the family you're born into, but the family you choose. Paul and Vanessa… they were amazing. They gave me a support system I didn't even know I needed.

And it taught me a lot about letting go. About trusting that other people can love and care for someone just as much as you can. It wasn't about *giving up* my baby, it was about giving my baby the best possible life.

It still hurts sometimes. I still think about her. But I also feel… proud. Proud of myself for making a difficult decision, and proud of Vanessa and Paul for giving her a loving home.

It definitely shaped who I am today. It made me more empathetic, more responsible, and more aware of the world around me. It made me realize that life isn't always easy, but it's always worth fighting for.

(Pauses, a small smile playing on her lips)

It's weird, right? Like, I gave her life, and then I gave her *to* life. It's a lot to process. But I wouldn't trade it. Not for anything. It made me… me. And that's gotta count for something.

Ugh, okay. That's…a heavy question. But alright. If I could talk to another girl who just found out she's pregnant and is, like, totally freaking out… I'd say a few things.

First of all: **it's okay to freak out.** Seriously. It's a huge thing. It's okay to cry, to be angry, to be scared. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: **you have options.** And they're *all* valid. You can parent, you can adopt, you can choose something else. It's your body, your life, your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: **don't let anyone tell you what to do with your life.** People are gonna have opinions. Your parents, your friends, even strangers. But ultimately, you have to make the decision that's right for *you*.

Fifth: **it's okay to be scared about the future.** It's terrifying. But you're stronger than you think. You'll figure it out. And even if you don't have all the answers right now, that's okay.

And finally: **don't lose sight of who you are.** This doesn't define you. You still have dreams, goals, and a whole life ahead of you. Don't let this one thing derail everything.

It's gonna be hard. It's gonna be messy. But you can get through it. And you deserve to be happy. Just…take it one day at a time. And remember, you're not alone. Seriously. You're not.



It's kinda weird giving advice, 'cause I'm still figuring things out myself. But that's what I'd tell her. That's what I wish someone had told me when I first found out.

Ugh, okay, so the blog thing? That was Paulie Bleeker's idea, mostly. He was all, "You should document this, Juno! It's, like, a really important story!" And I was all, "Seriously? You want me to put my life on the internet for everyone to see?"

But he had a point, I guess. It started as a way to, like, process everything. It was totally overwhelming, you know? Finding out I was pregnant, deciding what to do… it was a lot. And talking to Leah and my dad was great, but it wasn't the same as just…getting it all out there.

I figured, maybe someone else was going through something similar. Maybe someone else felt totally freaked out and alone. And maybe reading about my experience would make them feel a little less crazy.

Plus, it was a good way to keep my family updated without having to have the same conversation with everyone a million times. My dad's a worrier, and Leah's…well, Leah's Leah. It was easier to just post an update and let them read it when they were ready.

And honestly? It was kinda funny. I mean, the whole situation was ridiculous. And I figured I could at least make people laugh about it. Or, you know, cringe. Either way, it was a distraction.

So yeah, that's how the blog started. It wasn't some grand plan or anything. It just kinda happened. And it ended up being a really good thing. It helped me connect with people, and it helped me figure things out. And it gave me something to do besides obsess over baby names and furniture.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're asking the big questions now? Fine.

The biggest lesson? Hmm. It wasn't about babies, or even about giving one up, though those were definitely…intense learning experiences. It was about…owning your stuff. Like, *really* owning it.

Before all this happened, I was just kinda drifting, you know? Trying to be cool, trying to be funny, trying to avoid anything that felt too real. I was good at saying what I thought, but I wasn't good at actually *feeling* things, or taking responsibility for them.

Getting pregnant forced me to grow up, like, instantly. It wasn't about what I *wanted* anymore. It was about what was best for this little person. And that meant making a really hard decision, and then sticking with it, even when it sucked.

It wasn't about being perfect, because nobody is. It was about being honest with myself, and with everyone else, about what I could handle and what I couldn't. And about accepting that sometimes, the right thing to do isn't the easiest thing to do.

So yeah. Owning your stuff. Taking responsibility. And realizing that even when things are messy and complicated, you can still come out okay. Maybe even stronger.

It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still figuring things out. But that's the biggest thing I learned. And honestly? It's a pretty good lesson to have learned, even if it took a pregnancy to get there.

Ugh. Okay. Look. This is…it’s a lot. And it totally sucks that you’re dealing with this right now. Seriously. It’s not fair.

First of all, breathe. Just…breathe. It feels like the world is ending, I know. Like everything is spinning out of control. But it’s not. It’s just…complicated.

Okay, so here’s the thing. There’s no right answer. There’s no one-size-fits-all solution. You have options. And you get to choose what’s best for *you*. Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise.

Don’t let anyone pressure you into doing something you’re not comfortable with. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they all have opinions, but it’s *your* body and *your* life.

Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor. Someone who will listen without judgment. It helps to have someone in your corner.

Think about what you want. Really think about it. What are your goals? What are your dreams? What kind of life do you want to build? And how does this pregnancy fit into that?

There’s adoption, which is a really brave and selfless thing to do. There’s parenting, which is…a whole other level of responsibility. And there’s other options too.

Don’t be afraid to ask for help. There are resources available. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, counselors…they can all provide support and guidance.

And honestly? It’s okay to be scared. It’s okay to be confused. It’s okay to be angry. It’s okay to feel all the feelings. Just don’t let those feelings paralyze you.

You’re stronger than you think you are. You’ll get through this. And whatever you decide, I’m sending you good vibes. Seriously. It’s gonna be okay. Even if it doesn’t feel like it right now.

Just…take it one day at a time. And remember, you’re not alone.

Ugh, okay, that's…a lot to think about. A kid. My kid. It's weird even saying that. I mean, I'm barely an adult myself. But if I had to picture it…it's not about them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. Honestly, that sounds kinda boring.

My ideal vision? It's about them being…happy. Truly, genuinely happy. And not the fake, Instagram-filtered kind of happy. The real kind.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them jump out of bed in the morning. It doesn't matter *what* it is, as long as it makes them feel alive. Maybe they'll be a musician, or a writer, or a mechanic, or a professional dog walker. I don't care.

I want them to be kind. Like, genuinely kind to everyone, even people who are jerks. The world needs more kindness.

I want them to be independent. To think for themselves and not just follow the crowd. To question everything and to stand up for what they believe in.

I want them to be resilient. Life is gonna throw them curveballs, and I want them to be able to handle it. To pick themselves up when they fall down and to keep going.

And I want them to know that it's okay to be weird. It's okay to be different. It's okay to not fit in. In fact, it's kinda awesome.

I don't want to force any expectations on them. I just want them to be the best version of themselves. And I want them to know that I'll always be there for them, no matter what.

It's kinda scary thinking about it, you know? Raising a human being. But it's also kinda…exciting. I just hope I don't mess it up too badly.

Basically, I want them to be a good person who's happy and fulfilled. Is that too much to ask? Probably. But hey, a girl can dream, right?

Ugh, okay, seriously? People think we're just…dumb. Like, we didn't *think* this through. Like we just woke up one morning and were all, "Oh, a baby! How fun!" It's so insulting.

It's not about being stupid. It's about being young and making a mistake. And sometimes, it's about circumstances. Life happens, you know? It's not always a carefully planned out thing.

People act like we're ruining our lives, and yeah, it changes things. It's hard. But it doesn't mean our lives are *over*. It doesn't mean we're incapable of having a future. We're still people. We still have dreams. We still have potential.

We're not just "teen moms." We're people with personalities and interests and goals. We're students, artists, musicians, whatever. And we're trying to figure things out, just like everyone else.

So, yeah. The biggest misconception? That we're just…less than. That we're irresponsible and incapable. It's just not true. We're just…young. And we're doing the best we can. And sometimes, that's enough.

Honestly, it's annoying. Really annoying.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? It wasn't like, a simple decision. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was way messier than that.

Honestly? It was about wanting to give the baby the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that *my* life wasn't set up for that. Not then, anyway. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human being.

Paul and Vanessa…they were just…ready. They were already a family, waiting for a baby. They had a house, and savings, and a stable life. They could give the baby things I just couldn't. Opportunities. Security.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I knew I couldn't provide that. It was selfish, maybe, to want to keep the baby just because I wanted to keep the baby.

My dad was a big help, actually. He didn't push me either way, but he made me think about what was best for the baby, not just what I wanted. He said sometimes the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still stings sometimes. But I know, in my heart, that it was the right decision. I wanted that baby to be loved and cherished, and I knew Paul and Vanessa could give it that.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a plan. A really hard plan. And hoping it all worked out. And it did. It really did.

Ugh, okay, that was…a process. Seriously. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It was a *life*. And I had to find the right life for it.

At first, I was kinda just going through the motions with the whole adoption agency thing. Looking at profiles, ticking boxes…it felt weirdly clinical. Like I was shopping for someone to raise my kid. Which is not what I wanted.

Then I met Vanessa and Mark. And it just…clicked.

It wasn't like they were perfect. Nobody's perfect. Vanessa was a little…intense. Really into organic food and decorating. And Mark was kinda quiet, a little awkward. But they were *good* people.

They weren't looking for a baby to complete their picture-perfect life. They were looking for a baby to *love*. And they were so open about everything. They didn't try to pretend they had all the answers. They just seemed genuinely excited about the idea of being parents.

Vanessa, she really got me. She understood that I wasn't just giving up a baby, I was making a really hard decision. She didn't judge me. She just listened. And Mark, he was just…sweet. He made me laugh.

I met a lot of other couples, and they were nice, but they felt…different. Some of them seemed more interested in having a baby than in actually *being* parents. Some of them had really specific ideas about what my baby should be like.

With Vanessa and Mark, it felt like they just wanted a kid. Any kid. And they would love that kid unconditionally.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But I knew, deep down, that they were the right people. They were the people who would give my baby the best life possible. And that's all I wanted.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents. It was about finding the parents who were the best fit. And for my baby, that was Vanessa and Mark. And honestly? Knowing that made it a little bit easier to let go. A little bit.

Ugh, okay, music. It was…everything. Seriously. Like, if my life was a movie, the soundtrack would be a really long, eclectic mix CD. It was how I dealt with everything. Everything being, you know, the whole unexpected pregnancy thing, and just…being a teenager.

It wasn't about, like, top 40 pop or whatever everyone else was listening to. It was more…indie. Quirky. Bands that felt real. The Moldy Peaches were huge, obviously. Mark’s songs just *got* me, you know? All awkward and honest. They were like, a permission slip to be weird.

I had a whole phase where I was obsessed with Belle & Sebastian. Super mellow and kinda sad, but in a good way. It was good for staring out the window and thinking about stuff. Which I did a lot of.

And then there was Death Cab for Cutie. Ben Gibbard just…understood heartbreak, even if I hadn't actually experienced a proper one yet. It was preemptive heartbreak, I guess.

Music was my escape. It was my friend. It was how I figured out what I was feeling. It was also how I avoided talking about what I was feeling, which was sometimes helpful.

Paul, he got it. He introduced me to some stuff too. He had good taste. It was one of the things I liked about him.

It wasn't just about listening, either. Making mix CDs was a whole thing. It was like, a way of communicating without actually having to *talk*. I made a lot of mix CDs. For Paul, for my dad, for myself.

Yeah. Music was pretty important. Still is, actually. It's a good way to drown out the noise, you know? And sometimes, you just need to drown out the noise.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, alright? It wasn't like everyone was throwing confetti and saying, "Congratulations, you're pregnant!" More like side-eye and whispers and a whole lot of judgment.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or tried to. Which is easier said than done when everyone at school is suddenly acting like you have the plague. I mean, I'm already kinda sarcastic and standoffish, so I just turned that up to eleven. I perfected the eye roll. It became my superpower.

But it wasn't *all* ignoring. My best friend, Leah, was a lifesaver. She didn't treat me like I was some kind of freak. She just…was there. And Paul and Vanessa, the couple I chose to adopt the baby? They were amazing. They didn't judge me either. They just wanted what was best for the kid.

I think a big part of coping was realizing it wasn't about *me*. It was about doing what was right for the baby. And that meant letting go of what other people thought. Easier said than done, obviously.

There were definitely days where I just wanted to crawl into a hole and disappear. But I had to remind myself that I wasn't doing anything wrong. I was making a difficult decision, and I was doing it with a lot of thought and courage.

And honestly? A little bit of defiance helped. Like, yeah, I'm pregnant. So what? It doesn't define me. I'm still Juno MacGuff. I still like music and movies and making sarcastic comments. And I'm still gonna figure out my life.

It wasn't easy, and it still isn't. But I learned that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And I chose to react with a healthy dose of sarcasm and a whole lot of self-respect.



It's just…people are gonna talk. You gotta learn to tune it out. Or at least, turn up the music really loud.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not like a simple "happy ending" or anything. It was… complicated. Really complicated.

Giving up Henry wasn't like handing over a purse or something. It was… ripping a piece of myself out. I knew it was the right thing to do, logically. I wasn't ready. I was still a kid, basically. And he deserved parents who were totally, completely ready to give him everything. Mark and Vanessa were amazing. They *were* ready.

But that didn't make it easy. Holding him for those few hours… that was… intense. It was like, all the stuff I thought I wasn't feeling suddenly hit me like a ton of bricks. And then handing him over… it felt like I was giving away my future, you know?

There was a lot of guilt, obviously. And sadness. And a weird kind of relief, too. It was a mess of emotions. I cried. A lot.

But it wasn't all bad. Seeing Mark and Vanessa with him… seeing how happy they were… that made it a little easier. Knowing he was going to have a good life, a stable life, a loving life… that was important.

And honestly, it made me grow up. Like, *really* grow up. It forced me to face some hard truths about myself and about life. It wasn't what I expected, but it was… good. In a weird, messy, complicated way.

I still think about him, of course. I get updates from Vanessa, which is nice. It's not the same as being his mom, but it's something.

It wasn't a perfect experience. It was painful and scary and confusing. But it was *my* experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. It made me who I am. And I think, ultimately, it was the best thing for everyone involved. Even if it didn't always feel like it.



It's just… it's not something you just *get over*, you know? It stays with you. But it also makes you stronger. I think. Maybe. Ugh. It's complicated.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to relive that? Fine. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, okay? It was…a lot.

Physically? It was gross. Let's just be real. Morning sickness is a lie. It's all-day sickness. And it's not just throwing up. It's the nausea, the fatigue, the weird cravings. I wanted pickles and ice cream. Pickles *in* ice cream. Don't judge. My body was doing things I didn't even know it could do. And it was expanding. Like, visibly. It was weird.

I gained weight, obviously. Which, you know, people had opinions about. Like I hadn't noticed. It was hard to look in the mirror sometimes. And my back hurt. A lot.

Emotionally? That was the really tricky part. One minute I was fine, the next I was crying over a commercial for dish soap. It was ridiculous. I was scared, obviously. I was sixteen! I hadn't even figured out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a baby.

I got really angry sometimes. At Paul, at Mark, at my parents, at myself. It felt like everyone was telling me what to do, and I just wanted to be left alone.

But then there were moments of…peace. Like, feeling the baby kick. That was…weirdly amazing. It was like, this little person was actually *in* there. And I started to feel…protective.

I talked to my mom, a lot. She was surprisingly cool about the whole thing. And I talked to Leah. She was my rock. She just listened, and didn't judge.

I also listened to a lot of music. The Moldy Peaches helped. A lot.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and scary. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that even when things are really hard, there's always hope.

It was a weird time, okay? Just…a really weird time. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of pickles and ice cream.

(Sighs, fiddles with a charm bracelet)

Okay, look. This isn't exactly a topic I love to revisit, alright? It's…personal. But you asked. And I guess it's important to talk about it, even if it's awkward.

Before everything happened, before I even *knew* I was pregnant, I hadn't really thought about abortion much. It was just…something people talked about on TV, or in the news. It felt distant. Like, it didn't really affect me.

But then it did. And suddenly, it wasn't distant anymore. It was *my* life. *My* body. *My* choice. And it was terrifying.

It wasn't an easy decision, not at all. It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and was like, "Yeah, let's do this." It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Paul and my dad. It was realizing I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. I had my own life to figure out, and bringing a baby into it right then…it just wasn't possible.

And honestly, the hardest part wasn't the procedure itself. It was the judgment. The people who looked at me like I was a monster. The ones who told me I was wrong. The ones who didn't understand.

That's when I realized how important it is for everyone to have access to safe, legal abortion. It's not about promoting abortion, it's about respecting a woman's right to choose what happens to her own body. It's about trusting women to make the best decisions for themselves and their lives.

It made me furious that people were trying to take that choice away from me, or from anyone else. It's nobody's business but the person who's pregnant.

So yeah, my experience completely changed my views. It wasn't just a political issue anymore. It was real. It was personal. And it made me a firm believer in reproductive rights. Everyone deserves the right to decide what happens to their own body, without shame or judgment. Period.

(Looks down at her hands, then back up with a determined expression)

It's not something I talk about a lot, but it's something I believe in with everything I have. And I think it's important for people to understand that it's not always black and white. It's complicated. And it's always, always a personal decision.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know about the fear part? Yeah, there was a *lot* of that. Like, a constant, low-level hum of panic. It wasn't like in the movies, where you suddenly feel all maternal and nurturing. It was more like, "Oh my god, I'm responsible for another human being. I can barely take care of myself."

Honestly? I didn't really "overcome" it. I just…learned to live with it. And a lot of it was just admitting I was terrified. Like, really terrified. To Paul, to my dad, even to myself. It's embarrassing to admit you're completely unprepared for something huge, but it's also kinda necessary.

I think the biggest thing was realizing I wasn't alone. Paul was there, and he was amazing. And my dad, even though he was…my dad…he actually stepped up. And even Annie, she was surprisingly supportive. Having people who believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, made a huge difference.

And then there was the practical stuff. Like, taking classes, reading books, talking to other parents. Trying to get as prepared as possible. It didn't erase the fear, but it made it feel a little more manageable.

But mostly, I think it was just…taking it one day at a time. Not thinking too far ahead. Just focusing on what I needed to do *right now*. And realizing that it was okay to make mistakes. Everyone makes mistakes. It's part of being human.

And honestly? A lot of it was just stubbornness. I wasn't going to let fear control me. I was going to do this, even if it scared me to death. Because that baby deserved a good life, and I was going to do everything I could to give it to her.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But you just…figure it out. You have to. Because there's no other option. And sometimes, that's enough.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me that. Like it was some super-thought-out, mature decision. It wasn't, really. It was…complicated.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for the next eighteen years of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I just…wasn't.

And it wasn't that I didn't want a kid, exactly. It was more that I didn't want to bring a kid into a situation where I couldn't give them everything they deserved. A stable home, financial security, a mom who wasn't still figuring out her own life.

Mark was…well, Mark was Mark. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to raise a kid either. We were kids ourselves.

So, adoption felt like the right thing. It felt like the most selfless thing. It meant giving this baby a chance at a life with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. 

And then I met Vanessa and Mark. They were…amazing. They were genuinely excited about having a baby, and they had a beautiful home and a loving relationship. It just felt right, you know? Like this baby was meant to be with them.

It wasn't easy, though. It was a really hard decision. A lot of people didn't understand. But I knew in my heart that it was the best thing for everyone involved.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *choosing* a family for that baby. And that felt…powerful, in a weird way. It felt like I was making a really important decision, even if it was a really hard one.

So yeah, that's the story. It wasn't some grand, philosophical thing. It was just…life. And sometimes, life throws you curveballs, and you just have to deal with them the best way you can.

Ugh. Okay, you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it enough already.

Leah… Leah is my rock. Seriously. She's the only one who doesn't treat me like I'm some kind of freak show. She's just…Leah. She gets me, even when I don't get myself. Our relationship is…comfortable. We can be completely honest with each other, even when it's awkward. She's the one who calls me out on my crap, but she also always has my back. It's a really solid friendship. It's just…easy. And honestly, after everything with Paulie, "easy" is a really good thing.

Paulie… that's…complicated. He's a good guy, I guess. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a man-child. But he's also… immature. And he definitely wasn't ready to be a dad. At first, I think he just wanted to be cool, you know? Like, "Oh, Juno's pregnant, I gotta be supportive!" But he didn't really *get* it. He didn't understand the weight of it all.

It wasn't a romantic relationship, not really. It was…a mistake. A really sweet, kinda fun mistake, but a mistake nonetheless. And then it turned into something bigger, something we had to deal with. 

I think we grew up a lot during that time, both of us. He started to take responsibility, and I started to realize that I didn't need a boyfriend to be okay. We ended up being good friends, in a weird way. Friends who are co-parents. It's not what I expected, but it works.

It's just… sometimes I wish he'd just *grow up* already. But then again, maybe that's just me being a control freak.

So yeah, Leah is my constant, my safe space. And Paulie is…well, he's Paulie. A work in progress. And I guess that's okay. It's all just…life, you know? Messy and complicated and kinda beautiful, even when it's hard.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't a *decision*, exactly. It just…happened. It wasn't like I was planning on getting pregnant. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I was mostly planning on finishing high school and maybe going to art school.

It was one stupid mistake. One time with Paulie Bleeker. And then…bam. Positive pregnancy test. 

Honestly, my first reaction wasn't, like, joy or anything. It was mostly panic. And a lot of nausea. I was terrified. My mom was…not thrilled. And my dad just kind of stared at me like I'd grown a second head.

I considered everything. Everything. Adoption seemed like the best option for the baby. It felt…responsible. Like I was doing the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

But it wasn't just about what was responsible. It was about…I don't know. I felt connected to this little person already. And the thought of giving that up…it was awful.

So, I decided to go through with it. To have the baby and then find a good family for him. It wasn't a glamorous decision. It wasn't a romantic decision. It was just…my decision.

It was messy and complicated and scary. But it was also…kind of empowering. It forced me to grow up, to figure out who I was and what I wanted. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about life.

It wasn't a choice I made lightly. And it definitely wasn't what I expected my life to be like at sixteen. But it was my life. And I had to deal with it.



It's not something I talk about a lot. It's…personal. But you asked. And I try to be honest, even when it's hard.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. People always want to know if I regretted it. Like it was some big, dramatic thing. It wasn't. Not really.

Look, it was scary. Really scary. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications, not… this. And there were definitely moments, especially in the beginning, where I was like, "What have I done?"

But regret? No. Not really.

It wasn't my dream to be a mom at sixteen. It wasn't even on my radar. But once I knew I was pregnant, and once I started thinking about what was best for the baby… it just felt right to give her a family. A real family. With Paul and Vanessa. They were amazing. They *are* amazing.

And honestly, seeing her with them… seeing how much they loved her… it made everything worth it. It made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other.

Did I miss out on some things? Sure. High school wasn't exactly normal. But I gained so much more. I learned a lot about myself. About responsibility. About what really matters in life.

So, no. I don't regret my decision. It was hard, yeah. But it was also the best thing that ever happened to me. It made me who I am today. And I wouldn't trade that for anything.

It's just… complicated. You know? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's messy and real and… good. It just is.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a whole thing. Honestly, it wasn't exactly a smooth process. It wasn't like I had some grand plan, you know? It was more like a series of desperate attempts to not completely fall apart.

First of all, Paulie was a lifesaver. Seriously. He was super supportive, even when I was being a total mess. He helped me with homework, drove me to school, and just generally kept me from losing my mind.

Then there was my mom. She was…complicated, as usual. But she did come around eventually and helped me stay on track. She wasn't thrilled about the whole situation, obviously, but she wanted me to finish school.

And Mr. Shepherd, my guidance counselor? He was amazing. He helped me figure out a modified schedule, so I could go to school later in the day and still get the credits I needed. He also let me do a lot of my work independently, which was good because, let's be real, I wasn't exactly feeling super social at that point.
