It was a lot of late nights, a lot of caffeine, and a lot of just…pushing through. I had to learn to prioritize, which was hard for me, because I'm usually pretty good at procrastinating. And I had to accept help from other people, which is also hard for me, because I like to be independent.

Honestly, it was exhausting. But I knew I needed to finish school. Not just for me, but for the baby. I wanted to be able to provide for him, and I knew that a high school diploma was a good start.

So, yeah, I just…did it. One day at a time. It wasn't pretty, but I got through it. And honestly, looking back, I'm kind of proud of myself. It wasn't easy, but I didn't give up. And that's something.



It's not something I'd recommend, though. Definitely not. But hey, sometimes life throws you curveballs. You just gotta learn to swing.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like there was a flashing neon sign telling me what to do, you know? It wasn't easy. It was a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking to people.

Honestly? It wasn't about what I thought was "right" or "wrong." It was about what felt…less wrong. Abortion felt…heavy. Like, a really big, permanent decision. And I just wasn't ready for that. I wasn't ready to deal with all the feelings that would come with it.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…nice. Really nice. And they *wanted* a baby. Like, really, really wanted one. And they could give this kid a life I just couldn't. I was sixteen, still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being.

It wasn't about giving the baby away. It was about giving the baby *to* someone. To people who were ready and excited and could give it everything it needed. 

It wasn't a selfless act, okay? I'm not trying to pretend I'm some kind of saint. It was also about me. About not ruining my life. About finishing school and maybe going to college. About having a future.

It was complicated. It still is. But I knew, deep down, that choosing adoption was the best thing for everyone involved. For me, for the baby, and for Mark and Vanessa.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't perfect. But it was my decision. And I stand by it.



It's not something I talk about a lot. It's personal. But you asked, so… that's the honest truth.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Is this like, a pop quiz? Look, I've had a *lot* of time to think about this, okay? More than most people my age, probably. And yeah, absolutely. A thousand times yes.

It's not about the *who* that raises a kid, it's about the *how*. It's about love, and support, and stability. And you can find that in all kinds of families. Single parents, two moms, two dads, grandparents… it doesn't matter. What matters is that the kid feels safe and loved and has people who are gonna be there for them.

Honestly, the whole "traditional family" thing is kinda overrated. It's like, a Norman Rockwell painting. It doesn't reflect reality for a lot of people. And it definitely doesn't mean it's the *best* way to raise a kid.

I mean, look at my situation. My mom is…well, she's my mom. And she's awesome. But she wasn't exactly prepared for a baby. And it took a village, you know? Paul and Vanessa, they stepped up. They were the ones who actually knew what they were doing. And they gave me a good life.

So yeah, a child can absolutely thrive under non-traditional arrangements. Maybe even *more* than in a traditional one. Because it shows them that love comes in all shapes and sizes. And that family isn't about blood, it's about connection.

It's not about fitting into a box. It's about being loved for who you are. And that's what every kid deserves. Period. Don't even get me started if you think otherwise.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to dissect my own mess? Fine. Don't judge.

I think… my biggest weakness is probably that I build walls. Like, really high, really sturdy walls. And I let very few people in. It's a defense mechanism, obviously. I've had to be pretty self-reliant, you know? And letting people get close feels…risky.

I'm good at being sarcastic and deflecting, and making jokes about everything. It's easier than actually *feeling* things, or letting anyone see that I'm feeling them. It's a way to control the situation, I guess.

But it also means I can be kinda closed off and emotionally unavailable. And I push people away, even the ones I care about. It's stupid, I know. But it's hard to change.

I'm working on it, though. Paul and Vanessa…they kinda chipped away at the walls. But it's a slow process. And sometimes I just want to rebuild them, you know? It's safer that way.

It's just…I don't want to get hurt. And I don't want to hurt anyone else. So I keep my distance. It's a flawed strategy, I know. But it's the one I've been using for a long time.

So yeah. Building walls. That's my biggest flaw. Don't tell anyone I told you. It's embarrassing.

Ugh. Mark. Okay, so, that whole thing… it was a mess. A beautiful, confusing, kinda heartbreaking mess. Before Mark, relationships were… well, I hadn’t really *had* one. I’d seen my parents, and, you know, that was…complicated. And I definitely wasn’t picturing anything like what happened with him.

I went into it thinking I just needed someone to…be there. Someone to help with the baby, maybe. Someone who wouldn’t freak out about the whole situation. I didn’t think about *feelings*, really. I was so focused on the practical stuff.

And Mark was…good at the practical stuff. He was sweet, and supportive, and he didn’t judge me. But he wasn’t…*present*. He was always kinda drifting, you know? Like he was waiting for something else to happen.

It made me realize that you can’t just settle for someone who’s “good enough.” You need someone who actually *sees* you. Someone who’s willing to be fully invested, even when things are messy and complicated.

It also taught me that love isn’t just about grand gestures or romantic declarations. It’s about the little things. It’s about being there for someone, even when it’s inconvenient. It’s about really *listening* to them.

And honestly, it made me realize that I needed to figure out who *I* was before I could be in a healthy relationship. I was so caught up in the pregnancy and the adoption and everything else that I hadn’t really taken the time to think about what I wanted out of life.

So, yeah, Mark changed my perspective a lot. It wasn’t what I expected, and it definitely wasn’t easy. But it helped me grow up, and it helped me understand what I really needed in a partner. It taught me that settling is never worth it, and that real love is about more than just convenience. It's about connection. And I deserved that.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy question. But I get it. If someone's staring down a situation like I was, all tangled up and kinda terrifying… here's what I'd say.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Like, seriously. It's okay to freak out a little. Or a lot. It doesn't make you weak or a bad person. It just makes you a person.

Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it. There are people who care about you, even if you can't see them right now. Reach out. Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor… anyone. Don't try to carry it all yourself.

Third: **it's your decision.** And no one else gets to make it for you. Not your parents, not your boyfriend, not anyone. It's your body, your life, your future. You have to do what's right for *you*, even if it's hard.

Fourth: **don't let anyone shame you.** People are gonna have opinions. They're gonna judge. They're gonna say things that are hurtful and unhelpful. Ignore them. Their opinions don't matter. What matters is what *you* believe is the right thing to do.

Fifth: **it's okay to ask for help.** There are resources available. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, counselors… they can provide support and guidance.

And finally: **you are stronger than you think.** You're gonna get through this. It's gonna be hard, and it's gonna be messy, but you're gonna get through it. And you're gonna come out on the other side a stronger, more resilient person.

Look, it's not gonna be easy. But you're not alone. And you deserve to be happy. And you deserve to make the best decision for yourself, no matter what anyone else says.

Just…breathe. And remember that you're not defined by this situation. You're still you. And you're still awesome. Even if you don't feel like it right now.

Ugh. My dad. Okay, so it wasn't…smooth sailing at first, you know? He's a good guy, really. Just…kinda spacey. Always building stuff in the garage, always with the guitar. Not always *present*, if that makes sense?

When I found out I was pregnant, it was…a lot. He was definitely freaked out. Not angry, just…overwhelmed. He kept trying to fix things, like he could just *build* a solution to the problem. Offered to build me a nursery, which was…sweet, but also completely missing the point.

For a while, it was mostly awkward silences and him trying to be supportive in a way that felt really clumsy. He'd bring me ginger ale and ask if I needed anything, but he couldn't really talk about it. It was like the whole thing was too big for him to process.

But then, slowly, things started to change. He started actually *listening*. Not just waiting for his turn to talk, but really listening to what I was saying. He started asking questions, trying to understand what I was going through.

And he started helping with the practical stuff. Not building a nursery, but helping me research adoption agencies, going with me to appointments. He wasn't trying to fix things anymore, he was just…being there.

It wasn't a sudden transformation, it was gradual. But over time, we built this…connection. He's still kinda spacey, and he still plays the guitar at inappropriate times, but he's my dad. And he loves me. And I love him.

I think having a baby on the way forced him to grow up a little bit. It forced him to confront some stuff he'd been avoiding. And it forced *me* to see him as more than just my dad, but as a person with his own struggles and vulnerabilities.

It's still a work in progress, you know? But it's a good work in progress. And I'm grateful for that. He's…he's a good dad. Even if he's a little weird.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the essays. Like, it was some magical gift or something. It wasn't. It was mostly just…avoidance. And a lot of staring out the window.

Honestly, I think it started because I was just really good at observing people. Like, really *watching* them. And listening. High school is a goldmine for weirdness, you know? You just gotta pay attention.

I wasn't a big reader, not at first. I liked comic books and magazines, stuff with pictures. But then Mr. Meeker, my English teacher, he kinda forced us to read some actual books. And some of them were…okay. They made me think.

But the writing itself? It wasn't about following rules or trying to be fancy. It was about finding the right words to describe what I was feeling, or what I was seeing. And being honest. Even if it was awkward or embarrassing.

I think I also developed it because I was trying to figure things out. Like, who I was, what I wanted, what was going on with my life. Writing was a way to process all that stuff. It was like talking to myself, but on paper.

And I definitely rewrote things a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. Mr. Meeker was good about giving feedback, but mostly I just kept tinkering with it until it felt right.

So, yeah. Observation, honesty, rewriting, and a healthy dose of teenage angst. That's pretty much the secret. It wasn't about being a "good writer," it was about being *me* on the page. And sometimes, that's enough.



Don't overthink it, okay? Just write what you feel. And don't be afraid to be weird. Weird is good.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? There was a lot of side-eye, a lot of whispers, and a whole lot of people having opinions about my life that they weren't invited to have.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or, like, pretended to ignore it. I perfected the art of the withering stare. It's surprisingly effective.

But it wasn't always easy. My school was… not thrilled. Some people were just straight-up mean. And my dad? He was… processing. It took him a while to come around.

What really helped was having a few people who *didn't* judge me. My best friend, Leah, was amazing. She didn't even blink. She just started researching adoption agencies with me. And my mom, even though she was freaked out, she was still my mom. She just wanted me to be okay.

And Paul and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt my baby? They were incredible. They treated me with respect and kindness, and they made me feel like I was making the right decision.

I think I also just…owned it. I wasn't ashamed of what was happening. It wasn't ideal, but it was my life. And I was going to deal with it on my own terms. I didn't need anyone's permission to be me.

I also used humor. A lot of it. Sarcasm is a great defense mechanism. It lets you deflect and keep people at arm's length.

It wasn't about pretending everything was perfect. It was about finding the people who supported me, ignoring the haters, and focusing on what was best for my baby. And, you know, trying to maintain a little bit of my sanity in the process.

It sucked sometimes, but I got through it. And honestly? It made me stronger. It taught me a lot about myself and about the world. And it made me realize that people's opinions don't define you. Your actions do.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. One I don't always like to think about, honestly.

Do I regret being outspoken? Sometimes. Yeah. There were definitely times when my mouth got me into trouble. Like, *major* trouble. Saying what I thought, even when it wasn't what people wanted to hear, didn't always make things easier. It made things…complicated.

Especially with my dad. He's a good guy, but he's…sensitive. And I wasn't always the most sensitive person. I said things, and they stung. And I felt bad about that.

But then I think about the alternative. If I hadn't been honest, if I hadn't said what was on my mind, I wouldn't have been *me*. I wouldn't have been able to navigate all the craziness with the pregnancy and the adoption and everything else.

Being honest, even when it's hard, is just…who I am. It's how I process things. It's how I connect with people. And it's how I protect myself.

So, do I regret it? Not really. Maybe I wish I'd been a little more tactful sometimes. Maybe I wish I'd thought things through a little more before I spoke. But I wouldn't trade my honesty for anything. It's what makes me, me.

And honestly, the world needs more people who are willing to say what they think, even when it's unpopular. Even when it's uncomfortable.

So, yeah. I'm a work in progress. But I'm okay with being a little bit rough around the edges. It's part of the package.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. Seriously. It's like, everyone has an opinion on what you should be doing with your life, especially when you're, you know, pregnant and a teenager. It's exhausting.

Honestly? I mostly just ignore them. Which sounds easier than it is, believe me. But you gotta learn to tune out the noise. People are gonna judge you no matter what you do. If you wear too much makeup, if you don't wear enough, if you're too loud, if you're too quiet…it's endless.

The key is to figure out what *you* want. What makes *you* happy. And then just…do that. Even if it's not what everyone else thinks you should do.

I mean, my dad, he was worried. My mom, she was trying to be supportive, but I could tell she was kinda freaked out. And everyone at school? Forget about it. They were all whispering and staring.

But I knew I wasn't gonna just…disappear. I wasn't gonna give the baby up and pretend it never happened. That wasn't me. So I made a decision, and I stuck with it.

It's not about being defiant, it's about being honest with yourself. And it's about finding people who support you for who you are, not for who they want you to be. Paul and Vanessa, they were good at that. They didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. They just…listened.

And honestly? Sometimes you just gotta roll your eyes and walk away. You can't waste your energy trying to please everyone. It's impossible.

So, yeah. Stay true to yourself. It's the only thing that really matters. And if people don't like it? That's their problem, not yours. Just keep on keepin' on. And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. It helps.

Ugh, values. That sounds…intense. Like a guidance counselor is about to ask me about my five-year plan. But okay, fine. If I *have* to think about what's important to me…

I guess first and foremost, it's **honesty**. Not necessarily telling people what they *want* to hear, but being real. With myself and with others. It's messy, but it's better than pretending.

Then there's **independence**. I like being able to do my own thing, make my own decisions, and not have to rely on anyone else. It's not that I don't appreciate help, it's just…I need to feel like I'm in control of my own life.

**Authenticity** is a big one too. Just being myself, even if it's weird or awkward or unpopular. I don't want to be someone I'm not just to fit in.

And I think **loyalty** is important. To the people I care about. I might not always show it in the most obvious ways, but I'll always have their back.

And…okay, this is kinda embarrassing to admit, but **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. You gotta be able to laugh at yourself and at the absurdity of everything.

I guess those are the things that matter to me. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I try to aim for. It's about being a decent person, I guess. And not being a total sellout.



Don't tell anyone I said all that. It's kinda vulnerable.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges, honestly. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park. But if I had to pick *the* biggest one… it wasn't the morning sickness, or the weird cravings, or even telling my parents.

It was probably just… dealing with everyone else's opinions.

Like, suddenly *everyone* had an opinion on what I should do. My parents, obviously. My friends. Even people at school I barely knew. Everyone was telling me what was right, what was wrong, what I *should* feel. 

And it was exhausting. It felt like my body was already being taken over, and now everyone was trying to take over my brain too.

I just wanted to be left alone to figure things out for myself. I wanted to make my own decision, without feeling like I was letting anyone down. 

It was hard to stay true to myself when everyone was trying to tell me who I should be. And it was hard to remember that it was *my* life, *my* body, and *my* choice.

So yeah, dealing with all the outside noise. That was the hardest part. It made everything else seem a million times harder. It's like, can a girl just be pregnant in peace? Apparently not.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not like a light switch flipped, you know? It's more like a slow burn, a gradual shift in everything.

Before, my life felt…small. Like, contained within the walls of my school and my town. I was focused on getting good grades, making sarcastic comments, and avoiding responsibility. I thought I had it all figured out, which, looking back, was ridiculous.

Having a kid…it just makes everything feel bigger. More important. It's like suddenly you're responsible for this tiny human being, and their entire future rests, at least partially, on your shoulders. It's terrifying and amazing all at the same time.

I used to think I was pretty independent, pretty self-sufficient. And I am, in a way. But now I realize that needing people isn't a weakness, it's a strength. I rely on my parents, on Mark, on all sorts of people to help me navigate this whole motherhood thing.

It's also made me a lot less judgmental. Before, I was quick to size people up, to make snap decisions about them. Now, I realize that everyone is fighting their own battles, and you never really know what someone else is going through.

And honestly? It's made me a little less cynical. I still have my moments, don't get me wrong. But there's something about looking at this little person and seeing all the potential in the world that just…softens you.

It's not always easy. It's exhausting and messy and sometimes really frustrating. But it's also the most rewarding thing I've ever done. It's made me realize what truly matters in life. It's not about being cool or popular or having all the answers. It's about love, and connection, and creating a safe and happy world for the next generation.

It's…complicated. But good. Really good. It's made me a better person, I think. Or at least, I'm trying to be.



It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring it all out. But that's okay. That's life. And now, it's a life with a little person in it, and that changes everything.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that guy. He's a real jerk. He shows up at the *worst* times, usually when you're already kinda freaking out about something else.

Honestly? I don't have some super profound answer. It still gets to me. But I've learned a few things.

First, I try to remember that everyone feels that way sometimes. Even people who seem totally confident are probably second-guessing themselves. It's just…they're better at hiding it.

Second, I talk to someone. Like, a real person. Not just thinking about it in my head for three hours. My best friend, Leah, is good at that. She'll just listen and then tell me I'm being ridiculous. Which is usually true.

Third, I try to focus on what I *can* control. Like, I can't control what other people think of me, or what's going to happen in the future. But I can control my own actions. So I try to focus on doing the best I can in the moment.

And sometimes, I just have to let myself feel it. Like, okay, I'm doubting myself. That's fine. It sucks, but it's okay. And then I try to move on.

It's not about getting rid of the self-doubt completely. It's about not letting it paralyze you. It's about recognizing it for what it is – just a feeling – and then choosing to do what you need to do anyway.

It's kinda like…when you're driving and you're not sure which way to go. You just pick a direction and hope for the best. Sometimes you end up in the wrong place, but sometimes you discover something new.

So yeah. Self-doubt. It's a pain. But you can get through it. Just…don't let it win.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But…it's actually really important. Don't tell anyone I said that. It sounds kinda soft.

Look, I try to act like I'm totally independent and don't need anyone, but that's…not entirely true. Especially now. Before all this baby stuff, I was pretty good at keeping people at arm's length. It was easier. Less messy.

But then I got pregnant, and suddenly I needed help. I needed someone to talk to, someone to go to the doctor with, someone to just…be there. And that's when I realized how much I relied on Leah and Paul. And even my dad, even though he's…my dad.

They didn't judge me, you know? They just…supported me. Even when I was being a total mess. And that made all the difference.

I think…I think everyone needs a community. People who get you, who understand you, who will be there for you when things get tough. It's not about needing to be rescued, it's about having people to share the journey with.

It's about having someone to laugh with, someone to cry with, someone to just…be real with.

So yeah, community and social support are important. Really important. Even if I don't always show it. It's kinda like…a safety net. And sometimes, you just need a safety net.

Don't tell anyone I said all this, okay? I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be the sarcastic, independent one. But secretly? I'm just a girl who needs her friends.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? But if I had to pick *one* thing, the most important lesson… it wasn't about the baby, or even about being a mom. It was about realizing that life doesn't always go according to plan.

I thought I had everything figured out. I was gonna go to college, be a writer, have a cool, independent life. And then…bam. Pregnant. It totally threw everything off course.

At first, I was freaking out. Like, majorly. But then I realized that just because things didn't turn out the way I expected didn't mean they couldn't still be good. It just meant I had to be flexible, and open to new possibilities.

And it wasn't about giving up on my dreams, it was about redefining them. It was about figuring out how to make my life work *with* this new reality, instead of fighting against it.

So, yeah. The most important lesson was learning to let go of control. To accept that life is messy and unpredictable, and that sometimes the best things happen when you least expect them. And that even when things are scary and uncertain, you can still find strength and happiness.

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. It really is.

Ugh, that's a good question. And honestly? I don't know. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. That seems… exhausting.

But yeah, I *do* like writing. I mean, I'm pretty good at it, if I do say so myself. It's just… a good way to get my thoughts out, you know? And it's kinda satisfying to put words together in a way that makes people feel something.

I don't know if I want to be a *professional* writer, though. That sounds… stressful. Like, having to come up with ideas on demand and meet deadlines and stuff. I'm more of a write-when-I-feel-like-it kind of person.

Maybe I'll just keep it as a hobby. Or maybe I'll write a novel someday. A really sarcastic, funny novel about teenage pregnancy and the absurdity of life. That could be good.

Paul keeps telling me I should write a book. He thinks my voice is "unique." Which is a nice way of saying I'm kinda weird.

So, yeah, maybe. I haven't ruled it out. But don't expect to see my name on the New York Times bestseller list anytime soon. I'm just trying to figure out what I want to do with my life, one sarcastic observation at a time.

It's all very… up in the air. Which is kinda how I like it, actually.

Ugh, okay, the baby name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, a logical decision, you know? It wasn't like, "Oh, this name means this and it's historically significant." It was more…a feeling.

Paul, he wanted to name the baby "Peter." Peter! Like, seriously? So boring. And Annie, she had a whole list of names, all very…Annie. Very earthy and granola. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but it wasn't really my style.

I kept thinking about names that felt…strong. And a little bit quirky. And not too common. I wanted the baby to have a name that would let her be herself, you know?

And then, I was looking at a map, and I saw the town of Havenwood. And I just…liked the sound of it. Haven. It means like, a safe place. And Wood…it just felt solid and grounded.

So, I suggested Haven. And Annie and Paul both liked it. It was a compromise, I guess. But it felt right. It felt like a name that would fit her.

And then, we added the middle name Grace. Because Annie's mom's name was Grace, and it felt like a nice way to honor her.

So, Haven Grace. It's a good name. I think she'll like it. It's not Peter. That's the important thing.

It's weird, though. Thinking about a name for someone you haven't even met yet. It feels…big. And important. And kinda scary. But also kinda amazing.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, confusing, and sometimes terrifying rollercoaster that smelled faintly of hospital disinfectant.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was good at being sarcastic and pretending I didn't care, but inside… it was a mess. I mean, I *knew* I was making the right decision, logically. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that there were people who could give the baby a better life. But knowing that and *feeling* okay about it were two totally different things.

There were a lot of tears. A lot of late-night talks with Paul and Vanessa. A lot of just… sitting around feeling sad and confused. I kept second-guessing myself. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Would the baby hate me?

What really helped was talking. Like, *really* talking. Not just making jokes to deflect, but actually being honest about how I was feeling. Paul and Vanessa were amazing. They didn't try to tell me what to do, they just listened. And they reminded me that it was okay to be sad, and that it didn't mean I was a bad person.

And honestly, meeting Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted the baby… that made a huge difference. They were so kind and genuine, and I could see how much they wanted a child. It made me feel better knowing that the baby was going to a loving home.

It still hurt, though. It hurt a lot. And it took a long time to process. But eventually, I realized that giving the baby up wasn't about giving something *away*. It was about giving something *to*. It was about giving the baby the best possible life.

And that, I think, is what helped me cope. Knowing that I had made a selfless decision, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

It's still… complicated. But I'm okay. I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to be okay with the fact that sometimes, the right thing to do is also the hardest thing to do.



It's not a story with a neat little bow on top, you know? It's messy and real and complicated. And that's okay.

Ugh, okay, music. That's a good question. It kinda depends on my mood, honestly. Sometimes I need something loud and angry, sometimes I need something quiet and sad. But mostly, I like stuff that feels…real. You know? Not all polished and fake.

I'm a big fan of **The Moldy Peaches**, obviously. They're just…honest. And kinda weird. And they make me feel things.

So yeah, that's my music taste in a nutshell. It's kinda all over the place, but it all makes sense to me.

Ugh. Okay, that's a good question. It's…complicated. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just…not me.

Their house was…perfect. Like, magazine-perfect. Everything was coordinated and clean and smelled faintly of potpourri. Which, honestly, is my personal hell. My house is comfortably messy. It smells like pizza and old books. Theirs smelled like…aspirations.

It wasn't that I didn't think they'd be good parents. They clearly would be. It was just…different than anything I knew. It made me realize how much I wanted the baby to have a good life, but also how important it was for that life to be…authentic.

It was a weird feeling. Relief, and sadness, and a little bit of anxiety. It made me even more sure that I was doing the right thing, even though it was the hardest thing I'd ever done.

It wasn't about them being bad people. It was about them being…different. And realizing that different doesn't mean worse, it just means different. And that sometimes, different is exactly what a baby needs.

It wasn’t about being good, or even writing good songs. It was about having something to do, and being with people who made me laugh. And honestly, it was kinda therapeutic. Screaming into a microphone is a surprisingly good stress reliever.

So yeah, that’s how it happened. Boredom, a persistent French boy, and a desperate need to distract myself. It wasn’t exactly a master plan. It was just…a thing that happened. And it was kinda awesome. Even if our band name was terrible.

Okay. Wow. That's… a big one. And honestly, it's a really brave question to ask. If I was still… going through it, I'd want someone to just *tell it like it is*. So here it is.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. All of it. You're allowed to feel everything. Don't let anyone tell you how you *should* feel.

Second: you are not alone. Seriously. It feels like it, I know. But there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: you have options. And they're all valid. You can parent, you can adopt, you can choose to terminate the pregnancy. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: it's going to be hard. No matter what you choose. There will be challenges and setbacks. But you are stronger than you think. You can get through this.

Fifth: don't let this define you. You are more than just a pregnant teenager. You have dreams and goals and a future. Don't give up on them.

And finally: be kind to yourself. You're doing the best you can. And that's enough.

I know it's overwhelming. I know it feels like your whole world is falling apart. But it's not. You can rebuild. You can create a good life for yourself and for your baby, if you choose to.

Just remember to breathe. And to ask for help. And to believe in yourself. You got this. Even when you don't think you do.



Seriously. You do. And if you ever just need someone to listen, even a sarcastic, cynical teenager from a movie, I'm here. (Well, digitally, anyway.)

Ugh. Okay, the pre-adoption counseling. Right. That was…a lot. Honestly? It felt like being dissected by a bunch of well-meaning, but ultimately clueless, adults.

It wasn't *bad*, exactly. The people were nice enough. But it was just…intense. So many questions. So many feelings. They wanted to know everything. Like, did I fully understand the implications? Was I sure I wasn't doing this for selfish reasons? Did I have a support system?

And I get it, I really do. They were trying to make sure I was making the right decision, and that the baby would go to a good home. But it felt like they were questioning my maturity, my ability to be a responsible person. Like they didn't trust me.

It was also weirdly…clinical. Like I was a case study, not a person. They kept talking about "attachment issues" and "grief counseling." It made me feel like I was already mourning a baby I hadn't even given birth to yet.

I think the hardest part was talking about my parents. They wanted to know if I felt supported by them, if they understood my decision. And it was just…complicated. They were trying, but they didn't really *get* it.

It did help, though, to talk to someone who wasn't involved in the situation. Someone who could just listen and offer advice. And it made me think about things I hadn't considered before.

But mostly, it just felt like a really long, awkward interrogation. And honestly, I just wanted it to be over. I just wanted to get through it and move on.

It wasn't fun. But I guess it was necessary. It made me think things through, and it helped me feel more prepared. Even if it also made me want to run away and join the circus.

Ugh, that's a good question. A really good question. And honestly? It's complicated.

At first, yeah, I *thought* I did. I was the one who picked the couple, right? I interviewed them, I met them, I decided Mark and Vanessa were the best fit. So, in my head, it was all me. My decision. My baby.

It wasn't that they were trying to take control *from* me, exactly. They were just trying to do what they thought was best. And they all had their own ideas about what that was.

I wanted a perfect situation, you know? A perfect family. And I started to realize that "perfect" doesn't really exist. There were compromises to be made, things I had to let go of. 

So, did I feel like I had control? I guess…partially. I had a voice, and they listened. But it wasn't as simple as just picking a family and saying, "Okay, this is it." It was a lot more nuanced than that.

It was scary, honestly. Giving up a baby is scary enough. But giving up control, too? That was a whole other level of scary.

But in the end, I realized that control isn't everything. What mattered most was finding a loving home for the baby. And I think I did that. Even if it meant letting go of some of my own expectations.



It's still something I think about, you know? Whether I made the right choices. But I try not to dwell on it. Because ultimately, it wasn't about me. It was about the baby.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. And honestly? It's one I still think about, even now.

It's not like it was an easy decision, you know? It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And there were a lot of nights I just… lay awake and wondered if I was doing the right thing.

Not because it was easy. Not because it didn't hurt. But because it was the best thing for the baby. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being ready to raise a kid. I wasn't ready to give a baby the life it deserved.

Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give that baby everything I couldn't. And knowing that… knowing that my kid was going to be loved and cared for and have opportunities… that made it a little bit easier.

It doesn't mean I didn't grieve. It doesn't mean I didn't wonder what my life would have been like if I'd kept it. But I think… I think I made the right choice.

It forced me to grow up, you know? It forced me to take responsibility for my actions. And it taught me a lot about myself.

So yeah. I would do it again. Because sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is let go. Even when it breaks your heart.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept asking me if I was sad, and I was, but it wasn't just *sad*. It was… complicated.

For a while, it felt like a big empty space. Like, I carried this kid for nine months, and then suddenly… they weren't there anymore. It was weird. And I felt guilty, even though I knew I was doing the right thing. Like, was I giving up on something important? Was I being selfish?

I mostly just tried to distract myself. Hung out with Paul, listened to a lot of music, watched bad movies. I tried to pretend like everything was normal, but it wasn't.

Bren was… Bren was Bren. She was supportive, but also kinda blunt. She told me it was okay to feel whatever I was feeling, even if it was messy and confusing.

I think the biggest thing that helped was talking to Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted the baby. They were really open and honest, and they let me be a part of the process. Knowing that the baby was going to a good home, with people who loved them, made it a little bit easier.

It took a long time to feel okay. And I still have moments where I think about them, and wonder how things are going. But I realized that giving the baby up wasn't about giving up on *them*. It was about giving them the best possible life. And that's something I can be proud of.

It's not something you just "get over," you know? It's part of who I am now. It made me stronger, and it taught me a lot about myself. And it definitely made me appreciate the people who love me.

So, yeah. It was hard. But I got through it. And I think, in the end, it was the right thing to do. Even if it still kinda stings sometimes.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, alright? It's not like they were *bad* people, Mark and Vanessa were genuinely good folks. But it was…complicated.

The biggest thing was expectations, I think. They had this image in their heads of what the "perfect" baby and adoption would look like. And I was…not that. I was a teenager, for crying out loud. I had opinions. And a mouth. And a very specific taste in music.

Vanessa, she was really into all the baby stuff. Like, decorating the nursery and picking out names. And I appreciated that, but it felt weird, you know? Like she was already claiming the baby as hers before I even gave birth.

Mark was quieter, but he had his own issues. He kept asking me if I was *sure* I wanted to go through with it. Like he was trying to convince me to change my mind. Which was not helpful.

There were a few really tense meetings with the social worker, trying to mediate. And a lot of awkward silences. It was just…a lot.

I think they were scared, too. Scared of messing things up, scared of not being good enough parents. And I was scared of making the wrong decision.

It took a lot of talking, and a lot of compromise, to get to a place where we all felt comfortable. And even then, it wasn't perfect. But we got there. And in the end, it was the right thing to do. For everyone.

It just wasn't easy. It's never easy, is it?

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I think about every day, but it definitely comes up. It was… complicated.

It's weird to think about, but I wouldn't trade the experience, even with all the awkwardness and the stress. It made me *me*.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…not fun. It was like, suddenly everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life, and none of them were asking for one. It was seriously invasive.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to ignore it. Which is easier said than done when you're walking down the halls at school and people are whispering and staring. I perfected the art of looking straight ahead and pretending I didn't hear anything.

Paul was really good about it. He was like, "They're just jealous they don't have a cool story." Which, okay, maybe he was right. But it didn't make it any less annoying.

My friend Leah was a lifesaver. She just told everyone who asked to mind their own business. She's got that kind of fierce loyalty that I really appreciate.

I also just… leaned into the awkwardness. I mean, what were people gonna do? Judge me more? I was already being judged. So I just tried to be myself, and I didn't apologize for anything.

It helped to remember that most of the gossip was probably just people trying to fill the void in their own lives. Like, they were bored and needed something to talk about. It didn't make it right, but it made it a little easier to deal with.

And honestly, it made me realize who my real friends were. The people who stuck around and supported me, those were the ones who mattered. The rest? They could just go bother someone else.

It sucked, though. It really did. It was a reminder that people can be really cruel. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. And that's something, right?

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not easy to talk about, even now. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

Honestly? I was just… not ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a whole human being. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I could barely keep my own life together, how could I be responsible for another person?

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted her to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and able to provide for her, opportunities I just couldn't give her. Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They could give her a life I just couldn't.

It wasn't about not loving her. I loved her. I *do* love her. It was about wanting what was best for her, even if it meant making the hardest decision of my life.

It was scary. It was heartbreaking. It still is, sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't giving up on her, it was giving her a chance.

And honestly, I wasn't sure I could be the mom she deserved. Not yet. Maybe someday, but not then. I needed to grow up, figure things out, become a person who could actually handle being a parent.

It was a messy, complicated, and really, really hard decision. But it was my decision. And I stand by it. It was the best thing for her. And, in a weird way, it was the best thing for me, too. It forced me to grow up, to take responsibility, and to figure out who I was.



It's not a story with a neat little bow on top. It's just… life. And sometimes, life is messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also beautiful, and hopeful, and full of possibilities.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. And a hard one. It wasn't, like, a monster under the bed kind of fear. It was…more complicated than that.

I think my biggest fear wasn't that *I* wouldn't be a good mom, because I knew I would be. It was that they – Mark and Vanessa – wouldn't be.

I know that sounds awful, right? Like I didn't trust them. But they were so…perfect. You know? Like, Pottery Barn catalog perfect. And I was just…me. Messy, sarcastic, a little bit cynical. I worried they'd try to mold the baby into something it wasn't, or that they wouldn't understand when things got hard.

I wanted the baby to be loved, unconditionally. And I wanted it to be *okay* if it wasn't perfect. I didn't want it to feel like it had to live up to some impossible standard.

It was scary handing over something so…important. Something that was growing *inside* me. And trusting someone else to take care of it. Even though I knew they were good people.

I guess I was afraid of losing control. Of not being able to protect the baby, even after I gave it up. It was a weird mix of wanting the best for it and being terrified of what "the best" might look like.

It sounds dumb when I say it out loud, but that was it. That was the thing that kept me up at night. Just hoping that the baby would be happy. And that Mark and Vanessa would let it be…itself.

Ugh, okay, you wanna know about Bleeker? Seriously? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing.

Well, it wasn't like I *planned* on naming the baby's father "Bleeker." It just…happened. It was a whole process of elimination, really. I needed a name for him in the essay, right? For school. And I wanted something…unassuming. Something that didn't scream "teen pregnancy."

I started with a list of names I just…knew he wouldn't have. Like Chad. Or Brad. Too cliché. Then I started thinking about music. He was a musician, after all. And I remembered this band, The Bleeker Street Band. They weren't super famous, but they were kinda cool.

And "Bleeker" just…stuck. It sounded kinda artsy and sensitive, which I figured he was. And it wasn't a super common name, so it didn't feel like I was trying too hard.

Plus, it sounded kinda…sad. Which, let's be real, the whole situation was kinda sad.

So yeah, that's how I came up with "Bleeker." It wasn't a deep, meaningful choice. It was just…the best of a bad bunch. Don't judge me, okay? I was sixteen and trying to write an essay about a really complicated situation. It wasn't exactly a time for careful consideration.

It's a dumb name, honestly. But it worked for the essay. And it kinda became a thing. People still ask me about it. It's weird.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole punk thing? It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It just…fit. Everything else felt so fake and polished, and punk was just…raw. Real.

I think it started with the music. It wasn't about being technically perfect or having a pretty voice. It was about energy and attitude and saying what you actually *felt*, even if it was angry or messed up. Like, The Moldy Peaches, they're not exactly hardcore punk, but they have that same honesty. It's just…unfiltered.

And then it was the clothes. I wasn't trying to make a statement or anything. It was just…comfortable. And it felt like a middle finger to all the people who were trying to tell me what to wear and how to act. Like, yeah, I'm gonna wear combat boots and a thrift store jacket. What are you gonna do about it?

It wasn't about being rebellious for the sake of being rebellious, either. It was about not wanting to be part of the mainstream. It was about finding your own voice and not being afraid to use it.

My dad, he didn't really get it. He was more of a classic rock guy. But he always supported me, even when he didn't understand what I was into. He just wanted me to be happy.

I guess it was just a way of figuring things out. Trying to find my place in the world. And punk, with all its flaws and contradictions, felt like a place where I could be myself. A place where it was okay to be different. A place where it was okay to be a mess.

It's kinda embarrassing to talk about now, honestly. But it was important. It helped me become who I am. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I usually just *talk* about, you know? But you asked.

It messed me up, honestly. Seeing my parents just… not work. Like, they weren't fighting, exactly. It was more like they just grew apart. And it made me really scared of commitment. Like, what if I picked the wrong person and ended up just… drifting away from them too?

With Paul, it was… complicated. I was so afraid of getting too close, of letting myself actually *care* about someone. I kept trying to push him away, to convince myself I didn't need anyone. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. I didn't want to end up like my parents.

And then, getting pregnant… that threw everything into even more chaos. It forced me to confront my own fears and insecurities. I had to figure out what *I* wanted, not what my parents wanted or what society expected of me.

It made me really independent, I think. I learned to rely on myself, because I didn't always trust that other people would be there for me. But it also made me crave connection, a real, lasting connection.

It took a long time to realize that my parents' divorce wasn't my fault, and that it didn't mean all relationships were doomed. It just meant that I had to be careful, to choose someone who was honest and supportive and who I could really trust.

And with Mark… well, he was different. He was solid. He didn't try to fix me or change me. He just… accepted me for who I was. And that made all the difference.

It's still something I think about, you know? The impact of my parents' divorce. But I'm learning to let go of the past and focus on building a future that's different. A future where I can have a healthy, loving relationship, even if it's not the traditional kind.

It's messy. Life is messy. But that's okay. It's all part of the process.

Ugh, okay, you want me to be all self-reflective? Fine. It's kinda weird talking about myself, but… alright.

I think what makes my story…well, not *special*, exactly, because unplanned pregnancies happen all the time, but *unique*… is that it wasn't about the tragedy of it all. You know? A lot of movies and stories about teen pregnancy are all doom and gloom. Like, it's the end of the world.

But it wasn't for me. It was…complicated. Messy. Scary, sure. But it was also funny, and weird, and ultimately, kinda empowering.

I think people connected with the fact that I didn't try to be perfect. I said what I thought, even if it was sarcastic or inappropriate. I wasn't trying to be a role model or anything. I was just trying to figure things out.

And I think the relationship with Paulie and Vanessa was a big part of it. It wasn't a typical "dramatic teen pregnancy" situation. They were just…normal people, trying to do the right thing. And they were kinda weird and awkward too, which made it feel more real.

I guess what I'm saying is, it wasn't about the pregnancy itself. It was about growing up, and figuring out who you are, and learning to make tough decisions. And it was about finding your own family, even if it's not the family you expected.

It was about being honest, even when it's hard. And about finding the humor in the chaos.

So yeah, that's what I think makes it…different. It wasn't a story about a mistake. It was a story about a life. And that's kinda cool, I guess.

Don't make me blush. It's embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, good friends. That's…important. I've learned a lot about that lately, actually. It's not about having a ton of friends, it's about having the *right* ones.

Here's what I look for, or, like, what I appreciate:

*   **Honesty, but not brutal honesty:** You gotta be able to tell me the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. But you don't have to be a jerk about it. There's a difference.
*   **Someone who *gets* my sarcasm:** Seriously. If you can't handle a little bit of snark, we're probably not gonna click.
*   **No judgment:** I make a lot of questionable decisions. A good friend doesn't freak out about them, they just…deal. And maybe offer a little advice, but not too much.
*   **Someone who can be quiet with me:** You don't always have to be talking. Sometimes it's nice to just sit in silence and not feel awkward.
*   **Loyalty:** Like, if someone's talking trash about me, you gotta have my back.
*   **A good sense of humor:** Life's too short to be serious all the time.
*   **Someone who doesn't try to fix everything:** Sometimes you just need someone to listen, not to solve your problems.
*   **And, honestly, someone who can tolerate my music taste.** It's…eclectic.

Basically, I value friends who are real, who are honest, and who don't try to change me. I'm already a mess, I don't need anyone to make it worse.

It's hard to find people like that, but when you do, you gotta hold onto them. They're worth their weight in gold. Or, like, vintage records. Whatever.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like it was all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It definitely shook things up.

With my parents? It was…rough at first. My dad just kinda shut down. He's not good with big feelings. My mom, she tried to be supportive, but she was also, like, really worried. And kept offering me advice I didn't ask for. It took a while for us to find our footing. We still have moments, but it's better now. They're trying.

Paul? That was…complicated. We were just kids. And suddenly, we had this huge responsibility. It forced us to grow up, fast. We fought a lot, but we also leaned on each other. He was surprisingly good at the whole practical stuff, like researching adoption agencies. He's a good guy, even if he's a little clueless sometimes.

My best friend, Leah? She was amazing. She didn't judge me, she just…was there. She helped me pick out baby names, she went to doctor's appointments with me, she just listened when I needed to vent. She's the best.

And then there were people at school. Some were supportive, some were just…weird. A lot of whispering and staring. It was annoying. But I learned to tune it out.

Honestly, it made me realize who my real friends were. The people who stuck around, the people who didn't judge me. And it made me appreciate them even more.

It also made me realize that people are complicated. Everyone reacts differently to things. And sometimes, you just have to accept that and move on.

It wasn't easy, but it definitely changed my relationships. For the better, mostly. It forced me to be honest with people, and it forced them to be honest with me. And that's a good thing, even if it's uncomfortable sometimes.

It's like…it stripped away all the pretense. You know? It just showed me who people really are. And that's valuable. Even if it's not always what you want to see.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not like I sit around and contemplate my "worldview" or anything. But if you're asking what makes me, me… what I think is important… here's the deal.

First off, **honesty.** Like, brutal honesty. I don't really have time for BS. People should just say what they mean, even if it's awkward. It saves everyone a lot of trouble.

Then there's **authenticity.** I think people should just be themselves, even if that means being weird or flawed. Trying to be someone you're not is exhausting and pointless.

**Independence** is a big one. I don't need anyone to tell me what to do or how to think. I'll figure it out myself. Which sometimes leads to mistakes, but that's okay.

I also believe in **taking responsibility for your actions.** No excuses. If you mess up, own it. And try to learn from it.

And, surprisingly, **compassion.** Even though I try to act all tough and sarcastic, I actually care about people. I think everyone deserves a little bit of kindness, even the ones who are annoying.

I guess I also believe in the power of **finding humor in everything.** Life is messy and complicated, and sometimes you just have to laugh to keep from crying.

I don't really buy into a lot of the stuff adults try to tell you about "the right way" to live. I think everyone has to figure that out for themselves. And it's okay if your path looks different from everyone else's.

Basically, I just try to be real. And I expect other people to do the same. It's not always easy, but it's worth it.



It's kinda weird to analyze myself like this. I usually just make fun of other people. But yeah, those are some of the things I believe in. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, the name. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, "Oh, let's pick something cute!" It had to be *right*.

Paul and I went back and forth for weeks. He wanted something classic, like…Henry. Which is fine, I guess. But it felt kinda boring. I wanted something a little more…unique. Something that felt like *her*.

We made a list, a really long list. And then we started crossing things off. Too common, too weird, too…something. It was exhausting.

Then, one day, I was looking through my dad's old records. He had this Joni Mitchell album, "Blue." And I just…felt something. It was a really strong feeling.

So I suggested it. "Blue."

Paul was hesitant at first. He thought it was too…out there. But I explained it to him. Joni Mitchell is an amazing songwriter. Her music is honest and vulnerable and beautiful. And "Blue" is a song about sadness and hope and everything in between.

I wanted my daughter to have a name that represented strength and sensitivity. A name that reminded her to be true to herself, even when things are hard.

And honestly, I just liked the way it sounded. It's simple, but it's also kind of…powerful.

So, that's how we decided on Blue. It felt right. It felt like *her*. And it's a little piece of my dad, too, which is nice.

It's not a name everyone understands, and that's okay. It's our name for our daughter. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really awkward, emotionally messy hike up a steep hill. But yeah, I learned a lot. About myself, about Paul, about Annie, about the whole world.

I think the biggest thing I learned was that I'm stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I was just a kid, and suddenly I was dealing with…all of this. And I didn't fall apart. I made a really hard decision, and I stuck with it. That took guts, even if I didn't feel like I had any at the time.

I also learned that things aren't always black and white. It wasn't just about "giving up" the baby. It was about wanting the best for him, and realizing that I wasn't the best person to give him that. It was about being selfless, which is something I hadn't really thought about before.

And the world…well, the world is full of people who are just trying to do their best. Annie and Mark, they were amazing. They were so open and honest and…normal. It made me realize that there are good people out there, even when it feels like everything is falling apart.

I also learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other. Paul, even though he was kinda clueless sometimes, he was always there for me. And my dad, he was surprisingly cool about everything.

I guess…I learned that life is complicated. And messy. And sometimes really scary. But it's also beautiful. And worth fighting for.

It made me realize I didn't have to have all the answers right now. I didn't have to have a perfect plan. I just had to be true to myself and do what felt right. And that's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

It was a really weird, intense experience. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. It made me who I am. And that's…something.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. It's been…a while. And honestly, thinking about it all still makes my stomach do that weird flip-flop thing.

If I could go back… hmm. It's not like I regret anything, exactly. It all happened for a reason, right? And I learned a lot. But…

I think I would have let myself *feel* things more. I was so good at being sarcastic and deflecting, at pretending like everything was fine when it really wasn't. I was so focused on being strong and independent that I didn't really let myself be vulnerable.

I probably would have spent more time with my dad. We were okay, but…we weren't *close*, you know? I was always kinda pushing him away. I wish I'd just…talked to him more.

And maybe I would have been a little less judgmental of Mark. He was trying, okay? He was just…a little clueless. I was pretty harsh on him.

But honestly? I don't know. Everything happened the way it was supposed to. I met Paul and Annie, and they were amazing. And I gave my baby a good life. That's what mattered.

So, would I have done things differently? Maybe a little. But I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It made me who I am. And I think…I think I'm okay with that.

It's just…sometimes I wish I hadn't been so busy trying to be cool and collected. Sometimes I wish I'd just let myself be a mess. It would have been a lot easier, probably. But then again, maybe it wouldn't have been me. And that's kinda scary.



It's complicated, okay? Don't make me think about it too much. It's been a long time.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. A *lot*. Honestly, it kinda comes with the territory of, like, existing. Especially when you're trying to figure things out.

Okay, so here's the thing. Things are gonna fall apart. Plans are gonna change. People are gonna let you down. It's just…how it is. And you can either curl up in a ball and eat a whole pizza, or you can…deal with it.

I'm not saying it's easy. It totally sucks. But I've learned a few things.

First, **let yourself feel it.** Don't try to pretend you're okay when you're not. It's okay to be sad, or angry, or frustrated. Just don't wallow in it forever.

Second, **figure out what you can control.** You can't control everything that happens to you, but you can control how you react to it. Focus on what you *can* do, even if it's just something small.

Third, **talk to someone.** Seriously. Don't bottle it up. Vent to a friend, a family member, or even a therapist. Sometimes just getting it off your chest can make a huge difference.

Fourth, **re-evaluate.** Maybe the plan wasn't as great as you thought it was. Maybe this is an opportunity to try something new. Sometimes things fall apart so better things can fall together. It's cheesy, but it's true.

And finally, **remember that you're strong.** You've gotten through tough stuff before, and you'll get through this too. You're more resilient than you think.

It's not about pretending everything's perfect. It's about learning to cope with the imperfections and moving forward. And maybe eating a small piece of pizza. Just not the whole thing.



It's a process, okay? It takes time. And it's okay to stumble along the way. Just keep going. You got this.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. That's…complicated. It wasn't like a typical best-friend-forever kind of thing, you know? It started out pretty surface-level. She was just…there. Always perfectly put together, always knowing what to say, always kinda judging me with those big eyes. She was the opposite of me in pretty much every way.

At first, I mostly just tolerated her because she was Paul's friend, and Paul was…well, Paul. But then, when I got pregnant, things started to shift. She was the only one who didn't freak out, you know? She didn't try to fix things or tell me what to do. She just…listened.

And she helped me with the ads for the parents. Which was mortifying, honestly. But she was good at it. She knew how to make things look…appealing. And she didn't make fun of me for wanting a non-traditional family.

I think what really changed things was when she confessed she'd been faking being into Van. It was a huge deal for her to admit that she was just pretending to be someone she wasn't to fit in. And it made me realize that everyone's got their stuff, you know? Even the seemingly perfect ones.

It wasn't like we suddenly became best friends. We still had our differences. But we started to understand each other. She saw past my sarcasm and my awkwardness, and I saw past her perfectionism. We started to support each other, genuinely.

By the end, she wasn't just Paul's friend anymore. She was *my* friend. Someone I could rely on. Someone who got me, even when I didn't get myself. It wasn't a dramatic, tearful declaration of friendship or anything. It was just…there. A quiet understanding. And that was enough.

It was a weird friendship, for sure. But it was a real one. And I'm glad I had her. Even if she did make me wear that ridiculous dress to the baby shower.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to talk about my *favorite* part of being pregnant? That's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a waddle in the park, with a constant craving for cheese fries.

But if I had to pick something… I think it was the feeling of… well, of *having* something. Like, before, it was just me. And my music. And avoiding people. And then suddenly, there was this little person growing inside me. And it was… weirdly comforting.

It wasn't the kicks, honestly. Those were kinda freaky at first. It was more like… knowing that something good was happening, even when everything else felt totally messed up. Like, my life was a disaster, but *this* was good. This was something I could be proud of.

And I know it sounds cheesy, but it was kinda cool to feel connected to something bigger than myself. Like, I was part of this whole cycle of life and stuff. Which is, like, way more profound than anything I usually think about.

Plus, people were actually nice to me for once. Which was a bonus.

But don't get me wrong. It was also really hard. And scary. And I definitely wouldn't recommend it to everyone. But yeah, that feeling of having something good growing inside me… that was probably my favorite part.

Don't tell anyone I said that, okay? It'll ruin my reputation.
